item.title: Turning Junk Frequencies Into Gold
item.description:
The 2.4 GHz WiFi band we use every day wasn’t originally designed for WiFi at all. It was part of the ISM band - Industrial, Scientific, and Medical - a section of the radio spectrum designated for devices that unintentionally emit radiation as a byproduct of their operation. These bands, ranging from 6.78 MHz to 245 GHz, were meant for devices like microwave ovens, industrial heaters, and medical equipment.

The 2.4 GHz band, specifically the range of 2.4 to 2.5 GHz, is shared by devices like microwave ovens and 802.11b/g WiFi. This might seem problematic, but the ISM bands were not originally set up for licensed, intentional transmission. The emissions from ISM devices were considered a necessary side effect.

However, in 1985, the FCC opened these bands for intentional use, allowing technologies like cordless phones, wireless networking, and even video transmission to operate without a license. This decision came with a few caveats: a power limit of 4 watts and a “no complaints” policy regarding interference. If a microwave oven disrupts your WiFi, it’s simply an unavoidable consequence of using this unlicensed spectrum.

You might wonder why anyone would choose to use these interference-prone frequencies. The answer is the appeal of license-free operation and sufficient power for various wireless technologies. The limited range of these signals, combined with interference-resistant modulation techniques like DSSS, FHSS, and OFDM, makes sharing the spectrum feasible. These techniques are employed in various technologies, including cordless phones, WiFi (802.11b, a, g), Bluetooth, and WiMAX, allowing them to function effectively within the ISM bands.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Some Cabinet Work
item.description:
Over the weekend, I made progress reassembling the Beogram 4002, focusing on the cabinet trim and deck cover. To prevent damage, I had previously removed the rosewood trim.

The trim is attached to a metal frame that slides in and out to lock and unlock the cabinet. This frame relies on five guide washers, which are commonly broken in Beogram 4002 units. This one was no different. These washers have a unique design, as detailed in a past Beolover blog post.

This Beogram now has replacements for these washers, thanks to 3D printed versions from Beolover.

While it might seem possible to use standard flat washers as substitutes, the specially designed printed parts are essential for correctly assembling the Beogram cabinet. As explained in the Beolover blog post, these washers act as guides for the cabinet locking frame to slide smoothly.

While attaching the cabinet trim and lock, I discovered the frame was separating from the rosewood along the front.

This separation needed to be fixed with epoxy before I could proceed. Gluing it wasn’t a good option due to the risk of mess and potential damage. To work on it safely, I carefully removed the trim piece. To protect the rosewood finish, I covered it with painter’s tape, preventing scratches or glue residue. The picture shows the areas prepared for the epoxy.

I used small clamps, similar to the larger ones in my workshop, which are ideal for delicate tasks like this.

For this repair, I opted for slow-drying epoxy, which allows ample time for cleanup and adjustments. I let it dry overnight.

The following morning, the trim and locking piece were ready. I attached it to the cabinet using the five guide washers. The fit is snug and visually appealing.

item.title: Will You Save With Fractional Line Services?
item.description:
You might think ordering less bandwidth would save you money, but when it comes to telecom lines, that’s not always the case. While getting a fraction of a T1 line’s capacity seemed like a good idea for those who didn’t need the full 1.5 Mbps, the cost savings weren’t as significant as one might expect.

The issue is that the infrastructure for a T1 line, the “pipe,” has a fixed capacity regardless of actual usage. Even if you only use a fraction of the bandwidth, the underlying cost remains largely the same. Although fractional T1 lines were offered, they were often priced disproportionately to the actual bandwidth used.

Nowadays, getting fractional speeds can be more expensive than a full T1 line due to the specialized engineering required. It’s sometimes more cost-effective to order the full T1 and not utilize its entire capacity.

Traditional telecom services lack scalability, offering large jumps between service levels. A newer technology, Carrier Ethernet (also known as Metro Ethernet), addresses this limitation with its high scalability.

Carrier Ethernet offers standard network speeds like 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps, and 1000 Mbps, but also provides a wide range of bandwidth options in between. The key is to have a port that can handle your maximum expected speed, allowing you to easily upgrade bandwidth later with a simple phone call to your provider.

To avoid paying for unused capacity, compare pricing for fractional T1, DS3, and OC3 services with Ethernet over Copper and Ethernet over Fiber. Since prices depend on location, request a specific quote for your business address.

Note: Image of fraction dice courtesy of Arjan on Wikimedia Commons.

item.title: VPN Internet Access Links Facilities
item.description:
Connecting multiple business locations into a unified network can be a costly endeavor. While traditional solutions like private lines and Frame Relay have their merits, a newer method is gaining traction, especially for businesses with numerous sites.

Private lines offer unparalleled reliability, consistent bandwidth, and robust security due to their dedicated nature. They are well-suited for connecting phone systems or transmitting video between locations. However, the need for a separate line between each pair of sites makes them expensive, particularly as the network expands.

Many businesses prefer a mesh network where all locations connect to a central network “cloud,” enabling communication between any two points. Frame Relay, private IP, and MPLS networks offer this, but a more cost-effective solution exists: the internet.

While not as reliable or predictable as private networks, the internet’s widespread availability and affordability make it an attractive option for inter-site connectivity. Its limitations can be overcome, making it suitable for applications like email, point of sale transactions, data updates, and e-commerce. The TCP/IP protocol ensures reliable data transfer even with occasional slowdowns or minor data loss.

Security concerns are addressed through encryption, creating a “tunnel” for private data transmission over the public internet. This forms a virtual private network (VPN), combining aspects of both private and public networks. Various standardized methods like IPsec, PPTP, and SSL are available for establishing VPNs.

Businesses can implement their own VPNs or utilize managed solutions where a provider oversees routers and security software. With high-speed internet connections becoming increasingly affordable, now might be an opportune time to implement a new VPN or upgrade existing systems for faster speeds and potentially lower costs.

For guidance on choosing the best solution for your needs, whether connecting a handful or thousands of locations, our team of expert consultants is here to help. Contact T1 Rex to discuss your facility communication requirements.

item.title: Can Hotels Afford to Upgrade Bandwidth?
item.description:
Hotels and motels face a challenge: guests love fast internet, but providing it is expensive. Upgrading bandwidth seems like the obvious solution, but it’s costly, especially since guests expect free Wi-Fi.

While it seems logical that faster internet costs more, that’s not always true. Hotels can sometimes secure better internet speeds for less money. This depends on where they get their internet service and the age of their contracts.

The internet landscape has changed rapidly. Many hotels signed contracts for wireless internet years ago when options were limited and technology was different. These contracts may be outdated and more expensive than current offerings. Just like phone lines, competition in the internet service market has increased, leading to better prices.

Many hotels aren’t equipped to navigate the complexities of telecom contracts. They might rely on technology vendors who may not be getting them the best deals. Instead of going through vendors, hotels can work with specialized telecom brokers. These brokers can identify competing internet providers in their area and find the best offers, saving hotels money.

Technology has also advanced. Options like Carrier Ethernet and bonded T1 lines offer attractive pricing and higher bandwidth. Increased competition and advanced search tools make finding affordable broadband services easier than ever. Hotels can likely find better internet service for a lower price than they are currently paying.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Alternate "Circuit Diagram 2" with 24V Scale Illumination Lamps
item.description:
I recently acquired a well-preserved Beogram 4000 service manual containing a unique supplementary diagram. This diagram, Circuit Diagram 2, outlines the control system and features a notable difference in the position scale illumination. Instead of the typical two 12V bulbs wired in series, it depicts two 24V bulbs connected in parallel to the 24V power source.

This discovery complicated a recent interaction with Sonavor, who is currently restoring his own Beogram 4000. We both mistakenly assumed his model used the 24V configuration based on my inquiry about providing 12V or 24V LED bulb replacements. Ultimately, his model utilizes the standard 12V setup.

Nevertheless, I decided to share a high-resolution scan of this unusual 24V circuit diagram with fellow Bang & Olufsen enthusiasts.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Replacing the RAM Battery
item.description:
The Beocord 9000 utilizes a 3V battery to power its 16-word memory chip, an MCM144102, which is described as a peripheral memory unit in the Motorola 6804 manual but lacks readily available detailed specifications. This chip is responsible for storing calibration data and potentially the system time, although further investigation is required. A visual representation of the circuit is included below.

A positive aspect of the design is the inclusion of diode D27, which safeguards the battery against reverse polarity connection. This suggests that replacing the soldered battery with a holder-based solution is a viable approach.

The battery is situated directly beneath the TIME CAL indicator on the cabinet. In this instance, the original battery exhibited leakage of the lithium compound, evident as a green-grey substance surrounding it. During the battery removal process, a minor explosion occurred due to the leaked compound reacting with heat. Lithium’s high reactivity with oxygen in the presence of heat necessitates caution. Fortunately, protective eyewear prevented any harm. However, it is strongly advised to sever the battery leads using wire cutters before desoldering to minimize risk. Additionally, cleaning the area with ethanol to remove residual compound is recommended. The image below displays the battery location after cleaning.

A 1/3N battery holder was chosen due to the scarcity and cost of tabbed 1/3N batteries. A holder also facilitates easier future battery replacements, as it can be accessed by simply removing the glass panel without tools. The subsequent images show the new battery and the holder.

The Newark 25T0455 battery holder, magnified:

The image below shows the soldered holder. Maintaining correct polarity during installation is crucial; ensure the + and - markings on the holder align with those on the PCB to avoid future confusion.

Finally, the image below shows the holder with the battery inserted. The modification blends well, appearing almost intentional. It is unusual to encounter a soldered battery in such a high-end device, but consumer electronics are often engineered with a limited lifespan in mind.

item.title: When Dial-Up Internet Service Makes Sense
item.description:
While many have transitioned to residential broadband and dedicated business internet, it’s important to remember that approximately half of US internet users still rely on dial-up. Despite its age, dial-up has significantly improved and remains a viable option for many, even in professional settings.

Is dial-up outdated? Not really. Consider how you would access email or websites during a broadband outage. Even the most reliable DSL and cable providers experience occasional disruptions. It’s important to remember that broadband often prioritizes convenience over absolute necessity. When necessary, a simple phone line connection to your computer can provide 56K internet access.

Not everyone requires constant internet connectivity. Paying $35 to $45 monthly for broadband or $24 for heavily advertised dial-up services is unnecessary for users who only spend an hour per day checking email and browsing websites. For those online 15 hours or less per month, options like CogniSurf at $7.95 a month are available. Alternatively, WorldVerge provides unlimited dial-up access for $9.95 a month.

What does $9.95 a month with WorldVerge entail? It includes unlimited 56K dial-up internet with spam and virus filtering, five email accounts, complimentary 24/7 technical support, and dialers for both PC and Macintosh. For an additional $2.95 per month, an accelerator option can increase email download and website access speeds by up to six times. While not impacting software downloads, website FTPs, or VoIP calls, this enhancement nearly replicates the broadband experience.

Dial-up internet remains a viable and affordable option for various purposes, such as broadband backup, business travel, occasional use, and internet access in areas without DSL or cable coverage.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Lubrication of Platter Motor Bearings
item.description:
During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513), the DC motor was lubricated. This particular motor uses brushes and has simple sleeve bearings.

To access the bearings for lubrication, the pulley and outer housing were removed. The pulley is attached to the shaft with glue, allowing for easy removal. After taking out two small screws, the housing can be opened and the motor taken out.

Next, the black rubber vibration insulation boot was removed, revealing the circuit board connected to the brushes. After noting the position of the bottom part, three screws were removed to detach it and the brush plate.

The bottom bearing was lubricated by applying a small amount of silicone grease into the bottom sleeve located below the brushes. The top bearing was greased by applying a bit to the shaft and moving it up and down within the bearing.

The motor was then reassembled, using the slanted plastic disc on the commutator to guide the brushes into place during reassembly. Following the disassembly steps in reverse, the motor was placed back into the outer housing. Finally, the pulley was reattached to the shaft using superglue gel.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Cosmetic Items, Final Adjustments, and a Test Drive with George Duke on MPS!
item.description:
The Beogram 4000 restoration project, originating from Germany, is nearing completion. After adjusting the sub-chassis and arm height, I set the arm lowering limit, a crucial measure to protect the stylus from potential damage if the record detection fails.

Next, I calibrated the tracking weight, opting to enhance stability by replacing the original locking washer setup with an M3 nut and washer to secure the counterweight position.

Following that, I calibrated the arm weight using a digital scale and fine-tuned the feedback by adjusting the tracking sensor LED with a blue potentiometer.

The final adjustment involved setting the motor voltage, confirmed by achieving smooth sine curves on the oscilloscope for both 33 and 45 RPM.

To complete the restoration, I replaced the damaged main aluminum platter and arm cover with pristine parts from a 4002 5501 Beogram and a donor 4004, respectively. I specifically sought an early 4002 arm cover to match the 4000’s aesthetic.

Finally, I tested the restored Beogram 4000 with a George Duke record, “Liberated Fantasies,” a personal favorite from the MPS label. Witnessing this turntable perform flawlessly after its initial damaged state was incredibly rewarding.

item.title: Vote MPLS & Ethernet for Better Bandwidth
item.description:
The 2008 election season is upon us. To determine which candidates best serve your interests, we suggest considering MPLS and Ethernet for reliable bandwidth, improved performance, and reduced costs over 1-3 years. Let’s delve into their platforms to see if they deserve your vote.

IP Networking is currently the leading technology. Initially confined to local offices, IP has expanded to WANs at state, regional, and national levels. Today, almost all network designs are centered around IP or Internet Protocol.

What explains IP’s rapid growth? IP, and particularly Ethernet, dominate local area networking, offering high reliability, affordability, and near-universal connectivity. This local success naturally translates to wider adoption in metropolitan and long-haul networks. With a simple RJ45 connector interface, it’s no surprise that carriers are incorporating IP core networks into their infrastructure.

MPLS, or MultiProtocol Label Switching, bridges the gap between older TDM (Time Division Multiplexing) networks with their synchronized channels and newer packet-switching networks. This includes Carrier Ethernet and the Internet, both operating under the IP umbrella.

MPLS brings the advantages of private networking to businesses of all sizes. It seamlessly interconnects diverse locations, offering class-based bandwidth that prioritizes voice, video, and data transmission with minimal latency, jitter, or packet loss. Since the cost of the MPLS cloud is shared among users under the network manager’s control, connecting your locations becomes very cost-effective.

T1 lines, known for their dedicated bandwidth and reliability, often provide access to MPLS networks. Each location connects to the MPLS cloud through its own T1 line, with the cloud handling interconnectivity.

Ethernet rivals T1 lines when higher bandwidth is required locally or within a metro area. Choose Ethernet for superior performance at speeds of 10, 100, and 1,000 Mbps.

MPLS and Ethernet are a powerful combination because they represent progress. They offer higher bandwidth options and lower costs per Mbps compared to older technologies like Frame Relay and SONET. If this aligns with your business needs, consider MPLS Networks and Metro & Carrier Ethernet. These services are available immediately.

item.title: Sipping on the Trunk Lines
item.description:
The history of telephone trunks goes back to the early days of telephones. Trunks are lines that carry multiple phone conversations, initially connecting switchboards and switching offices. They’ve evolved from wire bundles to analog and now digital circuits, with T1, ISDN PRI, DS3, and SONET being common digital trunking services. However, SIP trunking is emerging as a popular alternative.

Telephone trunking saves money by combining multiple phone lines into a single high-bandwidth connection. T1 lines, including ISDN PRI, become cost-effective when exceeding 10-12 lines. ISDN PRI, a specific T1 type, provides up to 23 lines with Caller ID, making it popular for traditional PBX systems.

SIP (Session Initiation Protocol) trunking was designed for VoIP phone systems. SIP is a simple protocol widely used in enterprise VoIP systems. Many modern phones have built-in SIP and VoIP, connecting directly to LANs instead of separate phone networks. An IP PBX on the network manages calls between handsets and external lines.

SIP trunking addresses connecting those external lines. While connecting individual lines to an IP PBX for PSTN termination is viable for small setups, SIP trunking offers a more efficient method. Similar to using T1 or ISDN PRI for digital trunking, SIP keeps calls in VoIP packet format, utilizing the same signaling as handsets and IP PBX.

Many SIP trunks act as converged voice and data connections to providers, carrying internet traffic alongside calls. Voice is prioritized for quality, while remaining bandwidth serves internet needs. Call termination to the PSTN happens at the provider, who leverages bulk services for potential cost savings. On-network calls, even to other companies on the same service, may be free.

If SIP trunking seems beneficial for your business VoIP system, explore potential savings by checking out competitive SIP trunking phone services.

They value inquiries from nearby businesses that need equipment, installation, training, upgrades, or repairs. item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Capacitor Replacement on Unit #2
item.description:
The first Beomaster 1900 receiver is fully operational and undergoing testing in a listening room. However, the second unit still requires restoration.

Initial assessment of the second Beomaster 1900 has already been completed, and now it’s time to begin replacing capacitors on the main circuit board.

The main circuit board houses most of the capacitors that need replacing. Unfortunately, it cannot be removed for servicing and must remain connected to the wire harness.

Replacing capacitors on this board requires flipping the Beomaster over repeatedly to desolder old components and solder new ones. While experienced restorers might remove multiple capacitors at once, a safer approach is to replace them one by one, carefully checking polarity and value.

To prevent damage from repeated movement, I desolder the transformer’s secondary power wires from the board before starting the recapping process.

Several screws secure the main board to the chassis and heatsink assemblies. Since the plan involves replacing the thermal material on the output transistors, I remove the heatsinks to clean off the old paste.

With that done, the main board is ready for servicing. I use a simple foam block jig to support and protect the board during this process.

Next, I replace the +15 VDC power supply filter capacitor and apply new thermal paste, using a Sil-Pad for the chassis-mounted transistor.

For the ±31 VDC power supply filter capacitors, I rearrange and reattach terminals with heat shrink for a secure connection.

The rest of the capacitor replacements on the main board are straightforward, although time-consuming.

With the main board completed, only the Volume PCB and the Tone, Filter, and Tuning PCB remain to be recapped.

item.title: Increase Bandwidth Without Increasing Costs
item.description:
Companies need more bandwidth, especially for their wide area networks (WANs), but it can be very expensive. While high speeds are affordable within a company’s LAN, connecting to the outside world traditionally comes with much higher costs.

This is because WAN connections were typically provided by telecom companies using technology initially meant for phone services. While more modern providers have entered the market with updated infrastructure, even traditional providers are adapting to the demand for data services.

This increased competition presents opportunities for businesses to save money on bandwidth. By comparing prices from different providers, companies may find better deals than their existing contracts, especially if those contracts are outdated.

Engaging a telecom broker can simplify this process. Brokers can gather tailored quotes from multiple carriers, leveraging their relationships to secure competitive rates for businesses. Using a broker often results in better deals than businesses could get independently.

Another way to save on bandwidth costs is to switch to newer technologies. For example, Ethernet over Copper (EoC) offers comparable reliability and speed to traditional T1 lines but at a lower cost. EoC can provide double the bandwidth for the same price as a single T1 line, making it a cost-effective upgrade path.

Therefore, businesses have two primary options for increasing bandwidth without increasing costs: compare quotes from multiple providers, including newer entrants, and consider switching to newer, more cost-effective technologies like EoC. Utilizing both strategies can lead to significant savings on essential bandwidth services.

item.title: It's Wireless Cleanup Time Again

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): A New Arrival from California
item.description:
I recently acquired a Beogram 4002 (Type 5503; AC platter motor) turntable for restoration. The unit arrived in remarkably good shape. The dust cover is practically flawless, and the aluminum panels and platter are in fantastic condition.

However, there is a hole drilled into the top left corner of the aluminum plate surrounding the platter, meaning this part will need replacement. Thankfully, beneath the plates, the turntable appears to be in pristine, original condition.

This originality is a positive sign, as it usually means fewer unexpected problems during restoration. The turntable has the orange plastic transport lock bushings, which, as expected, disintegrated during shipping. Thankfully, the plinth corners are in perfect condition – a rarity!

Upon plugging in the turntable and pressing start, the carriage moved slowly to the LP setdown point and attempted to lower the arm. This is a good indication of the turntable’s overall health. A thorough cleaning and re-lubrication of the carriage and arm lowering mechanism should address the slow movement. This test also showed that the 33 RPM trimmer backlight bulb is out and the carriage pulley is cracked, both relatively easy fixes.

Overall, this Beogram 4002 is a great candidate for a complete restoration. With some work, it should return to like-new functionality. Stay tuned for updates on the restoration process!

item.title: Shared Internet Service for Apartment Buildings
item.description:
Property owners and managers are recognizing the increasing importance of broadband internet access, much like essential utilities. They are exploring ways to provide this service, similar to phone and cable companies. Offering high-speed internet can be a significant advantage in attracting and retaining tenants.

Becoming an internet service provider, even for a single building, requires reliable, dedicated internet access. T1 or Dedicated Internet provides this, ensuring the full bandwidth is dedicated to your use, unlike shared services like DSL and Cable. Consumer-grade services often prohibit sharing or reselling, while T1 allows you to share the connection with multiple users within your building.

With T1, you get a professional telecommunications service commonly used by small ISPs. A T1 Router connects to your building’s network, serving up to 25 users on a single line. Multiple T1 lines can be combined for even greater bandwidth.

Each T1 line offers 1.5 Mbps upload and download speeds, unlike services with limited upload speeds. While this may seem moderate, it is often sufficient for most users due to the dedicated nature of the connection. Bonding multiple lines can increase speeds up to 12 Mbps.

T1 service includes a Service Level Agreement (SLA), guaranteeing high availability and quick response times in case of outages. It is a reliable solution widely used by businesses.

The cost of providing internet service to tenants can be incorporated into the rent or charged separately. Providing wireless routers and setup assistance can be a valuable amenity for tenants.

T1’s advantage is its availability in areas where DSL and Cable internet are not accessible. It can be installed wherever traditional phone service is available.

The cost of T1 varies based on location and infrastructure. Prices start below $400 per month in major cities. Shared among tenants, the cost becomes very affordable.

Another option is T1 Integrated voice and data service, combining phone and internet on a single line. This is suitable for buildings requiring both services, with dynamic bandwidth allocation prioritizing internet use when no calls are in progress.

To determine if shared internet access is right for your property, consult with technical experts who can assess your needs and provide suitable options from various T1 service providers.

item.title: Dial-Up is Alive and Kicking
item.description:
In today’s world of high-speed internet, it might seem strange to talk about dial-up. Many people consider it outdated technology.

However, dial-up internet access is still relevant. Millions of people still use and appreciate it for browsing the internet and checking emails. This “outdated” technology remains profitable.

One of the main advantages of dial-up is its affordability. Unlimited access is available for a low monthly cost, making it a budget-friendly option compared to DSL or cable internet. The only cheaper option is free internet service.

Free internet is accessible in many places, like restaurants with WiFi, if you have a laptop or notebook computer with WiFi capability. Most new computers have this feature, but older computers can be equipped with a WiFi modem for a small price. This allows you to enjoy free internet while having a meal, though you still need to pay for the food.

However, relying on free WiFi has its limitations. It is not convenient if you need frequent access to your email or live in an area without readily available WiFi. Traveling or working late at night also presents challenges with relying solely on free WiFi.

If any of these situations apply to you, dial-up internet service might be a suitable choice. Most laptops and desktop computers, except for a few exceptions like the thin Apple Air (which has an accessory modem available), have a built-in dial-up modem. If your computer has a phone jack, it likely has a built-in modem.

You might be surprised at the capabilities of a 56 Kbps connection. Basic web browsing on text and graphics-heavy sites is possible, and some websites might load slowly even on broadband, making the difference unnoticeable.

A personal experience highlighted the usefulness of dial-up as a backup. When a cable internet provider experienced a lengthy service disruption during an upgrade, having a dial-up connection allowed for continued internet access. While broadband-dependent users struggled, those with dial-up could continue their online activities.

This situation demonstrates the value of dial-up as a reliable backup option when your primary broadband connection fails. While some providers offer limited free dial-up minutes as a backup, it’s not always guaranteed.

For those currently using or considering dial-up, exploring options like World Verge Dial-Up Internet is recommended. They provide unlimited access, local numbers, a travel-friendly dialer, spam and virus protection, email accounts, web space, compatibility with various computers, and 24/7 technical support for a reasonable monthly fee.

If faster web browsing is desired, an optional accelerator can enhance page loading speed. While it doesn’t affect music or video downloads, it can significantly improve the browsing experience for a small additional monthly cost.

item.title: Copper WAN Bandwidth Headed to 500 Mbps
item.description:
Ericsson has developed a new technology that could significantly boost data transmission speeds over existing copper wire infrastructure. This innovation allows for WAN connections over copper, achieving speeds up to 500 Mbps.

While Gigabit Ethernet is achievable with Cat-6 wiring for LAN connections, this technology focuses on connecting businesses to broadband providers using existing copper infrastructure. This is significant because many businesses require increased bandwidth for various purposes, including server farms, internet access, data transfer between locations, and the growing need for electronic medical record transfers.

Fiber optic cables offer superior bandwidth but come with high installation costs. Copper wiring, being ubiquitous and already in place, presents a cost-effective alternative. Ericsson’s approach leverages multiple copper pairs instead of relying on a single twisted pair. Using six copper pairs, they achieved 500 Mbps over a 500-meter range, enabling connections to nearby fiber-equipped buildings or FTTC boxes.

While not a novel concept, Ethernet over copper is already used in metropolitan areas. Ericsson’s technology takes it further, surpassing the 50-100 Mbps limitations of current installations. Similar to existing techniques, it employs multiple pair transmission and MIMO analysis to mitigate interference and signal reflections inherent in bundled copper cables.

With anticipated availability by year-end, Ericsson’s equipment offers a promising solution for businesses struggling with bandwidth limitations and seeking alternatives to expensive fiber optic installations. Existing copper-based services offer 45 Mbps speeds over a few miles, making this new technology a potential game-changer.

Schools & Libraries are Lagging Surprisingly, many elementary schools and libraries lack adequate internet access. They require modern broadband speeds, surpassing the outdated megabit per second standard. Today’s requirements necessitate fiber optic connections.

The FCC acknowledges this need, promoting internet speeds of at least 100 Mbps per 1,000 users for schools and libraries, with plans to increase this to 1,000 Mbps. Larger libraries require even faster speeds. The goal is to eventually achieve 10 Gbps per 1,000 students.

More Funding for Higher Bandwidths E-Rate, the government program providing discounts for internet access, has received a funding boost, increasing from $2.4 billion to $3.9 billion annually. A portion of this funding will support high-speed internet access, while the remaining funds will enhance infrastructure, including Wi-Fi. Support for outdated services like pagers and traditional phone lines will be phased out.

How to Qualify for E-Rate Discounts Schools, school districts, and libraries can apply for E-Rate discounts through the Universal Service Administrative Company (USAC). Service providers must also apply and receive a Service Provider Identification Number (SPIN). Many major carriers are already equipped to provide fiber optic broadband connections at various speeds.

How Much Are the Savings? E-Rate offers discounted service prices. Qualifying schools and libraries pay less for broadband access than businesses. The discount is determined by the poverty level and urban or rural status of the population served. Discounts range from 20% to 90%, calculated based on student eligibility for the national school lunch program.

The Easy Want to Find E-Rate Broadband While researching local providers or national carriers is an option, using a company specializing in E-Rate services simplifies the process. These companies, working with multiple carriers, can identify E-Rate providers in your area. This service is free, and inquiries are obligation-free.

item.title: Get Ready For The Recovery With Bandwidth on Demand
item.description:
The economy is recovering, benefiting some businesses while others struggle. Maintaining earnings through cost-cutting instead of increased sales won’t be sustainable. When the economy fully recovers, rapid adaptation will be crucial, but increased expenses are only justifiable with increased revenue. Bandwidth on demand offers a solution.

Bandwidth on demand allows businesses to access and pay for only the bandwidth they currently need, scaling usage up or down as required. This differs from the traditional approach of installing full capacity in advance, which poses financial risks if projected growth doesn’t materialize.

Bandwidth on demand offers flexibility, allowing businesses to increase or decrease bandwidth as needed. This adaptability is valuable in uncertain economic conditions.

Various services, often Ethernet-based, offer bandwidth on demand. Capabilities depend on the provider and existing infrastructure, such as copper or fiber optic cables.

ISDN PRI, for example, can support up to 23 phone lines on a single line. Businesses can start with a smaller number of lines and add more as call volume grows.

Even T1 lines, offering 1.5 Mbps, can be purchased fractionally, allowing for future upgrades to full capacity or beyond by combining multiple lines.

Consulting a bandwidth specialist is recommended to determine the most cost-effective options based on current and projected needs. Free consultations are available through Telarus.

item.title: Ethernet Over Copper Vs T1
item.description:
The T1 line is a widely available and dependable business bandwidth solution. It provides dedicated bandwidth at a reasonable cost, making it a reliable choice. However, another service called Ethernet over Copper (EoC) is gaining popularity as a viable alternative.

EoC is an Ethernet WAN connection that can connect multiple business locations or provide a dedicated high-speed Ethernet connection. It can also serve as an access point to private cloud networks, including national and international MPLS networks.

Both EoC and T1 lines are delivered using existing telephone wiring, known as twisted-pair cabling. Both technologies utilize multiple wire pairs through a process called bonding to increase bandwidth.

While they use different protocols and modulation techniques to transmit data, these technical details are generally not a concern for users. The important factor to consider is the amount of bandwidth available at a given price point.

In many cases, EoC offers both higher bandwidth and lower prices. This is partly due to the technology’s efficiency in transmitting data over copper wiring. Additionally, competitive carriers aiming to establish a market presence often promote EoC, driving down prices.

T1 lines typically provide a reliable 1.5 Mbps per line, which can be increased by adding more lines through bonding. However, bonding beyond 10-12 Mbps becomes less cost-effective, making other solutions like DS3 more suitable.

Ethernet offers a broader range of bandwidth options, from low speeds of around 1 Mbps to the standard 10 Mbps Ethernet used in LANs, and even up to 45 Mbps. However, EoC has distance limitations, requiring proximity to a carrier point of presence. T1 and bonded T1 solutions, on the other hand, do not face these limitations.

For businesses in rural areas or locations where EoC is unavailable, an emerging option called Ethernet over DS1 (EoDS1) offers a solution. EoDS1 utilizes the DS1 data specification used in T1 lines to transport Ethernet, effectively delivering Ethernet over a T1 line using specialized equipment.

The best service ultimately depends on your location. To make an informed decision, consider obtaining competitive quotes from providers. Request an Ethernet over Copper vs T1 Pricing and Availability analysis, and a Telarus consultant can provide recommendations tailored to your specific needs. Residential service is not available.

item.title: The Dark Side of Spectrum Renewal
item.description:
Half a century ago, the government embraced urban renewal, demolishing and rebuilding deteriorated urban areas for housing projects or highways leading to suburbs. Similarly, today, we’re witnessing “spectrum renewal,” where sections of the radio frequency spectrum are deemed too valuable for older technologies like analog TV and cell phone service, despite their widespread use.

This isn’t driven by lack of public demand. Millions of analog TV sets and cell phones are still functional. While people desire new technology like HDTV, not everyone can instantly replace existing devices. Analog cell service, vital for systems like OnStar and home alarms, faces a similar fate, leaving users stranded when it’s shut down.

The driving force behind this is intense competition for limited spectrum resources. Unlike the past, where new technologies like FM radio and UHF TV coexisted with existing ones, today’s demand for bandwidth-heavy services necessitates reclaiming spectrum occupied by older technologies.

This mirrors the challenges of dealing with outdated infrastructure. Just as land is finite, usable radio frequency spectrum is a limited resource. The most desirable frequencies, offering high bandwidth and good signal propagation, are in high demand, creating pressure to replace older technologies.

While spectrum renewal enables advancements in mobile technology, it has downsides. The potential financial gains from spectrum auctions contribute to the push to shut down analog TV. Similarly, broadband over power line technology could disrupt shortwave radio.

This raises the question: is this progress at an acceptable cost? While necessary for advancements in mobile technology, the challenge lies in minimizing disruptions as we transition away from technologies we’ve come to rely on.

item.title: CLEAR Sailing for 4G Wireless
item.description:
You’re hearing a lot about 4G wireless technology, but did you know that CLEAR is already rolling out its 4G WiMAX network? If you happen to live in an area where CLEAR WiMAX is currently offered, you can experience internet speeds comparable to DSL or Cable, all without the need for physical wires. They have a range of plans to suit your needs, whether it’s for your home, mobile device, or both.

Now, you might be wondering, what exactly is WiMAX, and how does it stack up against 3G? In simple terms, WiMAX is a globally recognized standard for wireless broadband, often described as WiFi but on a much larger scale, covering entire cities. While there are technical differences between the two, the comparison to city-wide WiFi is a good way to understand its potential uses.

The acronym WiMAX stands for “Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access” and is technically defined by the IEEE 802.16 standard, similar to how WiFi operates under the IEEE 802.11 standard. However, a key distinction is that WiMAX utilizes licensed frequencies and operates at a much higher power level. In contrast, WiFi shares unlicensed frequencies with a variety of devices like microwave ovens, Bluetooth devices, and cordless phones, all of which function at significantly lower power levels. This difference in frequency and power is the reason why your WiMAX connection remains strong even in your car or at home, while a WiFi signal weakens as you move away from its source, such as a cafe or your home network.

Remember when there was a big push to transition from analog to digital television broadcasting? A significant portion of the freed-up airwaves were auctioned off, and Clearwire emerged as one of the major winners. They utilized these acquired channels to offer their CLEAR WiMAX service. Thanks to the lack of signal interference and the strategic placement of powerful transmission towers, WiMAX can cover a significantly wider area, penetrating walls and reaching further distances. To use it, you’ll need a modem designed for either a PC or Mac, which connects to your computer or router much like a traditional broadband modem, except it receives its signal wirelessly. A more portable version, resembling a USB flash drive, is also available for laptops, offering mobile connectivity. The beauty of WiMAX is that it provides consistent service throughout the city, even while you’re on the move.

You might be thinking: “Doesn’t 3G cellular broadband offer similar capabilities?” You’re right, it does. However, WiMAX generally surpasses 3G in terms of speed. This advancement is why it’s categorized as 4G, or fourth-generation technology, signifying a step up from 3G. But what kind of speeds can you actually expect with WiMAX? CLEAR advertises average download speeds ranging from 3 to 6 Mbps, with bursts reaching up to 10 Mbps, a speed rarely achieved by 3G mobile broadband.

Currently, CLEAR WiMAX is accessible in select areas across the US, with plans to expand to more cities soon. The service is most prevalent in Texas, spanning nearly a dozen cities. Beyond Texas, CLEAR is also available in Hawaii; the Seattle-Portland corridor; Boise, Idaho; Chicago, Illinois; Las Vegas, Nevada; Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; Atlanta and Milledgeville, Georgia; and Charlotte, Greensboro, and Raleigh, North Carolina.

Another compelling advantage of CLEAR WiMAX 4G is its affordability. With plans starting at $30 per month, it’s often cheaper than many DSL and cable broadband plans and significantly more budget-friendly than 3G cellular data plans. And because it’s wireless, you eliminate the hassle of scheduling installations—the equipment is delivered straight to your doorstep, ready for you to set up and activate at your own convenience. No more waiting around for technicians. As a bonus, you can even combine home and mobile service, a feature that DSL and cable providers simply can’t match.

Does this sound like the broadband solution you’ve been waiting for? If so, explore further and order your CLEAR WiMAX 4G broadband service online today.

item.title: Your Point to Point Ethernet Connection

Point-to-point Ethernet offers a compelling alternative, often at a lower cost per Mbps, particularly for higher bandwidth needs. Ethernet streamlines data transmission by maintaining its format throughout the network, potentially allowing locations to function as a single bridged LAN.

This Ethernet connection, known as E-Line service, acts as a direct replacement for traditional T1 lines, forming a virtual Ethernet cable between two points. For those requiring multiple Ethernet services through a single physical connection, EVPL (Ethernet Virtual Private Line) presents a viable option.

When multiple locations need interconnected communication, E-LAN (Ethernet LAN) service provides a meshed network solution, enabling communication as if all sites share a single LAN.

Alternatively, E-Tree service facilitates point-to-multipoint connections, ideal for content distribution from a central source to multiple recipients without user interaction.

item.title: Business Ethernet Vs T1
item.description:
For decades, small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) have relied heavily on T1 lines. However, a new service called Business Ethernet is emerging as a strong competitor, offering comparable performance at a lower cost.

Business Ethernet, also referred to as Metro Ethernet, Ethernet over Copper, or Ethernet over Fiber, provides advantages such as scalable bandwidth options, reduced cost per Mbps, and wider availability. Its name emphasizes that Ethernet is no longer limited to Local Area Networks (LANs) and carriers, as it’s rapidly being adopted by SMBs.

Ethernet’s strength lies in its position as the universal standard for computer networking. Most desktop PCs, routers, switches, and cabling infrastructures are built to support Ethernet. This widespread adoption, driven by economies of scale, makes it challenging for other technologies to match Ethernet’s price-performance ratio.

The dominance of Ethernet has prompted telecom companies to re-evaluate their public networks. While T1 lines, DS3 bandwidth, and OCx services rely on circuit-switched technology initially designed for telephone calls, Ethernet operates on packet switching. As most networks have transitioned to packet switching, it’s logical to align telecom networks with this standard.

End-to-end packet switching presents intriguing possibilities. When LAN, Metropolitan Area Network (MAN), and Wide Area Network (WAN) all utilize Ethernet, businesses can implement layer 2 switching to connect multiple locations. This allows each location to maintain its own LAN while being interconnected through MAN and WAN Ethernet services, effectively extending the company network across different sites.

Business Ethernet’s scalability allows businesses to order a range of bandwidth options, often referred to as ports. As long as usage stays within the port’s capacity, bandwidth can be adjusted in small increments, even as low as 1 Mbps. This flexibility lets businesses acquire the bandwidth they need currently and easily upgrade as their requirements grow, optimizing costs without sacrificing performance.

When comparing costs with T1, variations exist depending on location and competition. However, it’s not uncommon to find 3 Mbps Ethernet priced similarly to a 1.5 Mbps T1 line. Another popular choice is 10 Mbps Ethernet, which often costs about the same as a T1 line from a previous contract period.

Ethernet over Copper stands out by utilizing specialized terminal equipment, installed by the service provider, to combine multiple copper pairs for the telecom connection. This enables bandwidths of up to 50 Mbps over existing copper wiring, eliminating the need for new fiber optic installation. Although T1 lines can also be bonded, their bandwidth is limited to a maximum of 10 or 12 Mbps.

Ultimately, the best choice depends on the specific needs of your business. Both T1 and Business Ethernet are reliable, professional-grade digital line services. Comparing competitive quotes for both options can help determine which option offers the most significant cost savings.

item.title: Cloud Hosting vs VPS
item.description:
Virtual Private Servers (VPS) offer a hosting solution for websites that have outgrown shared hosting but aren’t ready for the cost and responsibility of a fully dedicated server. However, a new option allows for flexible scaling and a pay-as-you-go model: cloud server hosting.

Discussions about cloud computing versus managing your own data center are becoming increasingly common. However, many companies haven’t reached the stage where investing in a complete in-house data center is necessary. They haven’t even considered setting up a server rack for web hosting, email, and other services. This is because outsourcing these tasks to hosting providers has become highly appealing.

Small businesses, such as those operated by freelancers, small retailers, and design studios, often start with template-based websites and hosting provided by local web services companies. As they expand beyond the basic “brochure” website or desire more control over their design and hosting, they often transition to budget-friendly hosting services found online. With hosting plans costing less than $4 per month, there’s little motivation to handle everything themselves.

How can companies offer such inexpensive hosting while remaining profitable? These low-cost plans fall under the category of shared hosting. While the control panel might give the impression of having a dedicated server, the reality is quite different. Dozens, or even hundreds, of other websites might share the same server without your knowledge. The only indication of shared resources might be occasional slowdowns. If your resource usage becomes excessive, the hosting provider might suggest upgrading to a virtual private server.

What exactly is a virtual private server? It bridges the gap between shared hosting and a dedicated server. A dedicated server provides complete control over a physical machine with its processor, memory, and storage. However, this also means bearing the cost and responsibility of managing a potentially underutilized resource. Conversely, needing more resources would require upgrading to a larger dedicated server or a cluster of servers, which can quickly become expensive.

VPS hosting utilizes virtualization software. A single physical server is divided into multiple virtual servers, each functioning like a standalone physical server. Only you and the hosting service are aware that it’s a virtual server, not a dedicated one. This shared infrastructure significantly reduces costs.

Virtual private servers offer increased resources and full root access, enabling software installation and customization. However, limitations remain due to sharing a physical machine and the challenges of adapting to changing resource requirements.

This is where cloud hosting comes in. The principle behind cloud computing is a vast pool of resources, including processors, RAM, hard drives, and bandwidth, managed by a provider. Instead of selling a fixed portion, access to this pool is leased. Similar virtualization principles as VPS hosting apply, but the resource pool is practically limitless. This allows for effortless scaling to meet current needs and easy adjustments as those needs change.

Cloud hosting servers provide choices of Linux or Windows operating systems, guaranteed CPU cycles, RAM, and hard disk space, hardware redundancy for reliability, full root/administrative access, a dedicated IP address, automatic nightly data backups, and compatibility with popular control panels like cPanel and WHM. Payment is based on hourly usage, without commitments, contracts, or setup fees. If servers are no longer needed, they can be canceled without penalty.

So, which hosting solution best suits your company? It’s recommended that organizations compare VPS, collocated private servers, and cloud hosting options, considering both pricing and features, to determine the optimal choice.

item.title: VoIP Without The Internet
item.description:
Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) emerged as an alternative telephone service that utilizes existing broadband connections for both internet and phone services. This allows providers to bypass fees associated with leasing traditional copper phone lines, leading to more attractive bundled packages for customers. Theoretically, the internet’s capacity should easily accommodate low-bandwidth voice data.

However, this isn’t always the case in reality. Internet paths, much like highways, can become congested, leading to bandwidth constraints, transmission delays (latency), and dropped data packets, all of which disrupt real-time communication like phone calls.

The primary bottleneck often lies in the “first mile,” the connection between a user and their provider’s network. Shared bandwidth services like DSL and cable internet don’t guarantee consistent quality or availability, resulting in fluctuating performance and dropped calls.

While budget-conscious consumers might tolerate such inconsistencies, businesses prioritize reliable communication to avoid customer dissatisfaction and disruptions. Negative experiences with VoIP have led some businesses to avoid internet-based phone systems entirely, while others have found solutions combining the advantages of both traditional and internet phone systems.

Successful businesses often achieve this by limiting their internet usage to non-time-sensitive tasks like web browsing, email, and data exchange. This doesn’t necessitate outdated phone systems and analog lines. There are two primary methods to benefit from VoIP without compromising quality:

  1. Hybrid PBX Systems: These systems utilize IP-based phones and switches within a company’s internal network, allowing for the use of a single Ethernet LAN for both data and voice communication. This requires careful network design to ensure smooth voice data transmission but eliminates the need for separate phone lines and their associated maintenance costs. External communication is then handled via traditional phone lines connected to the IP PBX.

  2. SIP Trunking: This involves a dedicated line connecting a company’s IP PBX directly to their VoIP provider. This dedicated line, often shared with internet data, ensures voice data quality by bypassing the public internet and connecting directly to the public telephone network via the provider. This guarantees consistent bandwidth availability and avoids competition with other internet users.

Both approaches prioritize quality and control by either connecting directly to the public phone network on-site or through a dedicated connection to the provider. This avoids the unpredictable nature of the public internet.

If your business aims to upgrade its phone system without compromising reliability, our consultants can present tailored solutions that address your needs while offering cost-saving opportunities. Share your requirements with us at EnterpriseVoIP.com.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival From Massachusetts - First Look
item.description:
A Beogram 4000 turntable arrived from a Massachusetts customer for a complete restoration. Thankfully, it was properly packaged and arrived without damage.

The turntable’s dust cover shows typical signs of use, but it will be replaced with a new one. The aluminum surfaces are in good shape overall.

However, there are some minor flaws. The keypad has a corner ding, suggesting it might have come loose during past transportation. Additionally, there are small scratches on the aluminum, possibly from the keypad moving around.

While the arm cover has some scuffs, the lettering is well-preserved, which is a positive sign. The plinth is in excellent condition, with sharp, undamaged corners.

Internally, the turntable appears to be mostly original, showing few signs of previous repairs. This is encouraging for the restoration process. The red carriage position marker is also in good condition.

As expected, the solenoid-actuated switch terminals show oxidation and signs of past attempts to fix them. These terminals will be cleaned, straightened, and plated with nickel and gold for long-term durability.

Initial testing showed promising results. The carriage moved correctly, the solenoid activated at the LP setdown point, and the strobe light functioned properly.

In conclusion, this Beogram 4000 restoration appears to be straightforward. The turntable is expected to be fully restored to its original appearance and functionality. Updates will follow as the process progresses.
