item.title: Beogram 4000: Cleaning of the Tone Arm Carriage Position Switches and a Non-Returning Carriage
item.description:
As a preliminary step in the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, I chose to verify the functionality of its control system. Prior testing had shown that the arm carriage would not return to its home position when moved across the platter without a record in place. Instead, it would travel to the center of the platter and stop. Ideally, the carriage should trigger the End Switch (ES) at this point and subsequently return to its home position on the right, turning off the turntable.

My initial focus was to ensure the proper operation of the carriage position switches, considering their critical role in the smooth functioning of this model. While not overly complex, I felt a video demonstration of the process would be beneficial to fellow enthusiasts working on this elegant design.

Despite cleaning the switches, the carriage run issue persisted. Upon closer examination, it became apparent that the spring responsible for activating the ES switch was not fully engaging. I removed the spring carrier again and slightly bent the spring downwards to increase the switch travel. This adjustment resolved the problem, enabling the carriage to return to its home position when moved across an empty platter.

However, further testing revealed a potential issue where the carriage could be manually positioned in a way that would not trigger the ES. This occurred when using the left arrow on the keypad to move the carriage beyond the ES activation point, seemingly overriding the ES function. As a result, the ES would release, preventing the carriage from returning when the arrow key was released.

To address this, I repositioned the ES activation spring slightly to the right on the carrier plate. This adjustment allows the carriage to reach its physical endpoint using the arrow key without moving beyond the ES switch’s activation zone.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): New Gold Plated RCA Plugs
item.description:
Over time, many Beogram devices have developed corroded DIN or RCA plugs. It’s a good idea to replace these old connectors with new, gold-plated ones. This specific Beogram 4002 (5513) came with RCA connectors.

I typically use large, modern, high-quality metal plugs for replacements. However, this project had a unique requirement: the Beogram needed to connect to a Beolab 5000. The Beolab 5000 has a compact compartment for its connectors, which creates limitations on plug size.

I chose gold-plated, all-metal Rean plugs that were short enough to fit the Beolab’s compartment. However, these plugs, like many others, have oversized cable exits. While this might accommodate the recent trend of using very thick cables, I find this excessive and prefer a cleaner look. To address this, I designed small 3D-printed inserts that would create a more streamlined appearance and provide a way to color-code the plugs.

Here’s a photo of the soldered plugs:

And here’s the final assembly:

The result is aesthetically pleasing. Here’s how the plugs look when connected to my Beolab 5000:

It’s a tight fit, but there’s still enough space to manage the cables. The last step for this Beogram restoration is to refinish the hood, which has some noticeable scratches.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4716/4715): Removing the Drive Mechanism
item.description:
Note: This post documents an outdated method. There’s a simpler way to remove the drive that doesn’t involve lifting the Pre-Amplifier board or disconnecting the solenoid linkage. See my later post for the updated procedure.

Following advice from ‘chartz’ and ‘sonavor’ on Beoworld.org (link to thread), I began replacing the belts in my Beocord 5000 (4716), which had become loose and stretched over time.

The first step is removing the drive mechanism. This involves lifting the left-side board to access the solenoid linkage. As ‘chartz’ recommended, I secured the operating panel to the enclosure’s bottom using three screws in reverse orientation. This clever trick prevents damaging the wires while working with the exposed components. Here’s a picture:

Next, I flipped up the left-side board. This board is secured by two screws: one in the back right corner and another beneath the enclosure next to the red DIN socket. With the screws removed, I carefully shifted the board to the right, disengaging it from the two brackets.

Conveniently, there are two upward-facing slots on the brackets where the board can be secured in an upright position. I recommend covering the plexiglass cover with a cloth to prevent scratches, a precaution I hadn’t taken in the following picture as I was still learning:

With that done, it was time to extract the drive.

First, I removed the solenoid linkage:

This required removing the retaining ring from its pivot shaft. I used a retaining ring tool, but it was tricky as the ring sits flush. By gently prying the ring open with the tool and wedging a small screwdriver between the ring and the linkage, I was able to raise the ring enough to get a better grip and remove it.

With the ring removed, the linkage could be rotated 90 degrees and taken out:

The next step was to disconnect the head plug, ensuring the deck was unplugged to avoid magnetizing the heads. This precaution was advised on a barely visible warning label inside the operating panel - a classic example of how not to design warnings.

Following that, I desoldered the solenoid connections:

The drive is secured at the front by two screws that go up through the enclosure’s bottom into the solenoid bracket. Here’s a view from under the enclosure:

I loosened these screws to allow the drive to slide forward.

Unlike the front, the drive’s rear isn’t secured with a screw. Instead, a bracket on the drive slots into the enclosure. By sliding the drive forward, it can be lifted out.

The final step involved disconnecting the large wire connector at the back of the drive:

This connector was quite firmly seated, and I had to carefully pry it loose with a small screwdriver before pulling it downwards. I realized then that removing the plexiglass cover would have made this easier. Finally, it came loose, and the drive was free.

Here’s a picture of the removed drive:

And the enclosure without it:

That concludes today’s work. Next time, I’ll begin disassembling the drive mechanism to access the belts.

item.title: Is Metro Ethernet Available?
item.description:
When your company needs more bandwidth, you might wonder about your options. Metro Ethernet is a popular choice, often providing more bandwidth for less money than traditional telecommunications services. But is it available in your area?

You can easily check availability using an Ethernet service finder to view a map of “lit” buildings nearby. A lit building has active fiber optic service, meaning the fiber optic cables are installed and operational with active laser light. In contrast, dark fiber refers to installed but inactive fiber optic cabling.

Lit buildings offer quick and easy access to fiber optic service. The infrastructure, like digging trenches and installing fiber cables, is already in place. Connecting you to the vast bandwidth available through fiber is a relatively simple process.

If your business is located in or can relocate to a lit building, you’re almost guaranteed access to Metro Ethernet at a competitive price. Sharing a high-bandwidth connection with other tenants presents an opportunity for even lower costs and high-volume usage. But what if your building isn’t currently serviced by fiber optics? Can you still get Metro Ethernet?

There’s a good chance you can. If a neighboring building has fiber, extending that service to your location is usually straightforward. Most of the heavy lifting, like laying fiber from the carrier’s Point of Presence (POP) to the building’s telecom room, is already done. Extending the fiber next door is a relatively minor task. In fact, you might even get this service for little to no cost if you commit to a reasonable bandwidth level.

What happens if there’s no fiber optic infrastructure in your vicinity? That scenario is trickier, depending on your location and bandwidth requirements. You might be surprised to learn that Ethernet operates on both twisted pair copper telephone cables and fiber. Not every business needs Gbps data speeds. Popular Metro Ethernet services offering 3 Mbps and 10 Mbps are easily delivered through existing copper cable infrastructure. This means you can be miles away from the nearest POP and still have access to Ethernet over Copper. While speeds up to 45 Mbps are possible, they necessitate a closer carrier POP for those higher bandwidths.

Is Metro Ethernet available in remote areas? It’s unlikely, as the “Metro” designation suggests. However, you might have options like EoDS1 (Ethernet over DS1), which utilizes T1 lines to provide Ethernet service. Ordering a single or multiple bonded T1 lines, depending on your bandwidth needs, is also a possibility regardless of your location.

To determine if Metro Ethernet is an option for your business, enter your business address (residential addresses are not applicable) into the Shop For Ethernet WAN Search box. The resulting map reveals the proximity of lit buildings to your location. Telarus consultants can then provide you with availability and pricing for Ethernet and other telecom services. You might find your location qualifies for a wider array of services and lower prices than you anticipated.

item.title: Business Telephone Systems Hosted VoIP Advantages
item.description:
Businesses of all sizes have various choices for their telephone systems. Small businesses can buy systems from local stores, while medium-sized businesses often work with contractors for key telephone systems or small PBXs. Larger companies may have internal teams that handle complex telephone systems. Nowadays, hosted VoIP is a cost-effective option for companies of all sizes.

How can one solution meet the needs of different-sized businesses affordably? It’s not a one-size-fits-all solution but a scalable technology adaptable to different demands—hosted VoIP, also known as hosted PBX or cloud telephone systems.

The cloud metaphor illustrates its nature. It involves using a large data center designed for business telephony for multiple clients. Its cloud service characteristics include significant scalable capacity and virtualization, ensuring client isolation. Billing follows a pay-as-you-go cloud model. The service provider invests in infrastructure, operation, and maintenance, while clients pay monthly per user.

Hosted VoIP usually offers telephone services comparable to advanced PBX systems. It includes call switching, in-house calls, local calls, and domestic long distance for a single price. International calls are billed separately, like traditional calling plans.

One benefit of hosted solutions is connecting multiple business locations. This setup helps avoid toll charges for interoffice calls. However, it involves network convergence and running SIP trunks between PBX systems. By bypassing traditional telephone companies, you become your own provider within your company locations.

Hosted VoIP providers manage a virtual PBX cloud. Each location connects to this cloud through your network. The cloud acts as a central hub, regardless of the handset’s physical location. These network devices can connect for conference calls.

Hosted VoIP now allows sharing external lines across locations. Internal calls stay within the network (“on-net”), while external calls require PSTN (Public Switched Telephone Network). Traditionally, each location had a PBX with dedicated outside lines, resulting in potential line availability issues. With a hosted solution, PSTN trunks reside in the cloud, accessible from any location, optimizing usage. Not all providers offer this, so inquire about this cost-saving feature if needed.

We’ve established that hosted VoIP offers advantages like scalability, pay-as-you-go pricing, no upfront investment, and no maintenance. It also connects multiple locations with advanced PBX features. Many providers integrate mobile phones for easy access. Some even include new desk phones in their service plans.

Could hosted VoIP be your next phone system? Explore pricing and features for different business telephone systems with hosted VoIP and choose what suits your company’s size.

item.title: Managed Hosting PBX Gets You Out Of The Telephone Business
item.description:
A lot of businesses find themselves managing their own phone systems simply because they need phones to operate, even though it’s not their core business. This has become the norm, but it doesn’t have to be this way anymore.

Companies previously invested in extensive phone systems because the productivity gains from each employee having a direct line outweighed the costs. In the past, a single phone line sufficed, but with the information age, constant communication became essential, driving the need for dedicated telecom departments.

These departments manage the PBX system, essentially a smaller version of a phone company’s central office. It connects internal calls and manages external lines. This setup requires constant upkeep, including replacing faulty phones, rewiring, and managing employee changes, all adding to the cost of doing business.

The financial burden includes managing these daily changes and the capital expense of the equipment. PBX systems are costly, and upgrades can necessitate loans for significant replacements. However, there’s a more efficient alternative: hosted PBX.

Hosted PBX shifts the responsibility of managing the system to a third-party provider. This eliminates the need for on-site equipment and frees up your resources. With this setup, employees can enjoy the same, if not better, phone functionality, often with “smart” phones integrated with the computer network.

This is possible due to the widespread use of company computer networks. Phones now use the existing broadband network to transmit data packets, connecting to a service provider who manages everything remotely. This makes them more efficient and cost-effective. It’s essentially a return to “telephone as a service,” or in today’s terms, “voice as a service.”

If your company is stuck managing its phone system, it’s worth exploring managed PBX hosting solutions. You might find a better and more cost-effective option for your business needs.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of the Main PCB and Installation of a Biasing Trimmer for TR3
item.description:
After getting the Beogram 4002 (5513) operational again, I focused on fully restoring the main PCB. This involved installing a trimmer to correctly calibrate TR3, the transistor responsible for amplifying the signal from the record detection sensor. The board’s condition upon arrival is shown below:

The RPM relay and trimmers had already been replaced by the owner. I finished the restoration by replacing all electrolytic capacitors

and adding a trimmer to enable bias adjustment at the base of TR3. To make adjustments with the board powered on, the trimmer was temporarily placed on the back, as pictured here:

After adjusting the collector DC voltage to 4.0V, I fixed the trimmer to the component side:

The original design used a fixed resistor, often causing insufficient amplification due to inconsistencies in the TR3 transistor’s current gain. Adequate amplification is crucial to avoid needle damage if the turntable is accidentally started without a record in place.

Next, I improved the installation of the replacement reservoir capacitor assembly, which had been installed previously:

Moving on to installing an LED in the sensor arm…

item.title: 3x3 Mbps Ethernet Doubles Your Bandwidth
item.description:
In today’s world, who couldn’t benefit from additional internet speed? Websites, software, and files continue to grow larger, but unfortunately, technology budgets haven’t kept pace. Imagine doubling your internet speed without increasing your current expenses – an appealing proposition, wouldn’t you agree?

It might sound illogical to suggest that doubling your internet speed wouldn’t cost more, especially since internet providers aren’t known for giving things away for free. The secret lies in adopting newer, more cost-effective technology instead of simply replacing your existing service with an identical one from another provider.

One way to double your internet speed with your current or a new provider, while retaining your T1 line service, is to order a second T1 line and “bond” it with your existing line. Bonding combines two lines to function as a single, faster line. A single T1 line provides 1.5 Mbps, so bonding two lines results in a speed of 3 Mbps. 

However, there are a couple of limitations. First, both T1 lines must be from the same provider, either your current one or a new one for both lines. Second, your monthly cost will double since you’re now paying for two lines. While you might find a different vendor offering lower prices for the same service, this alone likely won’t get you 3 Mbps for the price of 1.5 Mbps.

Instead of simply doubling down on T1 lines, consider switching to Ethernet over Copper. Both are dependable business-grade internet services with dedicated bandwidth. They can also be managed services, where the provider handles all the necessary equipment at your location to connect to their lines and your network. 

Another similarity between bonded T1 lines and Ethernet over Copper is that they both utilize the existing copper telephone wires already installed in your building. Although the signal types differ between T1 and Ethernet lines, they function the same way from a user’s perspective. 

The key difference lies in the cost. Ethernet over Copper, being a newer technology, utilizes the bandwidth capacity of copper lines more effectively. As a result, its pricing is very competitive, currently about half the cost of two bonded T1 lines. This means you could obtain a 3 Mbps Ethernet over Copper service for the same price as a 1.5 Mbps T1 service. 

A few other distinctions exist as well. T1 lines can only be upgraded in increments of 1.5 Mbps per bonded line. Ethernet, on the other hand, offers more flexibility, with bandwidth options ranging from 1 Mbps up to 10 Gbps, though higher speeds necessitate fiber optic cables. However, unlike T1, Ethernet over Copper has limited availability, primarily found in larger cities and suburbs rather than rural areas.

Interested in doubling your internet speed without increasing your costs? Check pricing and availability for 3 x 3 Mbps Ethernet over Copper or other Ethernet bandwidth services to discover potential savings in your area.

item.title: IT Departments are Wearin' the Green
item.description:
Maintaining IT budgets requires more than just good fortune these days. Many companies are discovering that environmentally friendly practices can save them money. These eco-conscious choices benefit both the planet and their bottom line.

One of the first areas to examine is electricity consumption. Power usage can be deceptive because it often occurs in small, unnoticeable increments. Every desktop computer, even when idle, contributes to the overall energy use, measured in watt-hours and kilowatt-hours. While electricity costs are easily offset by profits generated from productive work, the issue arises during idle time. Even when computers are unused, they still consume power, leading to unnecessary expenses.

Many companies have adopted a policy of shutting down computers and monitors overnight and during extended periods of inactivity. This practice has been proven to generate significant savings without significantly impacting equipment lifespan. In reality, most computers become obsolete before they wear out from use. When disposing of old electronics, it’s crucial to recycle responsibly, as circuit boards and CRTs contain hazardous materials. Proper recycling prevents these toxins from polluting the environment.

Turning off equipment when not in use, ideally with a mechanical switch that cuts off standby power, offers two advantages. First, it directly reduces the device’s power consumption. Second, it minimizes heat generation. No electronic device is perfectly efficient; some energy is always lost as heat. While essential for operation, this heat can become excessive, especially in server rooms.

Server rooms, with their concentrated computing power, often require substantial cooling. As equipment density increases, so does the need for air conditioning, creating a cycle of escalating energy consumption. To address this, designers are focusing on more efficient power supplies and even exploring DC power distribution.

However, maintaining an on-site server room might not always be the most practical solution. Colocation facilities offer a compelling alternative by distributing power and environmental control costs among multiple users. Additionally, colocation often provides access to more competitive bandwidth pricing.

For businesses looking to further minimize their reliance on grid power, generating their own electricity is an option. Office buildings and factories often have large, unused roof areas suitable for solar panel installation. By feeding into the grid, these solar arrays can significantly reduce daytime power consumption, especially during peak pricing hours. Google, among other companies, has already embraced solar power to supplement its energy needs.

If you’re considering upgrading to more energy-efficient computing equipment, consider consulting a network of value-added resellers. These experts can help you find the best deals on servers and network devices that can contribute to both environmental and financial savings.

item.title: Lit Buildings Have Near Infinite Bandwidth
item.description:
By: John Shepler

When choosing a business location, consider “lit buildings” for their exceptional connectivity. These buildings are already equipped with fiber optic internet infrastructure, offering a solution to bandwidth concerns.

What Does “Lit Building” Mean?

“Lit building” signifies a building pre-wired for fiber optic internet and potentially point-to-point bandwidth services. The term “lit” references the laser beams used to transmit digital signals at high speeds through fiber optic cables.

Advantages of Fiber Lit Buildings

In today’s business landscape, seamless electronic communication is essential, from small enterprises to large corporations. If your operations depend on computers, connectivity is crucial. Even the smallest businesses require internet access for credit card processing, online orders, email communication, and website management. Operating offline can hinder business growth.

However, securing reliable internet access can be challenging when moving into a new facility. Standalone buildings or being the first tenant often means bearing the cost and effort of installing internet service, including cabling, termination equipment setup, and provider coordination.

Lit buildings eliminate these challenges because the costly and time-consuming infrastructure is already in place. Simply contract with the building’s fiber optic provider, connect your router to their termination point, and your business is online.

Services Offered in Lit Buildings

Fiber optic connections surpass traditional landlines and cable internet by offering practically limitless bandwidth. While technical limitations exist, advancements in modulation and multiplexing techniques continually increase the bandwidth capacity of a single fiber strand, with speeds of 10 Gbps readily available and 100 Gbps becoming increasingly common. For larger businesses requiring even higher bandwidth, fiber optic cables can combine hundreds of individual strands.

The services available in lit buildings are comprehensive. Ethernet over Fiber, directly compatible with most Local Area Networks (LANs), is a popular choice offering scalable bandwidth from 10 Mbps to 10 Gbps and beyond. Many providers grant users portal access for on-demand bandwidth adjustments. Traditional Synchronous Optical Networking (SONET) services like OC3 to OC48 might also be available and can be demultiplexed to provide traditional T1 line or Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) PRI phone service. Additionally, Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) trunking for Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) and dedicated cloud connections are typically standard offerings.

Why Not Opt for Fiber?

Fiber optic internet provides a transparent and future-proof bandwidth solution that effortlessly scales with business growth. item.title: Are Your T1 Lines Saturated?
item.description:
By: John Shepler

The perfect network connection is invisible. Whether it uses copper wires, coaxial cable, fiber optics, or wireless technology, if it impacts your network traffic, it’s not truly transparent. The more noticeable these limitations become, the more they hinder productivity, demanding your attention.

Artificial Limitations

Shared broadband services like Cable, DSL, 4G Cellular, or satellite internet, despite promising “best effort,” are inherently limited by technology and company policies. Each type has a maximum capacity, typically accessible round-the-clock, except for rare outages. However, users only get a fraction of this capacity.

Firstly, bandwidth is capped. You’re purchasing a maximum speed, not a guaranteed one. Providers control this with rate limits. Your line might support 1000 Mbps, but you’re restricted to 10, 30, or 100 Mbps, regardless of other users.

Secondly, usage limits are imposed, especially on wireless and satellite connections where bandwidth is costly. Limits like 5 or 10 GB per month severely restrict usage, and even 20 or 50 GB might be insufficient for regular business operations. Exceeding this limit can result in extra charges, disconnections, or slower speeds for the remainder of the billing cycle.

Actual Limitations

Private and dedicated internet connections usually avoid artificial limitations. These premium services ensure you’re the sole user, eliminating the need for usage policies.

However, technical limitations persist. Every technology has inherent constraints. “Unlimited” bandwidth is a myth, even on local networks. The goal is to have sufficient bandwidth to avoid reaching capacity.

T1 Line Saturation

T1 lines, offering dedicated connections between two points or to the internet, have been the business standard for decades. As the sole user, there are no usage restrictions, and the line constantly allows data transfer. You utilize and pay a fixed price for a portion or all available capacity.

T1 lines offer 1.5 Mbps bandwidth, more precisely 1.544 Mbps. However, 8 Kbps is reserved for line synchronization, leaving 1.536 Mbps for actual data – equivalent to 16.59 GB daily or nearly 500 GB monthly.

Line Saturation Problems

Your T1 line reveals its limitations when transferring large files quickly or accommodating multiple users simultaneously. With a maximum capacity of roughly 17 GB daily, transferring even 1 GB per hour becomes challenging.

Attempting to exceed this limit slows down everyone’s traffic significantly. This bottleneck hinders productivity, especially when access to information is crucial for continuing work.

The situation worsens with cloud-based phone systems (VoIP). Voice data gets stuck in the bottleneck alongside other data, causing call quality issues like garbled speech, delays, and even dropped calls.

Solutions

For occasional saturation, prioritizing traffic can be beneficial. Real-time services like calls and video conferences get top priority, followed by business applications, and finally, background tasks like backups.

Ultimately, upgrading to higher bandwidth becomes necessary. Fortunately, costs have decreased significantly. Doubling your bandwidth with a second T1 line is an option. These lines can be “bonded” to act as a single, faster connection.

Ethernet over Copper, using existing copper lines, offers speeds of 10 Mbps and beyond. For these speeds, Ethernet over Fiber becomes cost-effective, scaling from 10 to 100, 1000, and even 10,000 Mbps. These services allow you to start with a lower speed and pay less until full capacity is needed.

If your T1 lines or other connections are struggling, explore pricing and availability of higher bandwidth services for your business location.

item.title: What Is Toll Free?
item.description:
The term “toll free number” is widely recognized, with most people having used one. But what exactly does it mean and how do businesses acquire them?

Unlike standard phone numbers automatically assigned with landline, VoIP, or cellular services, toll free numbers require a separate process. In the US and Canada, phone numbers follow the North American Numbering Plan (NANP) format: 1-NPA-NXX-XXXX.

In this format, “1” represents the country code, NPA stands for Numbering Plan Area (area code), and the remaining digits are unique to your line. The area code often indicates a geographical location, although VoIP providers can manipulate this.

Toll free numbers utilize specific area codes called toll free prefixes. While the term “toll free” implies free calls, it actually means the calling party doesn’t incur charges for the call. The owner of the toll free number is responsible for the cost of incoming calls.

To obtain a toll free number, businesses can order them from specialized companies. There are typically two payment options: a monthly fee plus per-minute charges for incoming calls, or a fixed monthly fee regardless of call volume.

Easily recognizable by their prefixes (800, 888, 877, 866, 855), toll free numbers are not tied to specific phone lines. Instead, you assign a “ring-to” number, directing incoming calls to any phone line you choose.

The popularity of toll free numbers has led to the introduction of multiple prefixes beyond the original 800, all functioning identically.

item.title: Cheaper Connections To The Cloud
item.description:
Businesses are often quick to celebrate the cost savings of cloud services compared to maintaining their own data centers. However, there’s a hidden cost that often catches them off guard: cloud connectivity.

The current cost of bandwidth depends on a company’s blend of LAN, MAN, and WAN traffic. Businesses with data centers located in the same building as their employees usually find most of their application traffic stays on the LAN. While a dedicated broadband internet connection is necessary for external communication, a moderate line speed can accommodate a large number of users if their usage is limited to email and web browsing.

E-commerce, however, is a different story. If customer and external user traffic dominate, a high-bandwidth connection is crucial for public-facing servers. In such cases, WAN traffic may even exceed LAN traffic.

Similarly, offsite but local data centers, even those primarily used for backup, recovery, or data mirroring, require high-bandwidth connections. This scenario often results in the majority of bandwidth being used by MAN rather than LAN or WAN.

The transition to the cloud significantly alters this dynamic. With public servers becoming rented services, bandwidth costs are absorbed into the service fee, potentially eliminating the need for a MAN connection altogether for cloud storage users. What becomes essential, however, is a significantly larger bandwidth pipe between the company’s premises and the cloud service provider.

Companies accustomed to in-house operations might be surprised by the increased cost of private line services to the cloud, potentially offsetting their anticipated savings. Conversely, companies currently burdened by high internet bandwidth costs may find relief in the cloud provider’s inclusive bandwidth to the internet. Creating a simple chart comparing LAN, MAN, and WAN bandwidth needs for both current and cloud-based setups is a worthwhile exercise.

Regardless of the resulting bandwidth mix, maximizing value for money is key. Fortunately, there are now more options than ever before, driven by competition and technological advancements.

One such advancement is Ethernet over Copper (EoC). EoC directly rivals traditional and high-bandwidth T1 lines, and in some cases, even fiber optic services.

Utilizing existing copper telephone wiring, EoC employs a more efficient modulation scheme than T1, achieving higher bandwidths. Unlike T1, EoC is distance-sensitive, requiring proximity to a telco office, making it suitable for urban and suburban areas but less so for rural locations.

EoC bandwidth options typically range from 2 to 20 Mbps, with some metropolitan areas offering services equivalent to 45 Mbps DS3. There are even providers offering 100 Mbps bandwidth over copper.

The pricing for EoC services is particularly attractive. 2-3 Mbps Ethernet service can often be acquired for the price of a T1 line, and discounts of 50% or more compared to traditional telecom services for higher bandwidth EoC are not uncommon.

Whether planning a move to the cloud or seeking to reduce current line service costs, exploring pricing and availability of EoC and other bandwidth services could reveal pleasant surprises.

item.title: I, Router

item.title: EV-DO Expands In The Face of WiMAX
item.description:
The arrival of 4G technology, specifically Sprint’s nationwide WiMAX network, raises questions about the future of 3G. While WiMAX boasts speeds up to 70 Mbps, suggesting a potential shift, the reality is more nuanced.

Sprint’s commitment to a national WiMAX network, with its impressive 31-mile range and 70 Mbps bandwidth, signals a potential shift in mobile technology. Realistically, users can expect speeds around 2-4 Mbps, especially when mobile. This rivals the current leading 3G service, EV-DO.

Developed by Qualcomm, EV-DO, short for “Evolution - Data Optimized,” is a standard for CDMA cellular transmission. It provides internet access and video on demand alongside traditional voice services. Major carriers like Verizon (BroadbandAccess and VCAST) and Sprint (Amp’d Mobile) have embraced EV-DO.

EV-DO, with download speeds of 2.4 Mbps and upload speeds of 153 Kbps, is comparable to DSL, cable, and satellite internet. Users typically experience 400-700 Kbps download speeds, sufficient for multimedia messaging, email, web browsing, and video/audio downloads.

EV-DO evolved from 1xRTT, offering speeds of 60-80 Kbps. While faster than dial-up, it struggles with bandwidth-heavy applications. This evolution is crucial as 1xRTT remains prevalent on CDMA networks, with EV-DO still being deployed beyond major cities and airports.

EV-DO Rev A, a backward-compatible upgrade, boosts peak download speeds to 3.1 Mbps and upload speeds to 1.8 Mbps. It also introduces Quality of Service (QoS) support, reducing latency for applications like push-to-talk, instant messaging, and potentially VoIP, although carriers remain cautious due to existing voice services.

As Sprint and Verizon upgrade to EV-DO Rev A, the next iteration, Rev B, is on the horizon. Launching next year, Rev B enhances performance to 4.9 Mbps per channel, with up to 15 channels working concurrently for a theoretical 73.5 Mbps download and 27 Mbps upload speed. Importantly, it maintains backward compatibility with previous versions.

This similarity between Rev B’s 73.5 Mbps and WiMAX’s 70 Mbps begs the question: is 3G evolving into 4G? In a sense, yes. Verizon, lacking independent WiMAX licenses, benefits significantly from this evolution. Ultimately, this bandwidth expansion paves the way for wireless applications previously restricted by limited airlink channels.

item.title: Internet SDN Mimics MPLS At Much Lower Cost
item.description:
By: John Shepler

Traditionally, businesses have faced a trade-off between expensive, high-performance WAN bandwidth and affordable, but unreliable, low-performance options. While cable or DSL internet offers cost savings, their inconsistent performance can be problematic. Conversely, dedicated private lines or MPLS networks deliver reliability and performance at a premium cost. If only there were a solution to make the internet perform like an MPLS network at a fraction of the cost. Thanks to SDN, there is.

What SDN is All About

SDN, which stands for Software Defined Network, represents the forefront of telecommunications connectivity. You might also come across terms like Hybrid SDN or SDN-WAN, which highlight its ability to combine different network types. Let’s explore what these acronyms signify and how they can benefit you.

SDN distinguishes itself from conventional hardware-based networks, like those used for telephone systems and the internet backbone, by using software to control network behavior. Traditional IP networks rely on routers and switches to determine data paths, while MPLS networks utilize specialized label switches to create a fixed network structure.

In contrast, SDN shifts network intelligence from inflexible hardware to software. This software program dynamically manages the hardware components, determining how they route traffic in real-time. SDN-WAN specifically refers to a Wide Area Network managed by SDN principles. It can integrate internet connections, private lines, and MPLS networks into a single, virtual WAN.

What’s Holding Back The Internet?

The internet’s allure as a low-cost connectivity solution has been hard to resist, but it’s crucial to remember that it was never designed to replace dedicated circuit-switched networks. The internet’s strength lies in its ability to reliably deliver data packets, regardless of network hiccups. TCP/IP ensures data integrity but doesn’t guarantee delivery speed.

As a result, internet users often experience performance fluctuations that, while merely inconvenient for casual browsing, can severely impact businesses running cloud-based applications. Voice and video communication, in particular, suffer from network neutrality, which treats all data equally. This lack of prioritization means VoIP packets compete with large file transfers, leading to choppy conversations and dropped calls.

Making The Internet Great For Business

A closer examination reveals that most internet performance bottlenecks occur in “the last mile” connections, not the core network. Compromises made to keep connection costs down are often the culprit. For example, DSL and Cable, the most affordable broadband options, utilize shared bandwidth with varying upload and download speeds. This means users have little control over bandwidth availability, latency, packet loss, or overall reliability.

Dedicated Internet Access (DIA) offers a step up in reliability. Options like T1 lines, DS3 bandwidth, OCx SONET, Ethernet over Copper, and Fiber Optic Carrier Ethernet provide a more robust connection. However, this stability comes at a cost, often ranging from two to ten times that of basic broadband.

Where Do Private Lines and MPLS Fit In?

Building a private internet network using dedicated private lines offers the pinnacle of performance, with high bandwidth, low latency, minimal jitter and packet loss, and maximum availability. However, this approach becomes prohibitively expensive as distance and the number of locations increase. MPLS networks provide a cost-effective alternative by creating a private network between designated locations, offering better performance than the public internet at a lower cost than dedicated private lines.

Businesses often choose MPLS for communication between headquarters, branch offices, and data centers where performance is critical.

How SDN Mimics MPLS at Lower Cost

The performance of Cable Broadband solutions has drastically improved in recent years, with speeds of 100 Mbps or even 1 Gbps now available at affordable prices. However, the inherent variability of Cable, DSL, 4G Wireless, and the internet itself remains a concern.

SDN controllers address this issue by actively managing available connectivity resources. By utilizing multiple connection types, such as Cable broadband, DSL, 4G, Dedicated Internet access, private lines, and even satellite, SDN can dynamically route traffic based on real-time network conditions. It can even distribute traffic across multiple paths if a single optimal route isn’t available.

This approach allows SDN to prioritize critical applications like VoIP and video conferencing by routing them through higher-performance connections. Essentially, SDN creates classes of service within your network, a feature absent in the public internet. This results in lower costs compared to an all-private network solution. Additionally, you gain the flexibility to connect to any location globally, including customers and suppliers, through the internet’s existing infrastructure.

If you suspect you’re overpaying for your wide area network, now is the perfect time to explore readily available, cost-effective SDN-based bandwidth solutions that align with your specific requirements.

Many businesses, from car dealerships to restaurants, benefit from having multiple locations. However, managing these locations as a unified company requires connecting them effectively. Point-to-point lines and MPLS networks offer solutions for this need.

Consider a car dealership expanding by acquiring another dealership. While this offers strategic advantages, consolidating operations like accounting, marketing, and IT can lead to cost savings. Centralizing these functions requires reliable and efficient connectivity between locations.

Point-to-point T1 lines are versatile, used by radio stations for program transmission and businesses for secure data exchange. item.title: Ethernet Services over Copper
item.description:
Connecting networks logically often involves Ethernet, a technology that has recently expanded its reach beyond local boundaries. Ethernet over Copper (EoC) connections are increasing in availability and often come at a lower cost compared to other options.

EoC enables standard Ethernet services to be delivered through existing copper telephone wiring. Unlike typical Cat 5E or Cat 6 wiring, EoC is compatible with older copper infrastructure not initially intended for Ethernet.

One of the main advantages of EoC is its utilization of existing copper infrastructure, particularly in Metropolitan Area Networks (MANs) and Wide Area Networks (WANs). This eliminates the need for expensive construction, as the copper wiring is already in place.

The technology works by leveraging unused twisted copper pairs, known as dry copper pairs. These pairs can be connected to EoC equipment, creating a high-speed Ethernet link from a location to the nearest telephone company office, where it can then be connected to other locations, typically via fiber optic lines.

Ethernet services, including EoC, come in standardized options. E-Line offers a direct point-to-point connection between two Local Area Networks (LANs), while E-LAN provides a multipoint service, similar to a meshed network, connecting three or more locations.

While EoC bandwidth can range from 1 Mbps to 20 Mbps or higher, it’s important to note that distance limitations exist. Lower speeds typically offer a wider range, while higher speeds restrict the distance to under a mile. This distance constraint is why EoC is often considered a metropolitan service.

Compared to services like T-Carrier or SONET, Ethernet offers greater scalability. Users can initially install a higher bandwidth capacity and only pay for the service they need, with the option to easily upgrade bandwidth as requirements change.

The cost-effectiveness of EoC, often providing double the bandwidth for a similar price compared to traditional T1 lines, makes it an attractive alternative. Furthermore, higher speeds are usually available at reasonable rates.

Considering these advantages, evaluating the potential benefits of increased bandwidth or improved pricing through EoC is worthwhile.

item.title: Is 5G Bandwidth Slicing The New Private Network?
item.description:
By: John Shepler

The internet is great for connecting, but it’s not always reliable. While it provides widespread access, low costs, and supports most applications, it can fall short when high performance and reliability are crucial. Issues like latency, packet loss, and congestion can hinder or even prevent interactive applications from working correctly. The solution? Private networks.

What is a Private Network?

The internet is a public network, accessible to almost anyone. All you need is an account with an internet service provider. Its strength lies in its global reach, built over decades. Everyone has equal footing – average users, corporations, and even connected devices. This principle is called network neutrality. The only things you can pay extra for are a faster connection to the internet backbone and more bandwidth.

While this equality is generally beneficial, it can lead to performance issues. When numerous users demand high bandwidth simultaneously, like during a live-streamed event or peak backup times, connections can suffer. This is especially problematic for applications requiring high speeds and low latency, such as video conferencing, gaming, remote surgery, financial trading, or controlling electric vehicles.

Private networks offer an alternative. Unlike your company’s LAN, which is isolated and typically offers sufficient bandwidth, private networks extend this concept across cities or even countries. Instead of building it yourself, you can partner with a network provider who offers dedicated point-to-point connections. While sharing infrastructure, you receive guaranteed bandwidth and network characteristics like low latency and minimal packet loss.

Types of Private Networks

While older technologies like T1 lines and SONET fiber were once prevalent, today, Ethernet over Fiber and MPLS networks are the most popular choices.

Ethernet over Fiber mirrors your LAN’s protocol, simplifying integration. It supports various configurations like point-to-point, point-to-multipoint, and mesh networks, offering speeds from 10 Mbps to 10 Gbps, with 100 Gbps becoming more common. Popular uses include connecting to cloud providers, linking business locations, and content delivery.

MPLS networks are specialized for wide-area connectivity, even internationally. Their unique protocol enhances security compared to standard IP networks. Though shared, these networks guarantee each customer their contracted bandwidth. MPLS networks with Ethernet access points offer extensive coverage at a lower cost than multiple private lines.

5G Slicing as the New Private Network

The rise of mobile applications requires wireless connectivity. While 4G LTE and now 5G offer significant improvements, they still rely on the internet with its inherent limitations. Bandwidth constraints and congestion can impact application performance, especially in busy areas. 5G slicing addresses this by reserving a portion of bandwidth for private use, for an additional fee.

Think of it as having a dedicated lane on a congested highway. 5G slicing offers a faster path to the internet or can create a private network or connection to a private fiber network. It’s essentially your LAN without wires, accessible over a wide area.

Some organizations are implementing private 5G networks on their premises for similar benefits. 5G slicing expands this concept, providing connectivity on the go, including for vehicles, smartphones, tablets, and various devices that struggle with traditional internet connections.

Issues with 5G Slicing

As 5G slicing is still in its early stages, availability might be limited. One concern is the potential for congestion if everyone seeks a private slice of the bandwidth. While 5G offers more bandwidth, especially on higher frequencies, it’s not unlimited. This scarcity drives the push for more 5G frequencies, including some currently allocated to the military.

Network neutrality also poses a challenge. Allowing paid prioritization through 5G slicing contradicts the principle of a neutral internet. While regulators currently accept it with some conditions, the increasing privatization of wireless spectrum might face opposition.

Would your business benefit from private networking? Explore the available bandwidth services for your locations today.

item.title: 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps, 1000 Mbps Internet Upgrades
item.description:
By: John Shepler

Are you frustrated with your company’s slow internet speeds? It’s understandable. Today’s applications are much more demanding than the simple websites and text-based emails common when T1 lines were first introduced. A 10 Mbps connection is now the bare minimum for most businesses, and it’s reasonable to need 100 Mbps or even 1000 Mbps. So, how can you upgrade effectively?

Upgrading Your Connection

One option is to gradually increase your bandwidth as your needs grow. Bonded T1 lines offer speeds from 3 to 12 Mbps in 1.5 Mbps increments. However, you must use a single provider for all lines, and equipment changes are needed with each upgrade. Still, this might be the best choice in rural areas with limited options.

Another option is Ethernet over Copper (EoC), which is available in most metropolitan areas. EoC provides higher bandwidth (3 to 20 Mbps) at lower costs compared to bonded T1. However, bandwidth decreases with distance from the service provider’s office.

The most promising option today is Ethernet over Fiber. While fiber optic service was once rare and expensive, newer Ethernet over Fiber solutions offer businesses several advantages.

Advantages of Ethernet over Fiber

Ethernet over Fiber (EoF) utilizes the same Ethernet protocol as your company’s LAN but with enhancements for telecom carrier use. Also called Carrier Ethernet or Metro Ethernet, this metropolitan service is easy to integrate with your network. A fiber or copper Ethernet connection links to your service provider, which you plug into your edge router.

Designed for scalability, EoF makes upgrades simple, usually without equipment changes. Unlike legacy services that required lengthy carrier-led equipment swaps, EoF upgrades happen quickly, often within hours or days. Some providers even allow on-demand adjustments through a computer interface.

Bandwidth Options

Ethernet over Fiber typically starts at 10 Mbps and can reach 10 Gbps or higher. Common speeds align with standard Ethernet LAN speeds: 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps, and 1000 Mbps. You can also get speeds between these benchmarks, starting at 10 Mbps and gradually increasing to 100 Mbps or more.

The crucial factor is the installed port speed, which dictates the connection speed to the provider’s equipment. A 100 Mbps Fast Ethernet connection is suitable for speeds up to 100 Mbps, while a Gigabit Ethernet port is recommended for higher speeds. For anything beyond 1 Gbps, install a 10 Gbps port from the outset to avoid future equipment changes.

Cost-Effectiveness

The popularity of Ethernet over Fiber has led many traditional and new carriers to offer it, creating a competitive market that benefits buyers. EoF pricing per Mbps is significantly lower than bonded T1, DS3 (T3), or SONET services. You can potentially cut your internet costs by 50% or more while maintaining high reliability, low latency, minimal jitter, and minimal packet loss.

If this sounds like the solution for your business internet needs, explore the pricing and availability of Ethernet over Fiber bandwidth options in your area.

item.title: A Kissing Hand For The Sandy Hook Elementary Students
item.description:
A children’s book about a raccoon hesitant to start school offers a heartwarming solution for children struggling with the idea of returning to the classroom.

The recent tragedy at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, has left many young students grappling with trauma and fear. The horrific event, where students and educators lost their lives, has created a sense of anxiety about returning to school for the spring semester. Finding a way to comfort these children and help them cope with their fears is a significant challenge.

Kim Piscatelli from East Hampton, Connecticut, believes she’s found a way to provide some comfort. Inspired by the children’s book “The Kissing Hand” by Audrey Penn, Kim initiated a project to provide each child in Newtown with a copy of the book and a pair of mittens or gloves adorned with a heart on the left palm. The book tells the story of Chester Raccoon, whose mother kisses his palm to reassure him whenever he feels lonely or misses home.

The project has garnered immense support, with knitting groups actively creating mittens with heart accents. The aim is to ensure that every child receives a pair of these comforting mittens along with the book as they return to school.

While the response has been positive, the need is extensive. Hundreds of students from Sandy Hook Elementary and surrounding areas have been impacted by the tragedy. To address this, individuals are encouraged to contribute by sending child-size mittens or gloves with heart embellishments to:

The Kissing Hand Mitten Project 93 East High Street East Hampton, Ct. 06424

Gloves are readily available, and heart shapes can be easily found in fabric stores. The goal is to gather and send as many mittens and gloves as possible to provide comfort and support to the children.

“Chester the Raccoon” plush dolls are also available for purchase online. These cuddly companions can offer additional comfort to the children.

Additionally, the book “The Kissing Hand” is temporarily available as a free download on iTunes, offering a digital version with text, illustrations, and narration. Physical copies are also readily available for purchase.

The hope is that this small gesture of a “kissing hand” will provide a sense of comfort and security, allowing the children to gradually return to a sense of normalcy in their lives. The project embodies a collective effort to support and uplift the community in the wake of unimaginable tragedy.

item.title: 100 Mbps Internet for Business
item.description:
For many mid-size businesses, DS3 internet with its 45 Mbps speed has been the standard. It’s widely available and offered a significant upgrade from older T1 lines. However, with the rise of video conferencing and cloud-based applications, even DS3 struggles to handle the demands of multiple users. It’s time to consider upgrading to 100 Mbps internet access.

The 100 Mbps service level is significant because it aligns with “Fast” Ethernet, a standard Ethernet LAN speed. Most network interface cards (NICs) in computers, routers, switches, and printers support 10/100 Mbps Ethernet speeds. Newer NICs even support Gigabit Ethernet (GigE) with 10/100/1000 Mbps ports.

The issue is that connecting to the internet at a slower speed than your 100 Mbps LAN will cause a bottleneck for internet traffic. While this might not be noticeable during low network activity, congestion becomes apparent with multiple users and heavy data usage. The connection to the internet, often the WAN or wide area network, becomes the chokepoint.

Fortunately, 100 Mbps business internet service is now more accessible and affordable than ever. Let’s explore the various technical approaches and their pros and cons.

OC-3, a traditional 100 Mbps telecom service, operates at around 155 Mbps. Offered by telecom companies nationwide, OC-3 is a fiber optic SONET service. It can transport various data types, including phone calls, private connections, and dedicated internet access. OC-3 is also used to deliver lower-speed services like DS3. While you might not associate DS3 with fiber optics due to its coaxial cable connections, it’s often delivered through add/drop multiplexers connected to SONET fiber cables.

OC-3 is a well-established and popular digital line service with an SLA (Service Level Agreement), ensuring reliability. Your bandwidth is both dedicated and symmetrical. Dedicated bandwidth means you don’t share the 155 Mbps with other users, ensuring consistent availability. Symmetrical bandwidth means you have 155 Mbps for both uploads and downloads.

Carrier Ethernet directly competes with OC-3 in bandwidth. Connecting to your LAN with Fast Ethernet at 100 Mbps is straightforward using a standard RJ-45 patch cable, eliminating the need for specialized fiber optic cables or interface cards required for OC-3. Like OC-3, 100 Mbps Fast Ethernet is symmetrical, dedicated, and comes with an SLA.

Fast Ethernet is available over both fiber optic and twisted-pair connections. However, Ethernet over Copper at this speed has distance limitations, making it more common in metropolitan areas. Slower speeds like 10 or 20 Mbps have a wider range and are more accessible.

Ethernet over Fiber, similar to OC-3, offers two key advantages. Firstly, the cost per Mbps is often lower than OC-3. Secondly, Carrier Ethernet services are scalable. While upgrading from OC-3 typically means moving to OC-12 at 622 Mbps, Carrier Ethernet offers more flexibility. With a Gigabit Ethernet port, you can easily upgrade to 200, 500, or even 1,000 Mbps as your needs grow.

Another increasingly available option is 100 Mbps Cable business broadband. This shared, asymmetrical service, similar to residential cable internet, typically lacks service level agreements. While it offers download speeds up to 100 Mbps, upload speeds are around 10 Mbps. This bandwidth is shared with other users, resulting in varying speeds, especially during peak hours. However, its affordability, often comparable to a T1 line, makes it suitable for businesses with limited budgets and basic internet needs.

If you’re considering new business internet service or upgrading from bonded T1 or DS3 to 100 Mbps or higher, now is the time to explore your options. Check 100 Mbps Internet pricing and availability for your business location. Complimentary consulting is available to help you navigate the choices.

item.title: What Makes a Great MAN
item.description:
Access to Metropolitan Area Networks (MANs), previously limited to large corporations, is now feasible for small and medium-sized businesses. If your company requires communication between multiple locations within a city, a metro network might be beneficial.

Metro Ethernet is the modern solution for data connections in major cities and surrounding areas. There are two main types: E-Line and E-LAN. E-Line provides a direct Ethernet connection between two points, such as a business and its data center, warehouse, factory, or branch office.

E-LAN, on the other hand, facilitates multi-point connections, resembling a LAN spread across a city, often called a Wide Area Network (WAN). This allows for connecting a main office to multiple branches, retail locations, warehouses, factories, or other sites within the metropolitan area. Both E-Line and E-LAN effectively unite local networks into a larger company network.

A high-quality MAN is characterized by speed, reliability, and affordability. While bandwidth is variable, Ethernet MANs typically offer standard Ethernet LAN speeds of 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps, and 1000 Mbps.

Fiber optic lines are commonly employed in MANs for their speed, capacity, and reliability. Gigabit Ethernet speeds require a fiber optic connection to your building. Business locations in major metropolitan areas, where metro networks are prevalent, often have existing fiber optic infrastructure or are near a carrier point of presence (POP). This is particularly common in large office buildings with multiple tenants and colocation facilities hosting server farms.

Carriers often extend fiber optic connections to buildings with sufficient bandwidth demand. In areas where this is impractical or financially unfeasible, Ethernet MAN connections can utilize Ethernet over Copper (EoC) technology. This system uses existing telephone wiring to provide Ethernet speeds between 1 and 100 Mbps, depending on the distance from the carrier.

A key advantage is the competitive landscape driving down the cost of MAN connections significantly lower than traditional telephone company offerings. item.title: Hosted Exchange Email Service Advantages
item.description:
POP3 email, while widely used by both businesses and individuals, has limitations that might make you reconsider your email service. While convenient, its client-server model, where emails are downloaded to your device, poses risks such as data loss and limited accessibility.

What exactly is POP3? It stands for Post Office Protocol, an internet standard for retrieving emails from a server to a client, like Microsoft Outlook or Mac Mail, installed on your computer. This setup allows offline access to downloaded emails but limits access from other devices and risks losing all your emails if your device fails.

While POP3 has its advantages, such as offline email access, it has some downsides. If your computer crashes, you risk losing all your emails. Additionally, managing emails across multiple devices becomes difficult, and you’re more vulnerable to spam and viruses.

While large companies use Microsoft Exchange on their own servers for enhanced security and features, smaller companies find it challenging to manage. Hosted Exchange offers a solution by providing the benefits of Microsoft Exchange without needing to manage your own server.

Hosted Exchange, managed by a hosting provider, offers several advantages. These include automatic backups, access from any device, easier email recovery, and secure communication with SSL encryption.

If you’re considering a more modern and robust email system, Hosted Exchange might be the right choice. It scales to your needs, eliminates the hassle of managing your own server, and can be more cost-effective.

item.title: Infrastructure as a Service Providers
item.description:
Cloud computing is widely understood to have three main levels: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), Platform as a Service (PaaS), and Software as a Service (SaaS). The most fundamental of these is IaaS, which forms the basis for the other two. IaaS essentially refers to providing basic hardware and operating system software over the internet.

Infrastructure is fairly self-explanatory: it’s the foundational hardware and software needed for computing. When considering cloud infrastructure, the comparison is often made with having your own data center. So why would a business choose to move to the cloud?

There are compelling business reasons to use IaaS. Traditional infrastructure is expensive to purchase and maintain, demanding constant upkeep and becoming obsolete quickly. Physical infrastructure is also sensitive, requiring controlled environments, security measures, and significant power resources.

Another consideration is determining how much infrastructure to acquire. You need enough to handle regular operations, but what about unforeseen spikes in demand? Products can suddenly become popular, or online content can go viral, leading to unexpected surges in traffic. Social media platforms are well-acquainted with this phenomenon.

Cloud service providers present a solution to the limitations of on-premise data centers, frequently with significant cost advantages. Their business model is based on scale. They build large data centers filled with virtualized and dedicated servers, storage systems, security tools, and diverse network connections. All of this is housed in highly secure facilities with redundant power systems.

This might sound like a colocation center, and there are similarities. However, a key difference is elasticity. Elasticity refers to the ability of resources to scale up or down as needed. With colocation services, you typically have a fixed contract, and while you can adjust it, changes take time.

Cloud services operate on a utility computing model, similar to electricity. You don’t request more power from the utility company; you simply use what you need. Only when you exceed your capacity do you need to adjust your service level.

IaaS is priced based on usage. Cloud providers possess vast resources, and their economies of scale allow them to serve numerous clients, each unaware of the others. Your services are isolated, ensuring that no other user can impact your resources or operations.

The benefit for businesses is clear: IaaS provides the necessary resources, when needed, at a cost that reflects actual consumption rather than idle capacity. This eliminates the need for large capital investments and reduces staffing requirements, as the provider manages operations and maintenance constantly.

To determine if your business could benefit from cloud services, it’s worthwhile to compare pricing and services from different cloud providers.

item.title: T1 Lines to Support Enterprise VoIP
item.description:
T1 lines are commonly known for their ability to combine multiple phone calls onto a single line using Time Division Multiplexing (TDM). However, they can also be used for Voice over IP (VoIP) communication between company locations or to connect with the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) through gateways.

Traditional T1 lines were designed to carry 24 simultaneous high-quality phone calls over a copper wire pair. Each call is digitized and placed into one of 24 eight-bit time slots, synchronized precisely using atomic clocks. Devices called channel banks handle the multiplexing and demultiplexing, essentially creating 24 distinct phone lines at each end. T1 PRI lines function similarly but dedicate one channel for signaling and data like Caller ID.

T1 and T1 PRI lines remain viable choices for businesses with traditional PBX phone systems. The interface remains consistent, and costs have significantly decreased. Most PBX and larger Key systems offer compatible interface boards.

VoIP differs from traditional circuit-switched telephony. Although voice is still converted from analog to digital, potentially using the same CODEC (Coder/Decoder), it’s handled differently. Instead of rigid time slots, digital voice samples are packaged into packets. These packets, adhering to the Internet Protocol (IP), coexist with data packets on the network. Transmission speed depends on network capacity.

For VoIP, the full 1.5 Mbps capacity of a T1 line is utilized as a Wide Area Network (WAN), referred to as “unchannelized.” Imagine it as a large data pipeline connecting two points. Both ends could be company locations, or one could connect to the internet.

A key difference between TDM-based T1 and VoIP is bandwidth management. In VoIP, your network, through routers or an IP PBX, prioritizes voice packets over less time-sensitive data to ensure call quality. Adequate bandwidth for peak voice traffic is crucial. As your needs grow, additional T1 lines can be combined to increase bandwidth.

Since both voice and data use the IP format, unchannelized T1 lines can carry both simultaneously. This enables “integrated T1 line service,” providing phone and internet over a single line. An IAD converts phone calls to VoIP, combines voice and data packets, then separates them at the destination, sending voice to the phone network and data to the internet.

Businesses using VoIP can leverage T1 lines for voice and data between offices. IP PBXs or IP Phones convert calls to data packets, eliminating the need for a separate IAD. However, a voice gateway might be necessary for calls outside the organization.

It’s worth noting that WAN connections are now available using Ethernet. By choosing Ethernet, Fast Ethernet, or Gigabit Ethernet WAN, businesses can establish efficient network connections regardless of distance.

item.title: Generalized MPLS Improves Optical Networks
item.description:
Multi-Protocol Label Switching (MPLS) is a technology that accelerates network speeds and supports various protocols, including IP, ATM, Frame Relay, and SONET. It achieves this by encapsulating these protocols within its own tunnels upon entering the network and restoring them to their original format upon exit. Within the MPLS network, routing occurs based on simplified tags inserted into packet headers.

Constructing this specialized network for transporting other network traffic offers the advantage of defining service classes. This ensures that real-time data, such as voice and video, receive the necessary bandwidth and low latency for optimal performance. The multi-protocol nature of this network is particularly appealing to carriers tasked with transporting diverse data types. Generalized Multi-Protocol Label Switching (GMPLS), a set of extensions, further enhances the versatility of this already adaptable network.

While MPLS focuses on controlling packet flow in packet-switched networks, GMPLS acknowledges the existence of other network types with elements not necessarily packet-oriented. For example, Time Division Multiplexing (TDM), the traditional digital telephony standard and foundation of Synchronous Optical Network (SONET), relies on time slots rather than packets. Although packets can be transmitted over TDM networks, large packets are divided into multiple time slots and reassembled later. This process negates the inherent advantages of predictable time slots in TDM, as they become irrelevant in the packet-switched world.

GMPLS reintroduces the significance of TDM. A time slot can function as a label, eliminating the need for additional labels since the network inherently understands the data carried within each time slot. Similarly, a wavelength or Lambda can serve as a label in a Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) network. Even an entire fiber can be treated as a GMPLS label to define a network path.

Assigning labels to all network elements involved in data packet routing decisions grants the GMPLS network a high degree of autonomy. It receives data from various protocols at the ingress point and adds its own labels. These labels can be MPLS “shim” type inserted into packet headers or “implicit” type associated with specific fibers, wavelengths, or TDM time slots. Label routing switches then route the GMPLS data over predetermined paths established at the ingress point. Upon reaching the network edge (egress point), all labeling information is removed, allowing the different data types to proceed in their native protocols.

Significantly, there is no mention of manual intervention for circuit provisioning or route setup. GMPLS networks inherently recognize available network resources and automatically establish and dismantle label-switched paths as required. The widespread deployment of GMPLS networks is anticipated to significantly simplify and expedite the labor-intensive task of service provisioning through automation.

item.title: Vanity Numbers for Small Businesses
item.description:
The significance of your business phone number cannot be overstated. It’s your lifeline to customers. If they can’t easily recall your number, they might dial a competitor’s instead. This is where vanity numbers come into play.

What exactly are vanity numbers? They are standard phone numbers designed for easy memorization.

There are two main categories of vanity numbers. The first type spells a word or phrase, similar to personalized license plates. Creativity knows no bounds here!

But how can you spell with numbers? The answer lies in the dial pad. Every modern phone features a 12-button dial pad, also known as a touchpad or touch-tone pad. These buttons replaced the rotary dial. Those familiar with rotary phones know that each finger hole had letters and numbers. For instance, the number 2 corresponded to A, B, and C. Early phone numbers even used letters to represent exchanges, like AD for Adams, for simpler memorization.

Similarly, modern dial pads retain letter-number assignments. Number 2 corresponds to A, B, and C, 3 to D, E, and F, and so on. Only the number 1 stands alone. The remaining buttons, * and #, serve special functions unrelated to phone numbers.

Now, compare remembering 1-877-327-4325 to 1-877-3-BRIDAL. For a bridal shop, the latter is more memorable and relevant. Other examples include 1-866-89-BIBLE, 1-866-6-BEEPER, and 1-866-684-DEAL— all real, available numbers. While these specific numbers might be taken, countless others await. Discover affordable toll-free options here.

The second type of vanity number relies on numerical patterns for easy recall. Consider 1-866-262-1500, memorable for its double zero ending. Or 1-800-301-1010 with its repeating pattern. These are also real, currently available numbers. Naturally, such unique patterns are limited and pricier.

Toll-free numbers, especially vanity numbers, are invaluable for small businesses. They incentivize customers to choose you over competitors. Local calls are cost-effective, but long distance charges can deter potential clients. item.title: Do You Need a Content Delivery Network?
item.description:
The way we deliver content online is evolving rapidly. While you could once manage a website with just a computer and a few phone lines, today’s high-definition video and nationwide audiences demand far more resources. This is where content delivery networks (CDNs) come in.

Think of a CDN as a specialized web hosting service. Just as you can host your website on your own server or outsource it, you can also choose between managing your content distribution or relying on a CDN. CDNs handle the technical aspects, like server upkeep, power, and high-speed internet connections, so you can focus on creating content.

Opting for a CDN offers similar advantages to using a hosting service: it’s often simpler, more cost-effective, and more scalable. CDNs have their own networks designed for storing and delivering content to many users across a large area. They guarantee sufficient bandwidth for your needs, whether it’s software, music, or high-definition video. Some CDNs even have partnerships with internet service providers (ISPs) to bypass the public internet entirely, resulting in faster content delivery.

CDNs use different methods to optimize their services. Some store multiple copies of your content on servers across the country, directing your download request to the closest available copy. Others distribute content across their network for efficient delivery. Load balancing among servers enhances reliability by automatically switching to a working server if one fails.

Speaking of bandwidth, if you’re finding your current capacity insufficient, it might be time to explore better WAN bandwidth options.

item.title: Ethernet Connects Businesses Throughout Latin America
item.description:
In recent years, numerous businesses have opted for Carrier Ethernet services for various connectivity needs, including Dedicated Internet Access (DIA), point-to-point private lines, last-mile access to MPLS networks, and meshed connections linking multiple business locations within the United States. This capability is now expanding globally. For instance, Level 3, a prominent international carrier, received recognition from the Metro Ethernet Forum (MEF) for its services in the Caribbean and Latin America.

While international voice and data services have been around for a long time, facilitated by extensive undersea fiber optic cables connecting continents, the recent shift lies in protocol changes and the emergence of new services for global companies and organizations.

Ethernet’s displacement of older protocols stems from the dominance of IP packets in electronic communication. Most Local Area Networks (LANs) are Ethernet-based, and the internet, the largest interconnected network, relies on routing IP packets. This begs the question: why not extend existing networks using the Ethernet protocol?

The primary obstacle to a faster transition to IP-based core networks is legacy infrastructure. The substantial investments in infrastructure over the past century, primarily built by telephone companies using Time Division Multiplexing (TDM) standards like T1, DS3, and SONET, won’t disappear overnight.

Fortunately, existing telecom equipment doesn’t need to be replaced to implement Ethernet services. Carrier Ethernet functions over IP and TDM networks. Ethernet over T1 (EoDS1) serves as an effective last-mile connection for MPLS networks or point-to-point private lines, leveraging the extensive reach of T1 infrastructure, particularly in rural areas. Ethernet over DS3 (EoDS3) offers higher bandwidth at 45 Mbps, while Ethernet over SONET starts at 155 Mbps and scales to at least 10 Gbps, with some connections reaching 40 Gbps and 100 Gbps.

The presence of the Metro Ethernet Forum (MEF), an industry standards group, has accelerated Carrier Ethernet adoption. The MEF establishes and maintains standards for manufacturers and Ethernet service providers, such as the E-NNI (Ethernet Network to Network Interface), which enables predictable and carrier-agnostic traffic exchange between networks. This allows carriers to expand their reach through peering arrangements via E-NNIs, accessing markets they don’t directly serve without laying fiber globally.

Level 3’s award-winning project involved providing Ethernet-based connectivity solutions for a major banking and financial services company throughout Brazil. An increasing number of large and medium-sized businesses are considering Ethernet services for interconnecting their locations worldwide. Smaller companies are also recognizing the cost benefits and seamless connectivity of Ethernet, making it a compelling choice when renewing contracts or setting up new installations.

If your organization, regardless of size, seeks improved connectivity at lower costs compared to traditional telecom services, explore the pricing and features of Carrier Ethernet services.
