item.title: Why PRI Over T1?
item.description:
PRI, or Primary Rate Interface, is a popular digital telephone service used by call centers, PBX systems, and internet providers. It’s part of the ISDN standards.

PRI is often referred to as T1 PRI in regions like the USA, Canada, and Japan because it utilizes a T1 carrier trunk. However, there’s also a service simply called T1, making PRI appear as a variation of T1.

Traditional T1, known as channelized T1, carries 24 digitized conversations simultaneously using 24 channels of 8 bits each. To manage call signaling, one bit from each channel is repurposed, leaving 7 bits for the conversation. This method is called robbed bit signaling.

PRI offers an alternative T1 format. It provides 23 channels for calls and reserves the 24th channel solely for signaling. This grants each voice channel the full 8 bits for communication. Referred to as out-of-band signaling, this separate data channel offers more advanced features compared to robbed bit signaling, such as Caller ID and faster call setup and teardown, which are crucial for call centers and ISPs. PRI channels offer flexibility by configuring for inbound, outbound, or two-way communication.

When deciding between channelized T1 and PRI, consider your needs and equipment. If features like caller information for CTI, billing, or Caller ID display are crucial, then PRI is preferable. If these features aren’t essential and having all 24 channels for calls is more important, or your PBX system lacks PRI support, then channelized T1 is a suitable option.

item.title: Is The End Of Cellular Phone Near?
item.description:
Cell phones are essential to modern life, but a recent development calls into question the future of cellular service. The release of the Apple iPad and its allowance of VoIP applications over 3G cellular networks, along with AT&T’s network adjustments for this capability, signal a potential shift in the telecommunications landscape.

Why is this significant? Cellular networks have historically blocked VoIP due to its potential to congest networks and cannibalize voice call revenue. Traditional cellular systems were designed for voice calls, with data services as a more recent addition. Carriers allocate limited bandwidth between voice and data, and the introduction of unlimited data plans opened the door for users to bypass voice plans entirely using VoIP services like Skype.

However, several factors are mitigating this concern. The rise of unlimited voice and data plans renders the distinction between voice and data usage less important for billing purposes. More importantly, the surge in bandwidth demand from data-intensive applications like video streaming is dwarfing voice call requirements. Carriers are rapidly upgrading infrastructure to accommodate this data explosion, shifting the focus from voice to data services.

As data usage continues to dominate, the traditional model of voice minutes may become obsolete. Future pricing models might involve pay-as-you-go for all services or flat fees for unlimited usage. Cellular carriers will evolve into wireless broadband providers, catering to mobile devices capable of both voice and data communication. While traditional cellular service may decline, wireless technology will continue to thrive in this new data-centric landscape.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Arm Lowering Mechanism, Replacement of Tracking Sensor Light Bulb with a LED Assembly, and a New Aluminum Pulley
item.description:
My Beogram 4000 arrived damaged from shipping, so I began by fixing it. The carriage, which moves along a rod with bearings, had detached.

I took out the rod and bearings to put them back into the carriage correctly. Then, I used a wrench to secure them. This allowed me to reinstall the carriage.

Next, I started my usual restoration process, beginning with the arm lowering mechanism. I took apart the solenoid, damper, connecting parts, and springs. I cleaned and lubricated everything before putting it back together.

The connection between the damper and tonearm frequently gets stuck, so I tackled that next. I took out the sensor arm and linkage, which was tough to remove. After cleaning and greasing the pin, I reassembled everything and realigned the arm.

The last step was replacing the tracking sensor’s light source. After removing the old bulb housing, I found that the aperture was out of place due to the shipping damage. I installed a 3D-printed LED assembly and a new machined aluminum pulley to complete the repair.

The next step is restoring the carriage movement contacts, which I’ll cover in my next post.

item.title: Fiber Optic Leased Lines for Business
item.description:
Traditional copper leased lines for business connectivity are becoming outdated in the face of increasing demand for bandwidth-intensive applications like big data, HD video, and cloud computing. Fiber optic lines are emerging as the preferred solution, offering lower prices and more choices.

](http://www.fibernetworkquotes.com/)

While large companies and bandwidth-heavy industries have used fiber optic leased lines for a long time, the technology is now becoming more accessible. Historically, most fiber bandwidth relied on SONET (Synchronous Optical NETworking), a standard originating from the telephone industry.

SONET picks up where copper-based T-carrier lines reach their limit. While T1 lines offer speeds up to 12 Mbps and T3 (DS3) lines provide 45 Mbps, SONET starts at 155 Mbps with OC-3 and scales up to much higher bandwidths.

SONET service levels increase in large increments, with OC-12 at 622 Mbps, OC-24 at 1.2 Gbps, OC-48 at 2.5 Gbps, OC-192 at 10 Gbps, and OC-768 at 40 Gbps. This large gap between levels may require businesses to purchase more bandwidth than needed.

As a TDM (Time Division Multiplexed) technology, SONET divides the signal into small, synchronized channels, reflecting its telephony heritage. This setup requires protocol conversion for compatibility with packet-switched Ethernet networks.

Despite needing protocol conversion, SONET is widely deployed and recognized for its reliability. Its ring topology, using two redundant fibers, ensures data flow even during network issues.

A newer alternative, Ethernet over Fiber (EoF), specifically Carrier Ethernet, offers advantages over SONET. Carrier Ethernet provides scalability, direct compatibility with existing networks, and cost savings.

Carrier Ethernet offers various service levels, including 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps, 1 Gbps, and 10 Gbps, with the flexibility to select almost any bandwidth. Upgrading bandwidth is also simpler and faster with Carrier Ethernet.

While relatively new, Carrier Ethernet is gaining popularity due to lower costs and scalability. This competition has driven down SONET prices, making fiber options more affordable.

Businesses looking for increased bandwidth, better pricing on existing fiber connections, or optimal solutions for new applications should explore the options available with SONET and Ethernet fiber optic leased lines.

item.title: ATM Networks: Little Cells Doing Big Things
item.description:
While the ATM acronym might make you think of cash machines, in the networking world, it stands for Asynchronous Transfer Mode. This core transmission protocol, unlike its namesake, isn’t something most consumers encounter directly.

ATM is a technology that falls into the same family as Ethernet, Frame Relay, and TDM. Although once considered a potential universal networking solution, it didn’t achieve that status. Nonetheless, a significant portion of telecom providers, around 80%, currently utilize ATM within their networks.

This might seem surprising given the buzz around Ethernet advancements like Fast, Gigabit, and 10 Gigabit Ethernet. ATM’s relevance stems from its design, intended to handle any digitized voice, video, or data protocol by packaging them into small, uniform 53-byte packets (cells) with 5 bytes for the header and 48 for data. Larger data streams are divided among multiple cells.

This uniform cell structure simplifies network operations, allowing for hardware-based packet handling which is more efficient. This efficiency makes it suitable for high-speed optical carrier networks like OC3 and OC12, where ATM finds its primary application, and even scales up to OC48 and beyond.

ATM networks utilize switches instead of routers because data travels over predetermined virtual circuits on virtual paths, ensuring all cells follow the same route from origin to destination, maintaining their order. This is crucial for voice and video transmission, minimizing jitter and ensuring smooth, synchronized delivery.

IP routing, conversely, can direct packets through different paths. While this adds robustness by enabling rerouting in case of network disruptions, it introduces variable packet arrival times, leading to delays and jitter. Such inconsistencies disrupt real-time data streams like voice or video, rendering out-of-sequence packets useless.

Despite its strengths, ATM is unlikely to dominate the networking landscape. Initially, it was projected to replace Ethernet as the latter’s speed limits were anticipated to become inadequate. However, Ethernet evolved with faster speeds and enhancements, solidifying its dominance in local area networks (LANs). Consequently, ATM found its niche in metropolitan and wide area networks (WANs), creating a division where LANs typically use Ethernet and WANs utilize ATM.

The push for a standardized IP environment is leading to end-to-end Ethernet deployments, simplifying network management. Whether WAN trunks will fully transition to a native IP format or simply carry IP over ATM remains to be seen. However, ATM might see renewed relevance as digitized voice and video traffic increases within networks.

Where available, this service is typically more affordable than DS3 on a per-Mbps basis.

Even if your business is located in a remote area without access to fiber optic cables, there are still voice and data connection solutions. item.title: Cheap Business Continuity Insurance
item.description:
What happens when your business can’t operate? It’s a disaster, leading to lost sales and potentially losing valuable customers. If customers go elsewhere during downtime, they may never return, putting your business at risk.

While numerous risks can disrupt your business, connectivity is one you can control. Most businesses, even traditional brick-and-mortar ones, rely heavily on electronic connections like phones and the internet to operate.

Losing these vital connections can be devastating. While a hotdog vendor might not be affected, businesses like stockbrokers or online retailers with on-site servers would be crippled. Point-of-sale system failures can bring businesses to a standstill.

This raises the question of using a “costly” T1 line versus a “budget-friendly” DSL or Cable Modem connection. While they might offer similar advertised bandwidth (e.g., 1.5 Mbps), DSL’s lower cost of $50-$150 per month can be tempting compared to a T1’s significantly higher price. Why would a cost-conscious business choose to pay more for seemingly the same service?

When everything functions flawlessly, the differences might seem negligible. However, T1 dedicated internet provides symmetrical upload and download speeds and dedicated bandwidth, generally outperforming business DSL and consumer-grade internet services. But the true value of T1 lies in its service guarantee.

T1 lines come with a Service Level Agreement (SLA), a contractual agreement outlining the provider’s response time to outages and the compensation you receive during downtime. This “insurance policy” incentivizes the provider to address and resolve issues swiftly.

In contrast, DSL or Cable modem internet offers “best effort” service without guaranteed performance levels. While providers will work to restore service, the time frame can be unpredictable, ranging from hours to days. T1 downtime usually receives attention within 30 minutes to a maximum of 4 hours.

Therefore, the true cost comparison between T1 and DSL goes beyond the advertised price. Consider the potential financial impact of downtime on your business. How much revenue would you lose in an hour, a day, or two? Could it be $1,000, $5,000, or even $10,000? If so, that seemingly affordable DSL connection could become significantly more expensive after a single outage.

The emergence of VoIP has further intertwined phone service with internet connectivity. Losing a DSL connection that supports your phones, computers, and web server can be completely paralyzing.

While only you can determine the specific risk to your business, alternatives to consumer-grade connectivity exist. Integrated T1 services, for instance, combine traditional phone lines and internet access on a single T1 line, potentially saving money compared to multiple phone lines and a separate DSL connection, all while benefiting from an SLA. Another option is a fractional T1 line, providing a portion of the bandwidth at a reduced cost while retaining the crucial service level agreement.

item.title: VoIP Phone Service Provides Flexibility
item.description:
Businesses of all sizes might be considering upgrading their phone systems but are unsure of the best approach. Should they stick with their existing Key Telephone or PBX system and upgrade it, or is it time to transition to VoIP? What many businesses may not realize is the wide range of options that VoIP solutions offer.

The key difference between VoIP and traditional phone systems lies in its network-based approach. While even a single-line phone or cell phone operates on a network, known as the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN), this network has limitations. It excels at connecting individual phones or facilitating conference calls but operates within its own technology and wiring constraints. In contrast, VoIP is designed to function seamlessly with standard computer networks that utilize packets of data.

This fundamental difference highlights the adaptability of VoIP. Similar to connecting a computer or printer, an IP phone simply plugs into a network jack, eliminating the need for specialized wiring. Location becomes irrelevant as IP phones are identified by unique addresses rather than physical connections.

Traditional phone systems require businesses to choose between connecting each phone directly to the phone company or implementing an in-house phone system to share outside lines. VoIP offers similar flexibility, allowing for an in-house system called an IP PBX or extending the network to a service provider through Hosted VoIP or Hosted PBX. This connection, known as a SIP Trunk, offers several advantages.

SIP Trunking allows businesses to consolidate their phone and internet services with a single provider. The SIP trunk can be configured to prioritize voice and data packets, preventing disruptions to calls during data-intensive activities. This combined approach often leads to cost savings compared to separate phone lines and internet connections.

Hosted PBX services provide businesses with unparalleled flexibility in phone placement. Beyond simply rearranging phones within an office, a hosted PBX enables phones in different geographical locations to function seamlessly as if they were under one roof. This capability, known as a virtual office, is made possible by SIP trunks connecting phones, regardless of their physical location.

For larger enterprises, robust VoIP systems manage hundreds or even thousands of phones distributed across headquarters, regional offices, and branches. Private SIP Trunks securely facilitate voice and data transmission between these locations, bypassing expensive phone company charges for internal calls. The central PBX system can be located on-site or hosted, offering flexibility and scalability. One of the most significant advantages of hosted VoIP is its pay-as-you-go model, eliminating the need for substantial upfront investments in equipment and dedicated staff for maintenance and upgrades.

Could your business benefit from a more adaptable communication system that integrates mobile phones and desk phones? If so, we encourage you to explore pricing and features quotes for competing VoIP service providers to compare and discover potential cost savings and increased flexibility.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoring the Hood
item.description:
Restoring a Beogram often includes restoring its hood, as many have accumulated scratches over time. This particular Beogram 4002 (5513) had deep scratches on its hood.

The restoration started by sanding with 220-grit sandpaper, then progressively moved to finer grits (320-grit shown). This process, which took about 3 hours and involved around 10 polishing steps with Micro-Mesh up to 12000 level, returned the hood to a translucent and shiny condition.

The rubber bumpers on the hood corners had deteriorated, leaving only embedded remnants. These remnants were drilled out using a 2mm drill bit. New bumpers were fashioned from sections of a 2mm O-ring, secured with super glue gel, and trimmed to a 1mm length for proper hood alignment.

With the hood restored, this Beogram 4002 is well on its way to looking its best again!

item.title: You Are Definitely Going to Need More Bandwidth
item.description:
By: John Shepler

Suddenly, the typical workplace is no more. The usual routines of office life have vanished. Employees are no longer commuting to their desks. Cubicles and parking lots are deserted. Countless desktop computers and phones sit idle.

The New Normal: Where is Everyone?

A small team remains onsite, but the majority of employees are working from home. There’s been a massive effort to establish remote connections using personal computers, iPads, and smartphones, relying on cable and cellular broadband. Consequently, bandwidth usage has surged by 30% or more. Video conferencing has become indispensable, with platforms like Skype, Zoom, FaceTime, RingCentral, GoToMeeting, and Webex taking center stage, utilizing built-in microphones and cameras.

This is Not a Temporary Situation

It’s tempting to believe that this disruption to our work lives is temporary. That in a few short weeks, things will return to normal. This is likely wishful thinking. While the pandemic might be peaking or has peaked in areas hit early and hard, it’s far from over. The crisis will continue to unfold in other regions that were not initially affected and have only recently implemented lockdowns. It will be like a rolling disaster, moving from city to city, even reaching less populated regions. Just as we start to feel like it’s behind us, a resurgence of infections is predicted for the fall.

Effective treatments and vaccines are anticipated, but they are likely months, if not a year or more, away. While the situation may not remain a constant crisis, it’s safe to say that it won’t be business as usual for a while. We must adapt and discover how to maintain successful businesses without large groups of people in a single workspace or close contact between employees and clients.

Essential Tools for the Virtual Business

Mastering distributed processes, secure communications, and remote operations is critical. VPNs will be crucial for security, while private and public cloud services will host the software that drives businesses. Robust bandwidth will connect it all together. “Touchless” interactions will be the new standard, with technology replacing hands-on activities.

What kind of bandwidth will be necessary? Basic home broadband won’t suffice. Remote employees may not have access to the high-performance business-grade private lines often used in offices. They will, however, require dependable bandwidth for video conferencing with coworkers, management, and customers, ensuring that home computers function as seamlessly as their office counterparts. While cable broadband might be adequate in some instances, remote areas may require an SD-WAN solution that combines cable, T1, WISP, 4G and 5G cellular, and even satellite connectivity for a comprehensive solution.

Bandwidth-Intensive Industries

Medical facilities, labs, and hospitals demand high-performance bandwidth solutions such as Gigabit Ethernet, 10 GigE fiber, dark fiber, and MPLS networks. These connections are crucial for linking distant facilities or collaborating organizations. While readily available in densely populated areas, these solutions pose a greater challenge in rural locations.

IT Bandwidth Requirements: Re-evaluated

The need for IT department connectivity has changed. High-performance, dedicated bandwidth connections to public, private, and hybrid cloud services will be essential. These connections offer faster, more responsive, and stable experiences than standard internet connections, providing a “LAN-like” quality from any business location. Dedicated point-to-point fiber optic lines, Metro Ethernet services, and MPLS networks that span large geographical regions, including global coverage, can achieve this.

The Aftermath

While this crisis will eventually pass, things may never return to the way they were. Businesses may find themselves surprised by the productivity of their remote workforce, even with the presence of children and pets. The truth is that those cubicles often saw a lot of socializing, personal internet use, and non-work-related emails. Allowing a large portion of employees to work remotely eliminates their commute and, potentially, childcare costs. It also reduces the need for physical office space. As a result, performance management may shift from monitoring physical presence to focusing on goal-oriented outcomes.

We can expect a significant increase in remote work, with core teams potentially operating from smaller facilities or shared workspaces. Video conferencing may replace many business trips once considered essential. It’s possible to achieve the same, if not higher, levels of productivity at a reduced cost while increasing flexibility. Moreover, securing additional help could become faster and more cost-effective without the need for relocation.

Introducing Drobo, an advanced hard disk storage solution that’s surprisingly easy to use. It works with standard 3.5" SATA drives of any capacity, resembling a straightforward multi-bay drive enclosure. Adding or removing drives, even swapping a 1 TB for a 2 TB, is always possible.

You might think this flexibility requires complicated administration, but it’s truly plug and play. No need for arcane command lines or admin panels – everything’s automated and user-friendly.

Essentially, you’re building your own private storage cloud on-site. This eliminates bandwidth concerns for real-time data access, as the unit sits on your network.

You’re likely familiar with RAID (Redundant Array of Independent Drives), which safeguards data against drive failures. Drobo goes further with “BeyondRAID.” Unlike RAID, it accommodates drives of varying sizes. Connect any six SATA drives to a Drobo, and the system automatically configures redundant storage, creating a combined storage pool without limitations from the smallest disk.

This aligns with the cloud philosophy – you don’t worry about the technical details. Need more space? Add a drive. Bays full? Swap a smaller drive for a larger one. The system adapts, providing extra capacity without data loss.

Upgrading is also effortless. Transitioning from a 9-bay to a 12-bay system (up to 24 TB) involves moving drives to the new unit. Don’t remember the order? No problem. Plug them in anywhere, add new ones, and you’re set. Status lights turn green when the system is ready.

Sound too good to be true? Explore their materials and watch the demo videos. Drobo units begin at four bays for small offices, scaling upwards to meet your needs.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Service Manual Adjustments & Preparing for Use
item.description:
In the previous post, I finished cleaning and deoxidizing the keypad and RPM panel. The keypad is now responsive, but the cueing up and down button is overly sensitive and needs further attention.

The RPM panel re-installation was put on hold because the plastic mounting fixtures were cracked, a common issue with Beogram 4002 turntables. I was fortunate that the cracks weren’t severe and the fixtures were still usable. To repair them, I used acrylic repair fluid while pressing the pieces together. Since this fix alone isn’t durable enough for frequent removal and re-installation, I reinforced it with Dura-Lar strips and epoxy on both sides of each mounting block.

The repaired mounting blocks attach to the aluminum frame with set screws located underneath. It’s important to note that the mounting screw for both the keypad and the RPM indicator panel sits directly below the RPM panel. This means the panel must be removed to access the keypad buttons or phono output board, highlighting the necessity of reinforcing the mounting blocks.

Next, I focused on verifying the voltages and signals from the Beogram’s detectors. The first check was the 4D1 LED and 4IC1 optical sensor, which detect the tangential arm’s position. The sensor reacts to light changes as the arm moves along the acrylic slide.

Following the service manual, I measured the voltage at the collector of the 4IC1 sensor with a transparent section of the slide between the LED and sensor. The voltage should be around 5V, and if not, adjusted using the 1R88 trimmer on the main board.

This adjustment is crucial because the run-out groove detection at the end of a record relies on a correctly set voltage level.

Next, I examined the fixed arm sensor, responsible for detecting the presence of a record and determining if it’s safe to lower the tonearm. The fixed arm has a light source directed at the platter, and an optical sensor reads the reflected light. A consistent, dim light signal, indicating a record is present, allows the stylus to be lowered. Without a record, the platter’s black ribs interrupt the reflected light, creating pulses that prevent the stylus from lowering.

This sensor’s signal needs to function correctly and at the appropriate level.

The sensor is producing pulses exceeding the required 6 volts, ensuring the tonearm won’t lower onto an empty platter.

Before checking the end groove and run-out stop circuit, I wanted to complete some mechanical checks and adjustments to prepare the Beogram for playback. I was pleased to find the platter-to-tonearm height was already at the required 23mm.

The arm lowering limit needed setting to ensure the stylus tip is approximately 1mm from the top of the first platter rib. This safety measure safeguards the cartridge from damage if the record detection circuit fails.

Another mechanical adjustment involved checking the tonearm’s length and parallelism. By running a string tangent to the Beogram arm assembly, I could visually confirm the stylus followed the string’s path.

I had previously confirmed the 7.7mm distance and parallelism between the tonearm and fixed arm when disassembling and cleaning the tonearm assembly earlier in the restoration.

With those steps completed, record playback is getting closer. The remaining tasks include fine-tuning the tracking sensor sensitivity, verifying the run-off stop function, and calibrating the platter speeds.

Adjusting the tracking sensor was relatively smooth, though it involved several iterations to achieve the desired sensitivity where the tangential arm motor moves after the correct number of revolutions.

The run-off stop check on the oscilloscope showed good results. I successfully adjusted trimmers 1R14 and 1R15 on the main board to set the 33⅓ RPM and 45 RPM speeds using the Beolover RPM tool.

These Beograms require a lot of adjustments and checks, but their exceptional design makes them well worth the effort.

Now, it’s time for a break with food and fireworks – away from the Beogram, of course. Afterward, I’ll make a quick adjustment to the keypad cueing button, and then it’s time to relax and enjoy some vinyl.

item.title: DIA and VPN For Europe

The company recognizes the increasing importance of international connectivity for business success in a globalized marketplace.

While large corporations often manage their own private networks, many businesses need reliable internet access without the high investment. These businesses require high-quality internet for e-commerce, customer communication, and connecting geographically dispersed locations. Dedicated Internet Access is a popular choice for businesses as it provides exclusive bandwidth, unlike shared bandwidth options like DSL or cable broadband, where speeds can vary depending on user activity.

With DIA, businesses have a guaranteed bandwidth speed, such as 1.5 Mbps for T1 lines or 2.0 Mbps for E1 lines, for both uploads and downloads. Ethernet connections are gaining popularity as a scalable alternative to T1/E1 lines, offering speeds from 1 Mbps to 10 Gbps.

VPNs provide a secure way to utilize the internet by encrypting data and creating a “tunnel” for secure transmission. This is particularly useful for companies with multiple locations or employees working remotely. VPNs eliminate the need for costly dedicated lines, allowing businesses of all sizes to connect securely.

There are two common VPN methods: IPSec, which requires dedicated software, and SSL, which utilizes web browsers and is commonly used for secure online transactions.

item.title: Bandwidth To Support Branch Offices
item.description:
Many businesses need multiple locations in a region to stay close to their customers. Connecting these branches seamlessly without breaking the bank is a common challenge. Thankfully, two high-performance networking technologies, Metro Ethernet and MPLS Networks, offer affordable solutions that weren’t available even a decade ago.

Carrier Ethernet takes the local networking capabilities of Ethernet and extends them across entire cities. This means easy connection and efficient transmission without needing protocol conversions. Since the entire network, both local and wide area, can use level 2 switching, branch offices can access resources just like the main office. This Ethernet approach also tends to be cheaper than traditional telecom options due to increased competition.

MPLS, or Multi-Protocol Label Switching, is another option. It creates secure, high-performance networks capable of transporting various data types. Many providers now use MPLS for its ability to control network factors like jitter and latency, making it perfect for combined voice and data networks.

Ethernet and MPLS are very compatible. Companies often use Ethernet for local connections and MPLS for long-distance links, creating a powerful and flexible network.

If you need to connect branch offices, explore the pricing and availability of Ethernet and MPLS services. You might be surprised at the options available.

item.title: Broadband For The Home Office
item.description:
Home office users have a lot of choices when it comes to internet bandwidth, from basic residential DSL and cable to professional options like FIOS, Business DSL, T1, or even Carrier Ethernet. Which one is the right fit? Here’s a breakdown of what’s available and what makes sense for home-based work.

Residential broadband services are often the best choice for home offices, primarily because they’re the most affordable. These services are usually confined to residential areas. While businesses in commercial zones might have access to cable broadband, they often pay double the price for a similar connection with potentially enhanced customer service.

Besides cost, residential broadband suits home offices because occasional brief outages and fluctuating bandwidths are generally acceptable in exchange for savings. If a 20-minute outage wouldn’t disrupt your workflow, residential broadband is a cost-effective choice. Additionally, consider your VoIP needs. If you’re using VoIP phones, ensure the bandwidth can handle decent call quality with minimal drops. A single broadband connection might be sufficient for both your phone and internet usage with a good router that prioritizes voice packets.

Finding the best residential broadband deal is simple with online tools. Using a service like “Can I Get DSL?” helps you quickly compare available options and prices by entering your information.

It’s important to note that these search engines need your landline phone number to pinpoint your location accurately. This is crucial because broadband services are location-dependent; what’s available to your neighbor might not be accessible to you. DSL, in particular, relies on high-frequency signals transmitted through existing telephone lines, limiting its reach. This distance constraint applies to both residential and business DSL.

If you don’t have a landline and rely solely on a cell phone or VoIP, determining DSL availability might be difficult. Since DSL uses the same lines as landline phones, you’ll need a neighbor’s landline number (with their consent) to run a search and get an idea of potential services. To establish service, you’ll need to contact the cable company directly.

Verizon FIOS, a fiber-to-the-home (FTTH) service, is becoming increasingly available, particularly in the New York metropolitan area. This service offers high-speed internet with download speeds up to 30 Mbps, along with phone and television services, all delivered through fiber optic cables.

Satellite internet is another option if you’re in a rural location or an area not served by DSL or Cable. Although it’s pricier than other residential choices and comes with equipment fees, it’s a viable alternative to dial-up. However, keep in mind that the latency (delay) inherent in satellite internet makes it unsuitable for VoIP; conversations might resemble walkie-talkie exchanges.

Wireless broadband, offered by local providers with limited coverage areas, can be found through newspaper ads or the Yellow Pages. It can be a comparable alternative to cable broadband in terms of quality and cost, especially in smaller counties where cable internet might be limited.

Professional-grade telecom services, like T1, are common for businesses needing reliable connectivity. T1 offers consistent 1.5 Mbps upload and download speeds, often with service level agreements for guaranteed uptime. While significantly more expensive (around $400/month in major cities), it provides superior reliability, faster repair times, and potential managed router services. This level of service is generally chosen by individuals with demanding professions requiring top-tier connectivity.

Business DSL, another option, is usually found in commercially zoned areas near telephone company offices. Offering symmetrical bandwidth (similar upload and download speeds) at higher costs than residential DSL, it shares the same distance limitations.

Other business-oriented bandwidth solutions, such as T3 or DS3 (45 Mbps) and fiber optic Ethernet (10 Mbps to 1 Gbps), are geared towards larger companies. Starting around $2,000 per month, they are rarely justifiable for home office use.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Replacement of Carriage Position Sensor Photocell
item.description:
Over many years of working with the Beogram 400x, I’ve encountered a wide array of issues, but these turntables never cease to present new challenges. In this instance, a Beogram 4002 exhibited inconsistent behavior when attempting to locate the record’s setdown point after pressing start. This pointed to a potential fault in the carriage position sensor.

Initially, I suspected the IR LED, a common culprit in later models like this 5513 Type. I replaced the LED, adjusted the brightness, and achieved the desired 5V output at the photo sensor cathode. The unit seemed to function correctly, successfully finding the setdown point.

However, the issue resurfaced. The voltage fluctuated, and the setdown point was no longer reliably detected. I replaced the brightness adjustment trimmer, suspecting oxidation, but the problem persisted. With other components ruled out, I began to consider the photocell, despite never having had to replace one before. Testing the photocell with a multimeter revealed intermittent responsiveness, confirming its failure.

Because this specific photocell functions as a photoresistor in the circuit, I opted to replace it with a standard photoresistor. This required modifying the photocell housing to securely accommodate the new component. After redesigning and 3D printing a new insert, I was able to install a standard GL5539 photoresistor.

After experimenting with different photoresistor types, I found that the GL5539 provided consistent performance under various lighting conditions. It’s important to note that adjusting the LED intensity using R88 might be necessary to ensure reliable switching of TR17 based on the presence or absence of a black stripe in front of the sensor. Monitoring the collector voltage of TR17 with a voltmeter is recommended during this adjustment process.

item.title: T1 PRI For Call Centers
item.description:
When deciding on phone service for your call center, digital options are essential. While individual analog lines work for small setups, they lack integration capabilities and become costly as you expand beyond a few lines.

For call centers with 10-12 lines using traditional PBX systems, digital T1 carrier service is a cost-effective solution. T1 lines offer two configuration options: channelized and PRI (Primary Rate Interface). Channelized T1 provides 24 independent lines suitable for various call types but lacks advanced features like Caller ID.

PRI, on the other hand, utilizes 23 voice channels and one dedicated data channel, enabling faster call setup, Caller ID, and integration with Computer Telephone Integration (CTI) systems for enhanced customer data display. Multiple PRI lines can be combined for increased capacity, and using two data channels ensures redundancy.

VoIP (Voice over IP) systems offer another approach. By converting voice into digital data, VoIP leverages your existing Ethernet network for both phones and computers. Unchannelized T1 lines, or data T1 lines, are used for data transmission beyond your facility, offering 1.5 Mbps bandwidth and the ability to combine multiple lines for increased bandwidth through bonding.

To determine the most suitable and cost-effective T1 service for your call center, consult with experts like Shop for T1. Their consultants can assess your specific requirements and provide competitive quotes. Requesting a T1 service quote is quick, easy, and free. Remember that T1 lines are intended for business use, not residential purposes.

item.title: The Rose Is On The Bloom
item.description:
Bloom Energy recently introduced its “Energy Server” fuel cell, presenting it as a significant step towards greener energy and energy independence. This begs the question: how impactful will this new technology actually be?

While it’s early to definitively say, Bloom Energy’s generators could become a vital part of energy production and management, or even revolutionize our relationship with energy entirely.

The Bloom Energy Server originated from a NASA project aimed at generating air and fuel from electricity for Mars expeditions. When the project concluded, Dr. KR Sridhar and his team realized the technology could be reversed to produce electricity using air and fuel. After five years, they had a working prototype, and within a few more, they scaled it to a commercial level of 100 KW. Now, the Energy Server is a viable product, implemented by major corporations like Google and Ebay.

So, how does it work, and what makes it superior to other green energy solutions? The Bloom Energy Server is a high-temperature fuel cell that transforms hydrocarbon fuel and oxygen into water and electricity. This technology was first explored during the Apollo Moon program when NASA utilized fuel cells in their spacecraft. Bloom’s innovation lies in using a ceramic plate as a dielectric, coated with proprietary inks to facilitate chemical reactions. Each handheld plate can generate about 1 KW of electricity, and by stacking them in modules, power output can reach 10 KW for a home or 100 KW for a small business.

The fuel cell runs on natural gas directly from utility lines, landfill methane, or other available bio-gases, with oxygen sourced from the air. It produces heat and steam, essential for sustaining the reaction, and releases a small amount of CO2 as a byproduct – less than burning the gas directly. This process is cleaner and more efficient than using a gas turbine generator.

It can be compared to a quiet, solid-state gas turbine generator without exhaust, making it a suitable replacement for engine-based backup generators in homes and businesses. Currently, the cost is prohibitive for residential use. However, it offers a roughly three-year payback for businesses using it as an alternative energy source, not just backup power. This is impressive for a newly released product in limited production. As production scales up, prices are expected to decrease. Additionally, Bloom Energy Servers will be offered in a wider range of models with varying power levels.

Even if this technology simply offered a new way to convert natural gas to electricity, it would still be significant. But it’s more than that. Being a clean, quiet device that can be installed next to a building with a similar size and appearance to a large electrical transformer, it allows for more distributed power generation. If the price becomes more accessible, with a one-year payoff or better, there might be a rush by medium and large businesses to install these systems.

We anticipated this to happen with solar panels, but cost and the fluctuating nature of solar power hindered widespread adoption. Google, a Bloom Energy Server user, has installed large solar panel arrays, but these remain uncommon in the U.S. Wind energy is more popular but also suffers from inconsistent output due to wind variability.

Critics of green energy use these limitations to dismiss the idea of moving away from traditional hydrocarbon fuels. However, this perspective is too narrow. The solution isn’t a single breakthrough like fusion but a multi-faceted approach using various technologies managed by a smart grid that distributes energy efficiently. For example, solar power is ideal for peak air conditioning demands during summer midday hours when solar panels generate the most power.

A truly smart grid could even leverage millions of electric cars parked in garages to regulate grid stability by quickly supplying or absorbing small amounts of electricity. The Bloom Energy Server could serve a similar function on a commercial scale. Imagine companies having both a Bloom unit and solar panels on their premises. Our struggling energy grid would stabilize, potentially allowing us to decommission outdated coal-fired power plants.

Of course, we still need baseload power, which alternative sources can’t currently provide. This highlights the need for more nuclear plants to reduce carbon emissions. Bloom Energy Servers, in large numbers, could potentially contribute to baseload power. However, it’s unclear how much natural gas we’ll have if we replace coal with gas on a large scale. Additionally, converting fossil fuels to electricity inherently releases some CO2.

We don’t yet know how successful we can be if we fully commit to energy independence and green energy. We can’t claim to have truly tried until solar panels, windmills, and people selling excess electricity to the grid become commonplace. We reached the moon in under a decade using fuel cells. Imagine how quickly we could solve our energy challenges if we fully dedicated ourselves to wind, solar, and fuel cell technologies.

item.title: Fiber Optic Ethernet Transport Offers Huge Advantages
item.description:
By: John Shepler

Data can be moved in many ways. The new top choice is Fiber Optic Ethernet, known as EoF or Ethernet over Fiber, which offers excellent value.

What is Fiber Optic Ethernet Transport?
When fiber optic lines were first installed, Ethernet wasn’t a factor. The standard was SONET (Synchronous Optical NETworking), designed to carry existing DS1 and DS3 phone calls on fiber. Fiber offered significantly more bandwidth than copper twisted pair, microwave, or coaxial cable.

Ethernet started in computer networking. Sending this data outside required protocol conversion for T-carrier and SONET fiber to carry data packets instead of phone calls. Eventually, carrying Ethernet directly was standardized, creating Ethernet over Copper and Ethernet over Fiber. Wireless options like WiFi and WiMAX emerged for shorter distances, using microwave, laser, and radio systems.

The Immense Advantage of Fiber Optic Ethernet
Carrier Ethernet, adopted by various providers, is directly compatible with computer networks, eliminating protocol conversion. Services like E-LAN can even connect multiple LANs into one large network.

Ethernet is also easily scalable. Traditional MAN or WAN services offer fixed speeds (like T1 at 1.5 Mbps or DS3 at 45 Mbps), limiting data transmission and requiring upgrades for more bandwidth.

Fiber Ethernet has a nearly limitless ceiling. Each fiber strand can handle around 10 Gbps and be multiplied many times over. With hundreds of strands in a cable, capacity is rarely an issue.

Payment is based on the service level, such as 100 Mbps or 1 Gbps. Upgrading is often as simple as a phone call, with port capacity (often 1 Gbps to 100 Gbps) as the limit.

Best Advantage of All
Competition and fiber optics’ capacity have driven prices per Mbps lower than ever, often surpassing SONET. These reliable circuits often have service guarantees, symmetrical upload/download speeds, and dedicated bandwidth.

Competing Bandwidth Options
Ethernet over Copper offers similar benefits for bandwidths of 10-25 Mbps. T1 lines are viable for lower speeds (1.5-3 Mbps).

Budget-friendly choices, mostly shared bandwidth for consumers, include business cable broadband, wireless internet, satellite, DSL, and cellular broadband. While Mbps prices are tempting, these often have asymmetrical speeds (download significantly faster than upload).

Wireless options usually have usage limits, unsuitable for large downloads. Satellite, though widely available, has latency issues affecting real-time applications.

These services are almost exclusively internet access. In contrast, Fiber Ethernet offers dedicated internet access or private point-to-point lines.

The best bandwidth service for your business depends on your needs. With more options and better pricing than you might expect, discover what Fiber Optic Ethernet services are available in your area.

item.title: Telephony In The Cloud
item.description:
When we think about cloud networking, we often picture data networks moving information between locations. However, many businesses are also transitioning their phone systems to the cloud. This shift brings both benefits and hurdles.

The traditional phone network is essentially a large cloud network. This system is designed for reliability and high-quality service, handling countless users at once. Users connect to this cloud through a direct line to their nearest local central office, unconcerned with the complexities of the system. They simply want to make calls easily.

Some businesses create their own private phone clouds using ISDN PRI lines to link multiple office PBXs. This avoids per-call charges, only paying for external calls.

A more contemporary approach involves merging voice and data networks across offices, streamlining management. MPLS networks, known for their reliability and cost-effectiveness, often underpin these systems. This is known as enterprise VoIP, where a central IP PBX or smaller, distributed systems handle calls. ISDN PRI lines connect to the public network for outside calls.

SIP Trunking presents an alternative to ISDN PRI lines for carrying voice traffic. Functioning as part of the VoIP system, a SIP trunk links to an outside provider. This provider manages connections to the public phone network, often at lower costs due to bulk call termination.

Some businesses take it a step further, sourcing all phone services from the cloud. Using SIP phones or adapted analog phones on their network, they connect to a virtual PBX at the provider’s location via a private line or SIP trunk. This virtual PBX manages all call routing, both internal and external. This setup is perfect for companies without a physical office, allowing geographically dispersed teams to function as if they were together. Even the receptionist’s role is virtualized, routing calls based on voice prompts or keypad inputs.

To see if cloud networking can benefit your business, consult with an expert on enterprise VoIP telephone services.

item.title: How Maestro Smart Antenna Improves Fixed Wireless
item.description:
Accel Technologies, a branch of Accel Networks, is launching a groundbreaking product for fixed wireless connections: the Maestro smart antenna system. Maestro aims to make 3G and 4G fixed wireless broadband a more attractive alternative to pricier business connectivity options like T1, MPLS, VSAT, Frame Relay, and point-to-point microwave services.

What makes Maestro so special? Like other smart devices, Maestro utilizes active technology to enhance performance. In this situation, it improves the performance of a typically passive component: the RF antenna. Antennas are essential for all electronic communication. They can be as basic as a foil trace on a circuit board or as complex as a multi-element Yagi beam antenna. Satellite dishes, long wires used with shortwave radios, and vertical tower arrays for directional AM radio broadcasts are all examples of antennas.

The crucial thing about antennas is that they are the initial point of contact for incoming signals and the final component involved in outgoing signals. An antenna can be any arbitrary length of conductor or a precisely calibrated system. Most antenna designs are “cut” to a specific size that resonates with the frequencies in use. The correct antenna length significantly improves both transmission and reception. Tuning antennas can be achieved by adding other passive components, such as capacitors and inductors. Adding more elements or creating a parabolic reflector (like a satellite dish) increases the antenna’s gain, which acts like amplification, resulting in a stronger signal. However, as a passive device, there’s a trade-off: gain in one direction leads to reduced sensitivity in other directions. For most applications, this is beneficial, as a directional antenna minimizes interference from signals coming from other directions.

Consider the antenna on your wireless router – it’s likely a small, black vertical stick. Its length is specifically chosen for the frequencies it uses, but it isn’t directional. This “whip” antenna transmits and receives equally well in all horizontal directions but not as well vertically. This design is suitable for blanketing an area with reception, such as a WiFi hotspot, as it provides broad coverage for users spread out or on the move.

However, is a basic whip antenna sufficient for connecting to a fixed wireless service? It might be if the signal is very strong. But what if you’re just outside the range of optimal coverage? Smartphones and USB modem aircards are designed for mobility, so they must have universal coverage, even if it means compromising performance. However, with a fixed business location and fixed towers, using an antenna optimized for the transmission path is more efficient.

This is where Maestro comes in. Its high-tech, patent-pending design incorporates eight antennas, three switchable filter banks, and an embedded Low Noise Amplifier (LNA) that adjusts to maintain the best carrier-to-noise ratio for the 3G or 4G service in use. Maestro boasts over 500 distinct setting options for fine-tuning performance.

Why such complexity? Accel Networks specializes in leveraging the widespread availability of cellular broadband service across the US and Canada. While we primarily associate cellular with mobile phone internet, it can also serve as fixed-location broadband. However, it sometimes struggles indoors because the small antennas on USB dongles and MiFi boxes can’t get a strong enough signal. Introducing a quality antenna before the transmitter/receiver results in a robust signal that won’t drop or slow down.

Maestro will launch roughly a month from now. Accel anticipates that its introduction for 3G and 4G fixed wireless broadband will challenge existing solutions businesses use for high-speed internet access, including rooftop VSAT satellite dishes, T1 lines, DSL, cable, frame relay, and even microwave fixed wireless systems. Many businesses, especially small retail stores and offices, don’t need massive bandwidth. They need basic connectivity for credit card processing, email, and website access. 3G or 4G cellular service can provide the necessary bandwidth, reliability, and latency at a significantly lower cost. Accel already has over 6,000 installations demonstrating this, and Maestro will bring these benefits to even more locations.

If your business is in an area with limited or expensive broadband service, explore the availability and pricing of fixed wireless broadband. You might be surprised at its affordability and performance.

item.title: Ethernet over Copper vs Bonded T1
item.description:
T1 lines have long been considered a reliable connection option for small to medium businesses, gaining traction as prices dropped in recent years. However, a new technology called Ethernet over Copper (EoC) offers even greater bandwidth at a lower cost and with simpler connectivity.

EoC, like T1, uses existing twisted-pair telephone wiring commonly found in business locations. Traditional T1 lines use two twisted pairs within this wiring, allowing for simultaneous two-way data transfer at 1.5 Mbps. While T1 prices have fallen to a few hundred dollars monthly, EoC provides comparable pricing with double the bandwidth at 3 Mbps.

This difference stems from EoC’s more modern and efficient data transmission technology. T1, developed post-WWII, relies on a synchronized, channel-based system ideal for phone calls but less suited for today’s packet-based internet protocols. Ethernet, designed for packet-based transmission, avoids this incompatibility, leading to increased efficiency.

While T1 can achieve higher bandwidth by combining multiple lines (a process called bonding), EoC offers a greater advantage. T1 bonding is typically limited to 10-12 Mbps, while EoC can reach up to 100 Mbps over short distances, with 10-20 Mbps readily achievable. For speeds beyond 45-50 Mbps, fiber optic connections become the preferred choice.

The main limitation of EoC is its distance constraint, often referred to as a “Metro Ethernet” service. Its availability is generally confined to major metropolitan areas within a few miles of the central hub. In contrast, T1, designed with signal boosters for long-distance transmission, can be accessed virtually anywhere, though cost increases with distance.

While fiber optic infrastructure expands, businesses don’t have to settle for limited bandwidth. By exploring available options and comparing prices for EoC and Bonded T1, businesses can determine the most suitable high-bandwidth solution for their needs.

item.title: Private Networking With Wavelength Services
item.description:
As companies expand, they often reach a point where traditional telecom services fall short. This leads IT departments to consider purchasing or leasing dark fiber for enhanced bandwidth, latency, and control. However, there’s another option worth exploring: managed wavelength services.

In simple terms, a wavelength is a distinct color or lambda on a fiber optic strand. Fiber optic lines transmit multiple light beams simultaneously, with each color representing a unique wavelength or frequency of laser light. These different colors allow the light beams to coexist within the fiber without interference, similar to separate wire pairs in a copper bundle or channels in a cable system.

Multiple wavelengths enhance efficiency. Transmitting and receiving multiple lambdas is much more cost-effective than laying thousands of miles of fiber optic cable. Each cable contains numerous strands, and each strand carries multiple wavelengths, resulting in a massive bandwidth capacity for commercial use.

This technology is called Dense Wavelength Division Multiplexing (DWDM). The “dense” signifies that numerous wavelengths are closely spaced on the fiber. DWDM terminal equipment demands precise control over the light wavelengths, adhering to an International Telecommunications Union (ITU) standard for industry-wide compatibility. A single fiber strand can support up to 160 channels or wavelengths within the infrared C and L bands.

Companies with high bandwidth requirements can lease entire wavelengths from carriers who own fiber optic networks. Integra Telecom, for instance, offers wavelength services on their metropolitan and long-haul fiber optic network. A key advantage of wavelengths is protocol flexibility. Integra provides both traditional SONET Interface options at speeds of 2.5 Gbps and 10 Gbps, as well as Ethernet Interface options at 1 GigE and 10 GigE.

Unlike dark fiber, where you manage all terminal equipment, or unmanaged wavelengths with limited carrier support, Integra’s managed wavelength services provide a comprehensive solution. This includes terminal equipment, 24/7 network monitoring, and alarm surveillance from their Network Operations Center (NOC).

The result is a highly dependable, high-bandwidth, low-latency point-to-point optical wavelength service suitable for both long-haul and metropolitan connections. Integra boasts a 5,000-mile high-speed long-haul network, metro services in major Western US cities, and connections to Chicago, New York City, Ashburn, VA, and Dallas. Their 3,000-mile metro access network spans 35 markets across 11 Western states, connecting over 1900 buildings with fiber. Businesses in Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Minnesota, Montana, Nevada, North Dakota, Oregon, Utah, or Washington can all leverage Integra’s robust fiber optic network and wavelength services.

Wavelength services are particularly well-suited for businesses requiring robust business continuity and disaster recovery solutions, Ethernet transport, optical storage connectivity, or data storage connectivity. Organizations with multiple data centers often require the high capacity that wavelengths provide.

To determine if wavelengths are a good fit for your telecom needs, request competitive quotes for managed wavelength services from Integra and other leading carriers.

item.title: Business Phone Line Options
item.description:
By: John Shepler

Every business, regardless of size, requires at least one telephone line. While phone lines may seem straightforward, you might have more choices than you realize. Are you confident that your business has the most suitable phone line?

Plain Old Telephone Service

The traditional analog phone line, known as POTS (Plain Old Telephone Service), is a basic and familiar option.

POTS lines are simple, consisting of a single twisted copper pair connecting a standard RJ-11 phone jack on your wall directly to the telephone company’s central office. A varying electrical current in the wires carries the phone conversation.

It’s worth noting that POTS functions as a self-contained phone system. Traditionally, phones used passive electrical components and drew power directly from the phone line. This feature ensures phone service even during power outages, as long as the phone itself doesn’t require external power.

However, modern phones, even single-line models, often rely on electronic components and need AC power adapters or batteries. This is particularly true for cordless phone systems with multiple handsets. While you might still have a dial tone during a power outage, you’ll need a backup battery for the phone to function.

Multiple Lines

You’re not limited to a single POTS line; you can have as many as you need. Keep in mind that there’s no cost advantage to having multiple lines. Each line has a fixed price, whether you use one phone per line or share external lines using a Key Telephone System or PBX.

Wireless as an Option

Cellular phone service offers the possibility of eliminating landlines entirely. With cell towers replacing wires, wireless communication can be a practical solution for independent professionals who are frequently out of the office. A data plan allows for internet and voice telephony on the same device. You can enhance your mobile setup with features like a toll-free number, fax capability, and international calling. Shared plans can accommodate small offices as well. However, larger operations will likely still require wired landlines.

Moving up to Trunks

A telephone trunk consists of multiple phone lines combined into a single cable. While analog trunks existed in the past, digital technology has become the standard. The most prevalent types of trunks are T1, ISDN PRI, and SIP.

T1 lines were developed to replace multiple analog POTS lines. Instead of separate wires, T1 lines utilize multiplexing to divide the available bandwidth into 24 independent channels, each functioning like a separate phone line.

If you have numerous phones and want to replace individual lines with a single T1 line, you might achieve the same or better service at a lower cost. A “channel bank” converts signals between T1 channels and analog lines, allowing you to connect your phones as usual.

T1 vs ISDN PRI

ISDN PRI (Primary Rate Interface) is a variation of the T1 line that employs the same channelization method but reserves one channel for dialing and switching for the remaining channels. This means you have a maximum of 23 available outside lines on a PRI trunk. However, ISDN PRI offers faster call switching, which is advantageous for call centers and businesses requiring highly efficient phone operations.

Most modern PBX systems have integrated interface circuitry for both T1 and ISDN PRI. You connect the trunk line, and the system manages the necessary conversions.

SIP Trunks

Many companies are transitioning to or considering VoIP technology. SIP trunks are a natural fit for VoIP phone systems because they use the same protocol (SIP). VoIP or SIP phones connect directly to an Ethernet LAN, often shared with computers, printers, and other network devices. The SIP trunk extends this network to connect to the VoIP service provider.

Similar to T1 and ISDN PRI, SIP trunks support multiple simultaneous conversations. However, these conversations utilize packet streams combined on a single line instead of separate channels.

An additional benefit of SIP trunks is their ability to carry both internet data and phone calls using packet format. Prioritizing voice traffic over data traffic within the trunk, known as Class of Service or Quality of Service, ensures optimal voice quality.

To determine the most suitable phone line for your business, a quick approach is to obtain competitive quotes for various options, from POTS to SIP trunking.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of PCBs
item.description:
Following the restoration of the arm lowering and tracking mechanisms on a Beogram 4002 turntable, the subsequent task involves refurbishing the printed circuit boards (PCBs) and replacing the reservoir capacitor.

The initial focus is on the main PCB. It was in its original state, showing signs of age and use. A detailed view highlights the RPM control section, which was particularly important for speed stability.

All electrolytic capacitors on the board were replaced with new, high-quality Japanese components rated for 105 degrees Celsius. Additionally, a new relay and a set of 25-turn, encapsulated trimmers for RPM adjustment were installed. For comparison, the old and new versions of the relay and trimmers were shown side-by-side. These upgraded components are offered to other enthusiasts interested in restoring their own Beogram turntables.

The rebuilt board, alongside the extracted components, demonstrates the extent of the refurbishment. It’s important to note that the trimmers were positioned so that their adjustment screws extended through the PCB. This allows for RPM adjustments while the board is installed, and the platter is rotating.

Next, the output PCB, which houses the output grounding relay, was rebuilt. The delay capacitor and the relay were replaced, and a switch was added to connect the system and signal grounds. This feature is beneficial when using an RCA adapter with the turntable, as it can help eliminate humming that sometimes occurs.

Finally, a new reservoir capacitor was installed. This Beogram 4002 had a dual-capacitance type, no longer available, featuring a 4000uF section and a 1000uF section. The 1000uF section is utilized only when a CD-4 board is present, which is uncommon. The 4000uF section is crucial for the Beogram’s operation. To replace this discontinued component, a two-capacitor assembly was used with a 3D-printed adapter designed to fit the original capacitor’s mounting bracket. A 20k resistor was added across the 1000uF capacitor to discharge it when the turntable is unplugged for maintenance or transportation.

The next phase of the restoration project will involve rebuilding the RPM trimmer panel and upgrading the scale illumination from traditional light bulbs to LED assemblies.

item.title: High Fiber Diet for Business Not Expensive
item.description:
With business picking up, many companies are hitting a wall – their internet connections can’t keep up with the increased data flow. The solution? A high-fiber diet for their network.

Fiber optic cables are incredibly efficient. A single strand can handle massive amounts of voice, data, and video simultaneously, far exceeding the needs of most businesses. This capacity can be further multiplied by splitting the light into different wavelengths, each carrying gigabits per second. A fiber optic connection essentially unlocks almost limitless bandwidth potential for your business.

While fiber optic communication was once prohibitively expensive, competition has significantly driven down prices. Unlike the past, where local phone companies held a monopoly, numerous providers now offer fiber optic services. Many possess their own fiber optic core networks and access networks using both fiber and copper.

Using copper, multiple twisted-pair wiring can deliver Ethernet speeds up to 45 Mbps by connecting to nearby carrier hubs. Fiber optic access is also a viable option for most city-based businesses, especially where usage justifies the installation cost. It’s becoming standard for office buildings and industrial parks to include fiber optic service as a basic utility during construction, allowing tenants to easily adjust their service level based on their needs.

What services can you get with fiber optic connections? A basic option is DS3, a digital service also used on T3 lines, offering 45 Mbps. However, DS3 uses just a fraction of a single fiber strand’s capacity. This means multiple customers can have their DS3 connections bundled on the same fiber optic line.

SONET, or Synchronous Optical NETwork, is the standard fiber optic service. Common SONET options include OC3 (155 Mbps), OC12 (622 Mbps), OC-48 (2.5 Gbps), and OC-192 (10 Gbps). While other levels exist, they are less widely available.

Many newer providers have built their networks on IP technology instead of the traditional telco standard, SONET. They offer Ethernet as a WAN service with various speed options, including 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps (Fast Ethernet), and 1000 Mbps (Gigabit Ethernet or GigE). Getting 10 Gbps Ethernet is feasible and surprisingly affordable if your business demands it, especially when time-to-market and productivity are crucial.

The cost of fiber optic services has become much more manageable. It’s common to find 100 Mbps Ethernet for a fraction of its past cost. If you require more bandwidth or haven’t explored pricing recently, get updated quotes before assuming it’s out of reach. You might be pleasantly surprised.
