item.title: Latest Evidence Of An Ethernet Juggernaut
item.description:
A powerful force is transforming the telecommunications industry, shifting it from traditional telegraphy and telephony to a digital packet-based system. This revolution, driven by Ethernet technology, is swiftly changing how our communication networks operate.

This shift towards Ethernet in metropolitan and long-distance networks highlights the dominance of digital networks, especially local area networks (LANs), in communication. While voice calls once dominated global traffic, data and video now reign supreme. Video, in particular, is driving the expansion of content delivery networks (CDNs) to handle high-definition content efficiently.

Consider how communication has evolved. The office desk phone, once central to business, has been supplemented by email, text messaging, and social media. Data has migrated from paper to hard drives, traversing electronic networks. Even cell phones, though still called “phones,” are heavily used for texting, emailing, and social media engagement, highlighting the focus on data transmission over voice.

The transition from telegraphy to telephony and now computer data networking has been gradual. While long-distance computer connections often utilize lines initially designed for digital phone calls, this method has limitations. Dial-up, which used analog lines for digital signals, quickly reached its capacity. Digital telephone trunks, such as T1 lines, DS3, and SONET fiber optic services, offer higher bandwidth but still involve translating data packets, leading to inefficiencies. As most LANs now run on Ethernet, transitioning metro and long-haul networks to Ethernet offers a streamlined, end-to-end solution.

Facilitating this shift is the industry’s transition from collision domains to switched Ethernet. This change doubled network speeds by enabling simultaneous transmission and reception. It also removed length constraints associated with collision detection. With switches replacing hubs in LANs, long-distance connections spanning thousands of miles can now function as a single LAN.

Underscoring this trend are recent developments in Carrier Ethernet. Windstream, a major carrier, now offers Carrier Switched Ethernet, providing wholesale bandwidth access to other carriers through its 980 network exchanges. Using Ethernet Network to Network Interfaces (E-NNI), this service significantly expands network reach by interconnecting with other providers. MegaPath, another major network service provider, has expanded its Ethernet over Copper (EoC) infrastructure, becoming the largest EoC provider in the US. Their network, covering 19 major markets, offers speeds up to 45 Mbps over copper lines, replacing the need for bonded T1 or DS3 lines.

The combined force of Ethernet over Copper, Ethernet over Fiber, and Ethernet Network to Network Interfaces enables a complete “all Ethernet” solution for businesses with multiple locations and dedicated internet access. This technology offers significant cost savings and facilitates the implementation of complex multi-point mesh networks. To explore how your company can benefit, compare Carrier Ethernet pricing, availability, and features with your current solutions.

item.title: WAN Providers Bandwidth Service Options
item.description:
Having a reliable internet connection is crucial for modern businesses. There are many options available, so it’s important to understand what’s on the market and how to find the best prices.

Wide Area Networks (WANs) and Metropolitan Area Networks (MANs) are how businesses connect to each other and their customers, essentially extending the reach of a Local Area Network (LAN). While traditionally dominated by telecom companies, the WAN market has seen an influx of new providers offering competitive services.

A popular choice for WAN service is the T1 line, a reliable option that’s been around for decades. A standard T1 line provides symmetrical bandwidth of 1.5 Mbps and can be used for private connections between business locations or dedicated internet access. T1 lines also support business phone systems, with options like ISDN PRI offering additional features and faster switching.

Ethernet over Copper (EoC) is a strong competitor to T1, often providing double the bandwidth at a comparable price. EoC is easily scalable to meet growing bandwidth needs. However, its availability is often limited to metropolitan areas due to distance constraints from the central office.

Business Cable broadband is another option gaining popularity, especially among smaller businesses. This option boasts impressive download speeds, but upload speeds are significantly lower. Cable broadband operates on a shared bandwidth model, meaning speeds can fluctuate based on usage by other customers.

For businesses demanding high-speed internet, fiber optic lines are the way to go. Options like DS3 and Ethernet over Fiber offer speeds ranging from 100 Mbps to 10 Gbps, making them suitable for bandwidth-intensive applications.

Wireless connections also have a place in WAN connectivity. Low-bandwidth fixed wireless, utilizing 3G and 4G technologies, is often used for applications like credit card verification. Higher-bandwidth fixed wireless can serve as an alternative to wired connections in specific areas.

For extensive connectivity needs, MPLS networks offer regional, national, and international coverage. These networks provide scalability and security, making them suitable for businesses with multiple locations.

Navigating the wide array of WAN options can feel overwhelming. Telecom brokers simplify the process by providing access to multiple carriers and tools for comparing pricing and availability. By leveraging these resources, businesses can make informed decisions and choose the best solution for their needs.

item.title: Lock In Telecom Cost Savings For Next Year
item.description:
As we wrap up the year and analyze our performance, it’s common to wonder if we’re overspending on business operations, especially networking and telecom. A thorough market analysis often reveals opportunities to secure better rates for the same services. By doing this now, you can lock in savings for the entire next year.

Why are such savings possible? Primarily, increased competition and technological advancements. Previously, businesses were limited to local telephone companies for their communication needs. Deregulation has since opened the market, introducing competition in long distance, local, and even international services.

The second factor is the evolution of technology. Traditional telecom networks, designed by telephone companies, have become outdated in today’s digital age. While they function with protocol conversion, they are no longer the most efficient or cost-effective means of data transmission.

A better alternative is IP-centric networks. These networks, using protocols like Ethernet, offer a seamless connection between local networks across locations. This setup eliminates the need for complex conversions and improves efficiency.

Consider lower-speed connections like T1, now challenged by Ethernet over Copper (EoC). Both utilize existing telephone wiring but differ in data transfer methods and characteristics. While T1 is limited to 1.5 Mbps per line, EoC offers speeds up to 100 Mbps, depending on proximity to the central office.

More importantly, EoC is significantly cheaper than T1. For instance, 3 Mbps EoC costs roughly the same as 1.5 Mbps T1. For greater bandwidth, Ethernet over Fiber (EoF) is a viable option with speeds ranging from 10 Mbps to 10 Gbps.

The combined impact of competition and technological advancements has led to a significant drop in telecom prices. Savings of up to 50% on voice, data, and internet services are not uncommon. Businesses with expiring contracts on older technologies stand to save even more.

The solution? Obtain competitive quotes for voice, data, and cloud services and compare them to your current expenses. Securing these savings before year-end ensures maximum benefits for the next year. What better way to start the new year than by boosting your bottom line?

item.title: Choosing Dark Fiber vs Lit Fiber Service
item.description:
When applications require the bandwidth of fiber optic transmission, businesses face a choice: use existing “lit” fiber services or establish their own transport services using purchased or leased “dark” fiber.

Deciding between these options involves weighing performance, cost, and installation time. Focusing solely on cost can lead to extended installation delays, potentially impacting operational needs. While a cost-effective solution might be suitable with ample planning time, immediate bandwidth demands may necessitate prioritizing availability over cost.

Choosing between dark and lit fiber is akin to the decision between owning and renting. Many companies opt to analyze available bandwidth services and select the most cost-effective option that fulfills their requirements. Engaging a telecom broker can streamline this process and potentially secure better pricing.

Both dark and lit fiber services are highly location-dependent. Fiber availability can vary significantly even within short distances, and existing infrastructure can influence the feasibility of new fiber optic connections.

Lit fiber services encompass various categories, including traditional SONET/SDH services and Carrier Ethernet. SONET/SDH, with its standardized Optical Carrier (OC) levels, offers bandwidth options ranging from 156 Mbps to 10 Gbps. Carrier Ethernet, recognized for its scalability and cost-effectiveness, is increasingly prevalent and offers bandwidth options from 100 Mbps to 10 Gbps.

For higher bandwidth needs, wavelength services provide a dedicated virtual fiber path within a shared fiber optic cable. This option, suitable for 10 Gbps requirements, offers advantages such as low latency and enhanced security.

Dark fiber provides the ultimate flexibility by granting control over all wavelengths on a leased fiber optic cable. While requiring investment in termination equipment, dark fiber allows for customized configurations, including utilizing different protocols on each wavelength. This option generally suits larger organizations with intricate IT requirements.

Before selecting a fiber optic service, organizations should thoroughly evaluate pricing, installation timelines, and the available options at their specific location to determine the most suitable solution.

item.title: DS1 Telephone Service Lowers Business Phone Bills
item.description:
DS1, more commonly known as T1, is a digital telecommunications standard that can potentially save businesses substantial amounts of money on their phone bills. Despite its benefits, many people are unfamiliar with it.

Although the terms are often used interchangeably, there’s a slight distinction between DS1 and T1. DS1 (Digital Signal 1) refers to the format of the digital signal transmitted over the line, while T1 describes the physical four-wire copper connection itself. Essentially, T1 carries the DS1 signal that carries the actual information.

DS1 technology offers 24 separate phone lines through a single digital connection. Each line operates within a dedicated channel known as a DS0, providing clear and reliable “toll quality” voice communication for both local and long-distance calls. This quality surpasses typical cellular calls and rivals well-engineered VoIP systems.

Unlike services relying on internet connectivity, DS1 delivers consistent call quality thanks to synchronized channels. This reliability makes DS1 popular among businesses who depend on clear and uninterrupted communication.

The cost-saving benefits of DS1 stem from its ability to combine multiple lines onto one. By consolidating up to 24 analog lines into a single digital line, businesses can achieve significant savings, especially those with eight or more outgoing lines. Integrating a T1 line with a PBX system further optimizes communication infrastructure and reduces monthly expenses.

If your business is looking for ways to reduce telecommunication costs, exploring the advantages of DS1 telephone service could be a financially sound decision.

item.title: Hosted PBX Adds Video Services
item.description:
Cloud-based phone systems, also known as Hosted VoIP or Hosted PBX, are gaining popularity with businesses of all sizes. This technology offers advanced features without requiring a large upfront investment. Now, these systems are evolving to incorporate video services as well.

MegaPath, a leading network and cloud service provider, is enhancing its hosted PBX offerings by including cloud-based unified communications video services.

A new generation of business phones makes voice and video integration possible. These “media phones,” as Polycom, a leader in IP telephony, calls them, resemble tablets with integrated screens and often have built-in cameras or support for external webcams.

Unified Communications (UC) aims to combine voice, data, and video on a single network. Taking this concept further, cloud-based UC simplifies the process even more. With your existing company network and essential equipment like computers and phones, you can move almost everything else to the cloud. Adding video capabilities enables desktop conferencing without needing new servers or significant network changes. The cloud handles all the technical complexities.

Integrating video into your voice communications offers significant advantages. It allows for instant video conferencing without dedicated rooms or scheduled meetings. While traditional video conferencing has been used to reduce travel costs, desktop video conferencing takes it a step further, enabling spontaneous or planned video meetings without disrupting employee workflows.

This type of personalized video communication is already familiar from smartphones, tablets, and laptops. The common thread is mobility.

Today’s workforce is no longer tied to a single location. Communication happens before leaving home, during commutes, at desks, and while on the move. In the past, this meant relying on operators or voicemail to relay messages, leading to delays in communication.

In today’s fast-paced business world, communication delays are unacceptable. Unreachable employees can stall projects, and potential clients might seek alternatives if they can’t connect immediately. A unified communication system is essential.

This is where cloud-based PBX systems excel. They integrate desk phones and mobile phones through Fixed Mobile Convergence (FMC). With video and single-number calling, you have consistent features and connectivity regardless of location.

Many hosted VoIP systems also offer HD audio. While mobile phones and some VoIP systems have compromised audio quality compared to traditional “toll grade” standards, HD audio elevates VoIP to deliver superior sound quality.

If your business phone system hinders productivity or requires costly maintenance or upgrades, explore the potential of Hosted PBX Cloud Services for both audio and video communication before committing to a solution.

item.title: FastE Fiber as MetroE for Business Ethernet Service
item.description:
As businesses increasingly rely on data, the need for high-speed data transfer is becoming crucial. Fast Ethernet, a readily available and budget-friendly solution, offers a reliable way to achieve this over existing fiber optic networks. Let’s delve into how Fast Ethernet operates and its role in optimizing bandwidth strategies.

You’ve likely utilized Fast Ethernet (FastE) on your network for years. FastE, synonymous with 100 Mbps Ethernet, surpasses standard Ethernet’s 10 Mbps and falls short of Gigabit Ethernet’s 1,000 Mbps. Network Interface Cards (NICs) in devices with Ethernet ports support one or more of these speeds. A 10/100 port handles both 10 Mbps and 100 Mbps, while a 10/100/1000 port accommodates 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps, and 1,000 Gbps.

Most computers, network devices, and peripherals already support 10/100 Ethernet, with the 10/100/1000 standard becoming increasingly common. Essentially, these devices are Fast Ethernet (100 Mbps) compatible.

The limitation lies in MAN and WAN connections, many of which fall short of these speeds. This disparity highlights how computer technology has advanced faster than communication technology. While 100 Mbps long-distance communication has been feasible for a while, specialized interfaces and high costs made it impractical for most businesses.

The high cost of proprietary data communication stems from traditional telephone industry practices. Many businesses rely on DSL or T1 lines for inter-office communication and internet connectivity. Although costs have decreased, limited bandwidth is becoming a bottleneck even for smaller enterprises.

The introduction of Carrier Ethernet services has transformed the landscape. These leased lines, provided by carriers, handle any communication beyond your premises. Unlike the past monopoly of local telephone companies, deregulation has allowed competitive carriers to offer diverse technologies and pricing.

Carrier Ethernet, now offered by both incumbent and competitive carriers, has experienced remarkable growth due to standardization by the Metro Ethernet Forum (MEF). MEF compliance ensures compatibility with Carrier Ethernet equipment and interconnection with other providers.

Fast Ethernet is a popular Carrier Ethernet service available for metropolitan and long-haul connections (MANs and WANs). MANs cover a city and its suburbs, while WANs connect cities across regional and national borders. International WANs utilize submarine fiber for global connectivity.

Ethernet-based metro networks (MENs or MetroE), often called MetroE networks, predominantly use fiber optic cables, extending this preference to network connections. Fast Ethernet and faster connections typically rely entirely on fiber.

MetroE networks offer various connection options, including the common 100 Mbps Fast Ethernet (FastE) and the 1,000 Mbps GigE. Emerging as a business-grade option is 10 GigE at 10,000 Mbps or 10 Gbps.

Implementing Ethernet throughout your network, including metro/wide area networks, offers significant advantages. The seamless interface with a standard Ethernet jack simplifies carrier handoffs. Additionally, businesses can opt for point-to-point E-Line connections or meshed multi-location E-LAN connections. Bandwidth flexibility is another benefit, with various increments available between 10, 100, 1,000, and 10,000 Mbps.

Cost savings remain the most compelling advantage. Ethernet significantly reduces the cost per Mbps compared to alternatives like SONET. This affordability empowers businesses to adopt bandwidth-intensive applications, such as cloud services, without breaking the bank.

Don’t let limited bandwidth hold your business back. Explore the high-bandwidth, affordable fiber optic connections offered by metro and wide area networks. Check bandwidth services and prices available for your business location.

item.title: Do You Still Have Broadband?
item.description:
By: John Shepler

Internet broadband speeds have increased significantly in recent times. While a few Mbps was initially considered sufficient, businesses are now rapidly adopting speeds of 100 Mbps and higher, with the FCC setting a 25 Mbps benchmark for broadband. This shift signifies escalating bandwidth demands driven by the increasing reliance on remote resources and the changing nature of online content.

What Does The New Standard Represent?

The updated broadband standards highlight the growing need for greater bandwidth. The transition from 4 Mbps to 25 Mbps reflects a fundamental change in how we use the internet. This trend is not expected to slow down due to the increasing reliance on data-intensive applications and services.

The Rapid Growth of Computing Requirements

From simple text-based communication, internet usage has evolved to encompass high-definition video streaming and complex cloud-based applications. As processor speeds and memory capacities continue to grow, so do the demands placed on network bandwidth.

What’s Next?

With the rise of 4K and the emergence of 8K video, bandwidth requirements will continue to increase. While apps may appear smaller, they rely heavily on complex backend processing on remote servers. Personalized services, location-based features, and the analysis of massive datasets demand robust and responsive networks.

Big Data, Big Support Required

Cloud computing, with its vast processing power and storage capacity, has emerged as the solution to managing large datasets. However, accessing these resources necessitates high-bandwidth connections to avoid bottlenecks.

Businesses are becoming increasingly reliant on automation and data-driven decision-making, necessitating even greater bandwidth to facilitate these processes. The increasing use of video conferencing, large file sharing, and cloud-based phone systems all contribute to the growing demand for bandwidth.

How Much Bandwidth Is Enough

While predicting future bandwidth needs with certainty is challenging, it’s clear that businesses today need to move beyond outdated technologies like T1 lines. A minimum of 25-50 Mbps is recommended for most businesses, with 100 Mbps being a suitable option for mid-sized offices. Larger organizations and those with high-bandwidth demands, such as video production or 3D printing, may require Gigabit or even 10 Gigabit Ethernet connections. As technology evolves, Terabit per second speeds are likely to become the new standard.

Ethernet is the Way to Go Now

Carrier Ethernet services provide the scalability and ease of use that businesses require in today’s rapidly evolving digital landscape. As your bandwidth needs change, these services can be easily adjusted to meet your requirements.

If your business is experiencing slowdowns or struggling to keep up with the demands of a data-driven world, upgrading your broadband connection is essential. With the availability of high-speed fiber optic connections at increasingly affordable prices, there’s no better time to upgrade your business’s digital infrastructure.

item.title: Increasing Bandwidth By Pair Bonding
item.description:
When your T1 line starts reaching its bandwidth limit, upgrading to a DS3 line might seem like the next step, but it comes with challenges. DS3 often requires fiber optic cable instead of the copper used for T1, and the cost difference is significant.

A simpler solution for a moderate bandwidth boost is adding another T1 line and using “pair bonding.” This technique combines two lines into one, effectively doubling your bandwidth to 3 Mbps. You can bond multiple lines, reaching up to around 10-12 Mbps.

Another type of pair bonding involves using unused copper pairs leased from the provider. These copper pairs, without any pre-existing signals, can be used for Ethernet over Copper (EoC).

EoC uses different modulation techniques to transmit data and can achieve higher bandwidths compared to traditional copper-based services. By employing methods like MIMO, EoC reduces interference between signals, allowing more data to be transmitted over fewer wires.

EoC services generally offer speeds between 3 Mbps to 10 Mbps, and in some cases, up to 50 Mbps. However, the maximum bandwidth decreases with distance from the provider’s office due to signal degradation.

Unlike EoC, T1 lines are not limited by distance because they incorporate signal boosters at regular intervals. If your location is too far for EoC, Ethernet over DS1 could be an option. This method uses the T1 protocol to deliver Ethernet signals, allowing for bandwidth increases through T1 pair bonding.

To determine if pair bonding suits your needs and budget, it’s recommended to explore available business bandwidth services in your area.

item.title: Benefits of a Gigabit Ethernet Network Connection
item.description:
The demand for high-capacity internet connections has caught some businesses off guard. What started as a T1 line evolved into a DS3 connection and maybe even an OC3 fiber optic service, but there always seems to be a bottleneck. It might be time to upgrade to Gigabit Ethernet (GigE).

It’s important to understand that those older telecom services you’ve been using are based on telephone technology. While they’re dependable, they weren’t designed for today’s network needs. This can lead to compatibility problems and inflated costs for the same connection speed.

Ethernet as a standard protocol, both internally and externally, eliminates connectivity issues. It ensures seamless communication for voice, video, and data transmission. Additionally, Ethernet can link multiple LANs into a single large bridged LAN, connecting geographically dispersed locations as if they were in the same building.

Just a few years ago, Gigabit Ethernet for local area networks seemed as outlandish as a Gigabit Ethernet WAN connection. Metro Ethernet and Carrier Ethernet were still new, and Gigabit Ethernet was seen as an excessive amount of bandwidth.

Today, GigE is no longer a laughing matter. Instead, businesses are eager to know where they can obtain it and how much it will cost.

This shift in attitude is due to the increasing bandwidth demands of modern computer applications. While multi-core processors and cheaper RAM have helped computers handle demanding tasks like video processing, networks are now feeling the strain.

Many current PCs, peripherals, and network devices come standard with 10/100/1000 Mbps Network Interface Cards, enabling Gigabit Ethernet on local networks. GigE provides the throughput needed for efficient file transfers and real-time operations without bottlenecks. The question then becomes, what about connections outside your facility?

For businesses dealing with medical imaging or video production, a Gigabit Ethernet connection might be the bare minimum. Similarly, GigE is essential for large organizations with consolidated data centers that require remote file access.

Fortunately, Gigabit Ethernet WAN connections are readily available in metropolitan areas, with multiple carriers vying for business in some downtown locations. The key requirement is a fiber optic connection to your building, as GigE surpasses the capabilities of copper-based and most wireless services.

The affordability of Gigabit Ethernet has improved, and competitive carriers are more willing to install fiber optic service aerially or underground. Check if fiber optic services are already available in your area.

item.title: The Cloud Needs Low Latency
item.description:
By: John Shepler

The Economic Appeal of Cloud Computing

Opting for cloud services over traditional data centers seems incredibly cost-effective. Instead of large loans and capital investments in servers and infrastructure, businesses can subscribe to a cloud service provider and pay only for the resources they consume. This eliminates the need to predict future business demands and allows for flexibility in scaling resources on-demand.

The Allure of Simplicity

The solution appears straightforward: forgo establishing a new data center or dismantle your existing one, and lease the necessary resources from a cloud provider. A simple network connection between your premises and theirs should suffice, making the physical location of the servers irrelevant to network users, who primarily interact with applications.

The Reality of Network Latency

The notion that a network can make distant resources seem as accessible as local ones is an ideal often challenged in reality. While a server miles away should theoretically function identically to one on-site, a noticeable delay can arise, creating inconsistencies in system responsiveness.

When Infinite Resources Feel Limited

Cloud data centers boast vast resources, allowing users to scale their usage dynamically and seemingly eliminating capacity constraints. However, some users experience limitations in the cloud that seem counterintuitive given its purported capabilities.

The WAN Factor

Often overlooked is the crucial role of the WAN (Wide Area Network) connection. While LAN (Local Area Network) performance is typically transparent due to high capacity and short distances, connecting over longer distances with WAN introduces challenges. Unlike local networks, WANs, especially those managed by telecom carriers, can exhibit sluggishness.

Factors Affecting WAN Performance

Several factors contribute to the transparency or lack thereof in WAN connections. Bandwidth, latency, jitter, and packet loss are key aspects. Maximizing bandwidth and minimizing the other three is crucial.

While increasing bandwidth might seem like the solution to sluggishness, latency, which is the inherent delay in data packet transmission over distance, cannot be mitigated by bandwidth alone.

Addressing Latency Issues

Minimizing the physical distance between connected points is one way to reduce latency. However, even at the speed of light, delays are unavoidable over long distances. Fiber optic cables offer faster speeds but still introduce latency, particularly over significant distances. Satellite links, while offering global coverage, introduce even more latency.

Therefore, using terrestrial fiber optic connections with the shortest possible routes is generally recommended for minimizing latency in cloud connections. Dedicated private lines offer the highest performance, while privately operated MPLS networks offer a balance between performance and cost-effectiveness.

The Internet as a WAN Option

The Internet, with its global reach and cost-effectiveness due to shared infrastructure, appears to be an ideal solution for cloud connectivity. While encryption can create secure tunnels, emulating private networks, performance limitations remain.

Unlike private networks optimized for minimal latency, the Internet prioritizes resilience. While this ensures continuous connectivity even with disruptions, it introduces variable paths and potential bottlenecks, ultimately impacting latency and jitter.

For applications demanding maximum performance or real-time interactivity, private lines are preferable. However, a hybrid approach utilizing Dedicated Internet Access (DIA) can provide a balance. DIA leverages the Internet’s high-performance backbone while using a private line for the “last mile” connection, minimizing latency and jitter.

Choosing the Right Cloud Connection

item.title: Beogram 4002: From Oil Cleanup to First Operational Test
item.description:
The Beogram 4002 restoration hit a snag. Although the main board was restored, the presence of rust and corrosion discovered earlier took priority. Addressing rust requires applying neutralizer and paint, which involves drying time between coats, thus delaying the planned reservoir capacitor and output board work.

Images highlighting the most severe rust spots are included.

Despite the significant rust, the turntable’s overall condition is good. To combat the rust, three coats of rust neutralizer were applied.

After a 24-hour drying period, the parts were painted with black oil-based paint.

Interestingly, the turntable, while heavily rusted, is otherwise in good condition.

The disassembly process revealed oil accumulation within the Beogram. This is a common issue stemming from using an improper type of oil on the turntable’s moving parts. Excess oil can be flung onto other components. The next step involved a thorough oil cleanup.

The floating chassis had to be removed to address the initial oil spill.

The tangential arm assembly, due for attention, was prioritized.

The spindle bearing nut showed clear signs of lubrication with thin oil instead of the correct grease.

This inappropriate oil, when subjected to the spinning of the tangential arm drive, splatters onto surrounding areas.

While oil was found on the floating chassis’s surface, the tangential drive sensor housing contained the largest concentration.

Such oil presence could disrupt the sensor’s function. After a thorough cleaning of the area, the tangential drive sensor assembly was reassembled.

This ensures the sensor’s proper functionality during the record tracking adjustment.

The arm lowering damper, found to be in good condition, was nonetheless cleaned and re-lubricated with light grease.

As is common, the tangential drive pulley exhibited hairline cracks, causing deformation when tightened to the spindle shaft, resulting in instability.

Remarkably, the Beogram’s transport bushings were in excellent condition, a rare find.

A new aluminum pulley, sourced from Nick, was installed.

With the assembly removed, an initial tonearm tracking force calibration was performed.

The installation includes a Beolover modification: a locking nut added to secure the tonearm counterweight in its calibrated position.

This concludes the initial mechanical restoration of the tangential arm. Focus can now return to the electrical system, specifically, replacing the reservoir capacitor.

A 3D-printed housing containing the new reservoir capacitors, a favored Beolover replacement part, was used.

This setup, a significant improvement over gluing the capacitors to the cabinet floor, utilizes the original Beomaster clamp.

Operational testing is nearing. The output board’s capacitor and muting relay have been replaced. A grounding switch will be added later.

Reassembly commenced with reinstalling the rust-treated chassis components in preparation for the floating chassis. The Beolover-restored DC platter motor was also reinstalled.

The Beogram is regaining its form. After installing the sub-platter, belt, and top platter, a test run can be conducted.

Seeing a successful first-time operation is always satisfying.

However, a thorough service manual check is necessary before risking a record.

item.title: Why Choose An MPLS VPN?
item.description:
Businesses need secure communication between their different locations. While private networks offer the highest level of security, they are expensive to build and maintain. Using the public internet is cheaper but raises security concerns.

A fully private network, offering top-notch security and performance, requires significant investment. Building a central hub and connecting each location with dedicated lines like T1 or Ethernet can become very costly, especially with increasing bandwidth demands and staffing for maintenance.

Many companies look for affordable alternatives to expensive private networks. While the public internet seems attractive due to its vastness and low cost, security risks make it a concern for businesses handling sensitive data.

Direct internet use for business communication is not advisable due to security concerns. However, using encryption technology, or tunneling, can make it a viable option.

Tunneling allows secure data transmission over the internet, similar to how SSL encryption enables safe online transactions. While cost-effective, internet-based solutions may lack performance stability, especially for bandwidth-intensive tasks like video conferencing or large data transfers.

This is where MPLS VPN networks come in. Designed for business use, these networks offer a balance of security, performance, and cost-effectiveness.

MPLS (Multi-Protocol Label Switching) uses labels instead of IP addresses to route data packets within the network, enhancing security and ensuring data privacy. While generally secure, additional encryption can be added for sensitive data.

MPLS VPNs are gaining popularity as a replacement for private networks due to significant cost benefits. Resources are shared among clients, making it an affordable option for businesses of all sizes.

If you’re looking for a cost-effective and secure network solution for your business, explore MPLS VPN options and compare them with private lines and IP VPNs to find the best fit.

item.title: Circuit Switched vs Packet Switched Networks
item.description:
By: John Shepler

Over the past few decades, two primary network technologies have been vying for dominance. The first is the traditional telephone system, which served us well throughout the industrial age. The second is the computer-based architecture that has driven the information age. You might recognize these as circuit switching and packet switching.

While both technologies will likely coexist for a while longer, we are at a turning point. From now on, packet switching will be the dominant force in every network, from copper lines to fiber optic cables to wireless connections. Let’s explore why.

What is Circuit Switching?

Circuit switching is a telephone-based technology. This system is logical for telephone calls because they need a dedicated connection between two devices for a specific period. Certain phones, like intercoms, can have a permanent, or “nailed up,” connection. For general use, any phone should connect to any other phone, but the connection is only needed for the call’s duration.

The central office switch makes this possible. It physically links the lines from any two phones using electrical switches. Years ago, multiple homes in a neighborhood might share a single line to the central office. This “party line” allowed anyone to listen in on their neighbor’s calls. With the introduction of automatic dialing, party lines became less popular, and each location got its own line and phone number. Connected phones had their own dedicated electrical circuit, which is where the term “circuit switching” originates.

Circuit Switching For Digital Lines

When long-distance calls transitioned from analog to digital, circuit switching remained the core concept. For example, a T1 line is split into 24 individual channels, each carrying a separate phone call as if on distinct wires.

T1 lines found a new use in connecting computers, enabling them to “talk” to each other. However, each channel only allows for 64 Kbps of data, which is equivalent to dial-up speed. A broadband circuit, reaching speeds of 1.5 Mbps, can be created by merging all the channels into a single transmission line. Like their analog predecessors, these circuits require a continuous, or “nailed up,” connection for computers to interact. Circuit switching works well for point-to-point communication, but what if many machines need to communicate at or near the same time?

What is Packet Switching?

Packet switching was invented to allow information sharing among numerous devices. It’s like a reimagined party line. However, unlike the old analog system, multiple “conversations” must happen concurrently without interfering with each other. If devices randomly sent bits of data onto the line, it would be chaos. Instead, the information intended for each network node is grouped into independent units called packets.

Packets contain pieces of data and address bits indicating their origin and destination. This is what enables packet switching. Instead of dialing a number to establish circuits, network switches and routers guide the packets using the addresses within them. Multiple devices can use the network line simultaneously as long as the traffic is managed effectively, and each packet includes its destination address.

Circuit vs Packet

Computer-based packet networks and telephone-based circuit networks have existed side-by-side for quite a while. The largest circuit-switched network is the PSTN, or Public Switched Telephone Network. The Internet holds the title of the largest packet-switched network. What we’re seeing now is a convergence of these two technologies.

Maintaining a single network is more efficient than managing two separate ones, and combining voice and data traffic on the same network opens up possibilities for additional services. But which technology comes out on top: circuit or packet switching?

And the Winner Is….

Packet switching is the clear winner, especially since global computer traffic has surpassed voice traffic. Computer traffic now includes digitized video, which alone surpasses the combined volume of voice and data. All of these utilize packet switching technology across the internet and private networks. As wireless voice communication shifts from dedicated cellular systems to packet-based 4G networks, the transition from circuit-switched to packet-switched networks will be complete.

What network connections are essential for your company or organization? The options are plentiful, ranging from traditional analog POTS lines and T1 digital trunks to dedicated copper and fiber optic Internet connections, multi-location Ethernet networks, and MPLS networks. Get pricing and availability today.

item.title: Asynchronous Pulsed Radiated Incident Light Communications
item.description:
A novel approach to “community” networking systems is being explored, inspired by a naturally occurring form of interconnected free space optical communications. This method transmits data using nanometer wavelengths, which are unregulated and currently not monetized, requiring minimal energy.

The underlying protocol, Asynchronous Pulsed Radiated Incident Light communications, falls under the Ultra Narrow Band (UNB) modulation category. It operates at a low bit rate, directly pulsing the lightwave emitter. Traditional free-space optics (FSO), while capable of high bandwidth over long distances, are limited to point-to-point connections. Creating a mesh network with FSO typically demands multiple transceivers per node, significantly increasing complexity and cost.

This new approach solves this challenge by ensuring all nodes within a local network have direct line-of-sight with each other, forming a three-dimensional communication sphere. These local networks, called swarms, self-organize like Bluetooth networks, maintaining asynchronous communication as nodes join or leave.

The low signaling rate minimizes processing power requirements and provides high resistance to noise and interference. The distinct yellow-orange pulses from individual emitters are easily tracked within the swarm. Security is based on mutual agreement among communicators, as transmissions are openly visible.

The IEEE has started standardizing this communication protocol, naming it FiFli and forming a dedicated forum. The initial draft standard, APRIL-1, is expected to evolve rapidly, with numerous versions anticipated. Currently, a debate within the committee revolves around naming the signaling metric, with “Natural Optical Wavelength Access Yield” (NOWAY) competing against the simpler “Wavelength Access Yield” (WAY).

Illustrations depicting FiFli technology can be found on T1 Rex. These include depictions of scientists studying the optical emitters, a small FiFli swarm in a lab setting, and an artistic interpretation of FiFli as an open and non-commercial standard.

item.title: Connectivity for Telemedicine and Remote Work
item.description:
By: John Shepler

The rapid emergence of the Coronavirus pandemic is speeding up existing trends, particularly telemedicine and remote work. Both heavily rely on broadband internet bandwidth. Let’s explore the available connection options.

Connecting the User

Most remote workers and telemedicine patients connect from home using devices like desktops, smartphones, laptops, or tablets. Home users often prefer cable broadband with speeds of 30 to 100 Mbps, while remote users rely on public WiFi or 4G/5G cellular broadband.

Individual employees or patients typically lack the resources for business-grade connections such as private lines, fiber optic, or point-to-point microwave. They rely on affordable last-mile connections, usually shared and asymmetric cable or cellular connections, with download speeds significantly higher than upload speeds.

These connections are generally suitable for remote logins, video calls, and website browsing, offering affordability and reliability.

Special Cases

Some medical equipment may not function optimally with home internet, requiring traditional landlines or specialized wireless access.

Businesses requiring higher performance might need dedicated leased lines like T1, Ethernet over Copper, or Fiber to the Premises for improved performance and security.

For broadcast-quality live video, a small remote studio with a dedicated Metro Ethernet private line might be necessary to avoid the audio and video issues common with consumer internet video chat services.

Business Bandwidth Options

Providers often have more demanding connectivity requirements than individual users. Companies or medical organizations supporting numerous simultaneous users connecting to a central, potentially cloud-based, system require robust connectivity.

Two key considerations are: connecting external users, primarily via internet broadband, and internal connectivity through Local Area Networks, potentially expanded via Metropolitan or Wide Area Networks to encompass multiple locations. A dedicated high-bandwidth cloud connection can also enhance the performance of cloud applications.

Sufficient internet bandwidth is crucial to accommodate peak user loads and surges in demand. Dedicated broadband internet using scalable Ethernet over Fiber can manage substantial demands, with Gigabit and 10 Gig E services widely accessible.

For enhanced performance and security, organizations might opt for internal networks isolated from the public internet. Point-to-point dedicated private lines offer a transparent network solution. For geographically dispersed locations, MPLS networks balance cost-effectiveness with high performance and robust security.

SD-WAN (Software Defined Wide Area Network) can optimize last-mile internet connections by intelligently routing traffic across various connection types, including wired, fiber optic, and wireless. This prioritizes demanding applications while ensuring efficient use of available bandwidth.

If your company is considering or actively implementing remote work or telemedicine, we can assist in finding the optimal connectivity solution at the most competitive price.

item.title: Cheap Internet Service is a Business Liability
item.description:
Digital networking offers exciting possibilities for improvement, speed, and cost savings, but it can also lead to frustrating connectivity issues. Many businesses invest in advanced systems like VoIP, expecting seamless communication and cost efficiency. However, they often face dropped calls, poor voice quality, and system crashes.

These issues can severely impact operations. Imagine running out of supplies because your automatic restocking system fails due to a dead internet connection. Picture losing a significant client because they couldn’t download important files due to connectivity problems. These scenarios highlight the potential consequences of unreliable internet service.

The allure of cheap internet often leads businesses astray. While a $50 per month broadband plan might seem appealing compared to a $500 one, the cheaper option often comes with limitations. These low-cost plans usually involve DSL or Cable internet, which are considered “extra” services and are not subject to the same regulations as primary services.

This “best effort” approach means your connection isn’t guaranteed. You share bandwidth with numerous users, leading to inconsistent speeds and frequent outages, especially during peak hours or when providers conduct maintenance. While DSL and Cable might be suitable for casual use, they can’t handle the demands of businesses relying on constant connectivity.

On the other hand, a dedicated T1 line, despite costing more, provides a consistent 1.5 Mbps upload and download speed. This dedicated connection guarantees reliability and speed, making it ideal for businesses that can’t afford downtime. Additionally, T1 service is regulated, meaning providers are obligated to provide prompt support and ensure consistent uptime.

Businesses, especially those new to networking, often learn the hard way that consumer-grade internet can’t meet their needs. Lost sales and customer dissatisfaction due to unreliable internet connectivity can far outweigh any initial savings. Investing in a professional-grade solution like a T1 line is crucial for businesses that rely heavily on internet connectivity.

For businesses seeking reliable connectivity solutions, options like T1 lines offer dedicated voice, data, or combined services. T1 lines are cost-effective and widely available. More extensive networks can benefit from MPLS networks, which offer secure and reliable connections between geographically dispersed locations.

T1 connection costs vary based on location, with prices as low as $399 per month in some areas. To determine if a T1 connection suits your business needs, consulting with experts who can provide tailored quotes and discuss available options is recommended.

item.title: Hosted VoIP Solutions Include New Phones
item.description:
Cloud services are changing how we think about technology. Just like server racks are moving to the cloud, so are office phone systems. Traditional PBX systems are being replaced by cloud-hosted solutions. But this transition begs the question: what happens to the physical phone lines?

Similar to connecting data servers off-site, a connection called a SIP Trunk links your on-premise network to the hosted PBX. While it’s possible to use existing analog phones with adapters, this approach misses out on the advanced features of Voice over IP (VoIP).

One major benefit of VoIP, particularly for larger businesses, is the integration of phone and computer networks into a single system. Phones become similar to computers, using RJ-45 connectors and possessing their own MAC addresses. This eliminates the need for rewiring or reprogramming when changes are necessary.

While analog phones can be adapted for VoIP using ATAs, this solution is generally suitable only for small businesses or home offices due to limited features. For most applications, switching to IP phones, designed specifically for VoIP, is recommended.

Building an in-house enterprise VoIP system requires significant upfront investment in new phones and IP PBX equipment. A more accessible option is a hosted PBX solution with a pay-as-you-go model, mirroring the popular cloud computing approach.

Hosted PBX providers offer comprehensive phone services billed monthly. While you can buy IP phones, many providers include lease costs in their per-user pricing. This ensures phone compatibility and simplifies support by having a single point of contact.

If you’re aiming to move away from continual capital expenditures and prefer a usage-based model, hosted VoIP may be the ideal solution. Request quotes from providers, compare features, and see how it stacks up against your current setup.

item.title: Drobo Mr. Storage Roboto
item.description:
Hard drive space disappears faster than you can imagine, especially with large digital media files like photos and videos. Even large hard drives fill up quickly.

While upgrading or adding hard drives seems like a solution, it creates new problems like managing backups and worrying about data loss from hard drive failures. These tasks can be time-consuming, especially for professionals working with large files. It’s almost like you need a personal assistant to manage it all.

Introducing Drobo, a device that acts like a “storage robot.” Shaped like a black cube, it has four slots for standard SATA hard drives. You simply insert the drives, and Drobo handles everything else.

Drobo’s sophistication extends beyond combining drive capacity. It safeguards your data against hardware failures using a system similar to RAID (Redundant Array of Inexpensive/Independent Disks) but with added flexibility.

Called SAFE (Secure, Automated, Flexible, Expandable), Drobo’s technology allows you to mix drives of different sizes without any configuration. If one drive fails, you won’t lose data. Just replace the faulty drive (indicated by a red light) with a new one. You can even start with one or two drives and add more as needed. Blue lights indicate the used capacity.

While Drobo utilizes some storage space for data protection (a 1.5 TB setup provides 929 GB usable space), the convenience of automated management makes it worthwhile.

Data Robotics designed Drobo for simplicity. Connect it to your PC or Mac via USB, insert the drives, and you’re done. Green lights indicate drive readiness. Drobo’s internal monitoring ensures data security and alerts you with a flashing red light if a drive needs replacement.

Drobo also works with both PCs and Macs through a USB connection. Alternatively, the optional Droboshare accessory enables network storage access over a 10/100/1000 Ethernet connection.

Learn more about the Drobo Fully Automated SATA Robotic Storage Array 4 Bay USB 2.0 and see if it’s the right solution for you.

item.title: Cheaper Business Broadband Abounds
item.description:
Due to budget constraints, many businesses are searching for cost-cutting measures that don’t negatively impact operations. Telecom and networking expenses are frequently targeted because they represent a significant monthly cost. It’s wise to examine these costs closely, as savings can often be found within your business broadband services.

Some managers may believe their telecom costs are fixed and non-negotiable, a perception stemming from contracts signed years ago with the sole provider available at the time - usually the local telephone company. This situation is now rare. Deregulation and technological advancements have led to numerous competitors, each offering unique advantages.

Consider the dedicated T1 line. It remains an excellent choice for business broadband, providing dedicated bandwidth, high availability, bonding options for increased bandwidth, and the security of a private, direct connection. However, T1 lines are often perceived as expensive.

This perception no longer holds true. T1 line prices have decreased significantly in recent years. If you’re operating on an old contract or a month-to-month agreement after its expiration, you’re likely missing out on significant savings. Requesting competitive T1 line quotes for your location will reveal potential cost reductions over the next three years, rather than remaining tied to the past decade’s rates.

Ethernet over Copper (EoC) is now available in many business districts for a cost comparable to T1. EoC simplifies interfaces by utilizing your network’s existing Ethernet standard, adapted for long-distance transmission over telephone copper cables. A 1.5 Mbps T1 line equivalent could potentially be upgraded to a 2 Mbps or even 3 Mbps EoC connection. However, this technology’s availability is limited by distance, typically within a few miles of the nearest telephone company central office.

Business-class cable broadband is another alternative. If a local cable operator (MSO) services your area, you might secure 25, 50, or even 100 Mbps cable broadband for a price comparable to a T1 line. Cable offers substantial bandwidth for the cost, but keep in mind that as a shared service, bandwidth can fluctuate. This may or may not be a concern depending on your needs. Additionally, upload bandwidth is significantly lower than download bandwidth. This difference is insignificant for web browsing, video streaming, software downloads, or email, but could pose limitations if your business frequently uploads large files to remote data centers or other locations.

For a more budget-friendly option without sacrificing reliable broadband, consider fixed wireless broadband utilizing 3G technology. This technology, similar to what powers laptops and smartphones, comes in a fixed installation format suitable for retail stores, construction sites, and other business locations. Expect typical 3G bandwidth speeds: up to 1 Mbps for downloads and significantly less for uploads. This option, costing potentially one-third of a T1 line and installable within a week, is suitable for point-of-sale connectivity, email, and occasional web browsing.

If you’re concerned about overpaying for business broadband, network services, or phone services, your concerns are likely valid. Don’t remain uncertain. Obtain current pricing and availability for business broadband and telephone services tailored to your location and requirements to uncover potential savings.

item.title: Vyvx and Genesis Offer Worldwide Video Transport
item.description:
The Power of Fiber for Video Transport

Those working in video production, distribution, news, or sports broadcasting need reliable video transport. While satellites have been the traditional choice, fiber optic networks offer compelling advantages, including vast bandwidth, minimal latency, and accessibility in popular locations. The Level 3 and Global Crossing merger brought together their video transport expertise, resulting in a comprehensive range of services.

Level 3’s Emmy Award-winning Vyvx service provides broadcast fiber services, managed video networks, teleport and satellite services, and venue-specific services. Their VenueNet service offers dedicated access at all major US league stadiums. In addition to Vyvx fiber access, Level 3 provides high-quality video encoding, internet, phone access, and dedicated support at each venue.

At Vyvx’s core lies a vast IP MPLS network, providing inherent VPN security, real-time video rerouting capabilities in case of network issues, and swift video connection setup and teardown. Users can book services in advance or utilize the 24/7 Vyvx booking center for last-minute needs. This flexibility is challenging with limited satellite bandwidth and practically impossible with dedicated point-to-point fiber connections over traditional networks.

Level 3 recently introduced uncompressed high-definition video transport between Los Angeles, Washington D.C., and New York City at speeds of 1.5 and 3.0 Gigabits per second. This allows video professionals to transmit live feeds in their original, uncompressed format.

Another Vyvx offering, the Managed Video Network Service (MVNS), is a fully managed distribution system providing fiber optic connectivity and necessary equipment. MVNS allows users to distribute broadcasts or pre-recorded video feeds to multiple destinations through a web-based booking system.

The Global Crossing acquisition brought Genesis Solutions, their competing video transport service, under the Level 3 umbrella. Genesis offers global HD video over IP, flexible bandwidth allocation, and immediate point-to-multipoint access setup.

Global Crossing’s converged IP network connects 700 cities across 70 countries. Genesis leverages this network to deliver specialized managed video services with both compressed and uncompressed transmission options. Dedicated bandwidth is available in increments from 2 Mbps to 270 Mbps. MPEG 2/4 compression equipment is available for encoding, decoding, transcoding, and compression to achieve the desired bit rate and format.

The compatibility between Vyvx and Genesis is evident. Combining the networks expands capacity and extends the reach to major global broadcast markets via fiber optic transmission. Eleven satellite teleports are also available for locations without fiber access.

For those requiring full-time or occasional video transport, Level 3 Vyvx Solutions offers the capability and experience to handle diverse needs. Don’t assume cost or capacity limitations; explore the available video transport service options and pricing to ensure your project’s timely and budget-friendly completion.

item.title: Low Latency WAN Options
item.description:
Businesses are increasingly demanding low latency in their WAN connections. But why is latency suddenly so important, and how can you achieve it?

Latency is the time it takes for data packets to travel between two points. While insignificant on local networks, latency can pose major problems on long-distance WAN connections, especially for applications where speed is critical.

It’s important to note that latency and bandwidth are not directly related. You can have slow connections with minimal latency and blazing-fast connections with terrible latency. Factors like distance, network design, and equipment quality are the primary drivers of latency.

Live television broadcasts exemplify a situation where latency is largely unavoidable. Imagine a news van transmitting a live feed to a studio. Regardless of their locations, the signal experiences significant latency due to the vast distances involved. This delay is why reporters and anchors must pause before responding to each other to avoid talking over one another.

The reason for this delay lies in the signal’s journey. It travels from the van’s satellite dish to a satellite in geosynchronous orbit approximately 22,236 miles above Earth and then back down to the studio. This round trip of at least 44,472 miles, coupled with the signal’s speed of 186,000 miles per second, results in a minimum quarter-second delay each way, totaling a half-second round trip. Any equipment or landline connections along the way further exacerbate this delay.

This explains why satellite broadband excels for one-way transmissions like TV broadcasts but struggles with two-way communication like VoIP calls. While streaming remains unaffected, two-way interactions suffer noticeably. Data transfers are less impacted as the latency is often small compared to the transfer time. However, video conferencing can be awkward, and real-time gaming becomes an exercise in frustration.

The key takeaway is to avoid geosynchronous satellite connections if latency is a concern. Remember that even landline and undersea connections are subject to a minimum one-millisecond delay per 186 miles due to the speed of light. In reality, achieving this minimum latency is impossible as copper wires, fiber optic cores, and network equipment introduce further delays.

So, what distinguishes a low-latency connection from a high-latency one? The answer lies in short routes between locations and minimal intermediary equipment. This suggests that private networks, not the internet, are the way to go. While the internet prioritizes universal access and resilience, latency takes a backseat.

Many modern MPLS networks are engineered for minimal latency, employing relatively few label switches for routing traffic and ample bandwidth to prevent congestion that exacerbates latency. Opt for networks with direct fiber optic connections to your locations to minimize distance. If MPLS meets your requirements, it offers cost advantages and mesh network capabilities for seamless communication between sites.

For absolute minimal latency, direct private line connections, specifically designed for this purpose, are the optimal choice. These fiber optic lines provide near-straight paths between locations with minimal electronic equipment to slow things down. However, these connections are primarily found between major international financial hubs like London, Frankfurt, New York, and Chicago, as high-frequency trading is the primary driver behind their deployment.

Do you require lower-latency connections or need to minimize latency on long-haul links? If so, explore the availability and pricing of Low Latency Fiber Optic Networks to evaluate your domestic and international options.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Recapping the Tone Control & FM Tuning Board (Unit #1)
item.description:
The final major task in the Beomaster 1900 restoration, detailed in the previous post, has been completed. This post covers the last board requiring capacitor replacements: the Tone Control & FM Tuning Board. Replacing the ten capacitors on this board is straightforward due to their accessibility. The true challenge lies in cleaning and fixing the three slider controls: Bass, Treble, and Balance.

Before images of the Tone Control & FM Tuning Board are shown below.

Work began by cleaning and restoring the slide controls.

Disassembling the Bass and Treble sliders revealed a prior repair attempt, likely performed alongside the main board’s bridge rectifier replacement, although the two are unrelated.

The slide controls have a design flaw where the control contacts attach to the sliding control bridge. The bridge’s small black plastic piece, which houses the contacts, is prone to breakage. A glue repair on the bass control bridge points to an attempt to address this issue.

The treble slider control is depicted below.

A reliable slider control bridge repair kit was likely unavailable at the time of the glue repair, which likely provided a temporary fix. Given the eventual failure of such repairs, the current solution involved using a replacement bridge sourced from Martin Olsen of Beoparts.

The photo below showcases the new Beoparts bridge alongside the original bridge intended for the bass control slider.

The image below shows the bass slider control contacts mounted on the new bridge.

Cleaning and lubricating the rails on which the contacts slide is another crucial step in the slider control repair.

Deoxit and conductive carbon grease were used. The bass control slider is now ready for reassembly and reinstallation on the Tone Control & FM Tuner Board.

The treble slider control is now ready for reassembly.

Anticipation to listen to this Beomaster receiver grows. However, some tasks remain.

The last slider control, the balance control, differs in style from the others. While visually similar, its design eliminates the need for repairs required by the bass and treble controls. This balance control slider style is preferable due to its enhanced durability.

Nevertheless, it still requires cleaning and lubrication.

Before-and-after pictures of the balance slider control cleaning are shown below.

Moving on to capacitor replacements, the electrolytic capacitors in this Beomaster, similar to others, were found to be out of tolerance.

Below is the one in the worst condition, a 2.2uF capacitor.

It measured a staggering 6.27uF.

Below is a photo of the fully restored Tone Control & FM Tuning board.

The final steps before testing involve replacing the Beomaster 1900 indicator lamps, a task scheduled for tomorrow.
